Bottom line and stockholders are more important than individual employees (although this shouldn't be surprising in a large corporation).

pros: Great benefits and overall good internal customers to work with. Good mission work.
cons:
Poor Internal Operational leadership.  If one is working in a non-billable position within the company, it's about control and not about doing the right thing by your internal customer and what's right for the business.  Way too much cat fighting and napoleon complexes. Lot's of bullying tactics in the workplace.  No inclusion, collaboration, team playing and transparency.  It's about ONLY the bottom-line and not about the people as the benefits would make one think.  Leadership can be less than willing to allow one to take time off when needed.

Not a strong resource in place to help one find work when contract comes to an end.  The employee is on their own.  

Difficult to navigate through the company.  Too many road blocks.

review_title: Grabbing hold of my career and taking it somewhere else.
pros: Flexible schedule.  Ok insurance benefits, although costs continue to increase as benefits diminish.
cons: Performance review system recently "improved" is too complex, not well explained, and hence fraught with more excessive inequities than the previous system.  Instructions for entering "commitments" are vague, general, bloated with corporate-speak, and effectively meaningless.  End result is that any employee not in favor can always be told that (s)he did not meet expectations.  Raises and advancement have very little correlation to ability and performance.  Employees often are not used in their areas of expertise.  The company has become totally oriented to the bottom line with little to no true concern for the well-being of the employees, although much lip-service is given to the contrary.  Employees are pushed in never-ending cycles to meet schedule after overlapping schedule, forced by the "bottom line" to push out shoddy software in order to come in at or below increasingly unrealistic budget constraints.

pros: Numerous projects to work on, many people on the same team to help aide in your career.  Great history of standards and company procedures to learn how a engineering should be done.  Great senior engineering people on staff that have been with the company for many years.  Great benefits and 401K matching while I was there.
cons: It can be very hard to move up within this company depending on the program you are staffed on.  If the program is doing well then the raises and promotions will occur, but otherwise the reverse is true.  Sometimes it feels as if you are just a number and your manager in another office that is 4-5 states away doesn't know what you do let alone they don't have the ability to see what you do for your program team on a day-to-day basis.  Work sharing can be difficult between offices as there are so many across the US.

pros:
-Stable employment
-LM will be around for a long time
-Culture is changing, albeit terribly slow
cons:
-Insurance & Benefits continue to decline to more "align with competition"
-Yearly raises do not keep up with inflation and other employers (even in a year with record-setting stock prices)
-Travel is encouraged, but made to be a pain for expense reports and scheduling due to recent changes.

Personal observations - I've been:
-Flat-out lied to regarding promised transfers, affecting my personal life significantly.
-Promised a flexible schedule around core hours, then criticized and disciplined when using this "benefit" to support my single-parent status.

review_title: A great stepping stone to better opportunities.
job_title: Embedded Software Engineer in Owego, NY
pros: Many employment opportunities for recent college grads.  Lockheed Martin is a large company with many projects and locations; there is usually something that will interest you.  Decent pay and benefits and a good tuition reimbursement program.
cons: Management positions are plentiful, high paying, and stable, but ultimately a burden to the company and projects.  Schedules and budgets are often overly aggressive and with a lack of engineers and decent tools (software and hardware).  The company is obsessed with earned value management practices and program schedules / statistics since this is their foundation for bidding on new contracts - engineers are at the mercy of a race to be the cheapest.  Strongly encouraged overtime due to a shortage of engineers.

pros: LM is a good place to work.  The commitment to ethics is not just for show.  Lots of really smart people.  Lots of opportunity within the company.  Plenty of variety in projects and things to work on.  The programs you work on are critical to the nation (i.e. the work you do actually matters).  Solid business base and backlog.  LM is a great American company.
cons: Very process heavy, bureaucratic, slow to act.  Lack of will to try new things.  Lots of ex-military and ex-government people try to make LM operate like the military / government.  Too much compliance training.  Heavy east coast focus and perspective.

review_title: I used to be disgusted...now I try to be amused.
job_title: Computer Specialist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: So many cool projects, so little time! Honest, if you can find a good manager who can keep you in charge numbers for projects that interest you, you will never be bored. And it's not all missiles and airplanes and shoot-em-out-of-the-sky stuff. You can hold your head high no matter what your politics are. You can be as intellectually challenged as you want to be.
cons: After a while the paperwork/time accounting starts to get to you. And lately it's getting harder and harder to find the magic charge numbers to justify your existence. Did I mention ethics training? The buildings (in the Bay Area, anyway) are drab and the people dress to match them!  Women are few and far between, BTW. But on the flip side, the're wicked smaht :-)

review_title: You should work for Lockheed Martin.
pros:
Lockheed supports a good work / life balance and an 'open door' policy with access to management.  Employees are encouraged to be 'free thinkers' and make suggestions to improve processes & procedures.  Compensation is aligned with industry standards.  The benefits offered for medical, dental, 401K, etc are outstanding.
Employees enjoy a business casual environment but everyone knows you have a job to do.
cons: Frequent re-organizations should be expected - and the end result sometimes leaves you scratching your head wondering "Why?"  Which brings up the next point - management does not readily share information with non-management staff.  Meetings hosted by executives tend to sugarcoat & wordsmith conditions masking what the real situation might be.

review_title: Great Place to Launch Your Career
job_title: Multi Functional Financial Analyst in Grand Prairie, TX
pros:
There really are a lot of wonderful things about Lockheed, especially for a new hire:
1) Competitive New Hire Pay
2) Meaningful Work - in my role, I'm the sole financial analyst over contracts that can be worth anywhere from $50K to $300M.  The Program Managers come to me for data, analysis, understanding and advice.
3) The End Customer - The US Gov is not fun to work for; HOWEVER working with the military and knowing how quality product reach our customer IS fun to work for
4) Benefits - 401K matching, tuition reimbursement, GREAT health/dental/vision benefits compared to most Fortune 500, rotational Leadership Development Programs, classes (including Six Sigma training)
5) Work-life Balance - You work pretty close to a 40-hour work week in most positions, business or engineering; Also, a lot of sites, including Dallas, work a 9-80 schedule, which means every other Friday is off! Believe it or not, it's even more enjoyable than it sounds.  Vacation is great and the plant shuts down at Christmastime (and that doesn't take away from your vacation hours!
6) Locations - After a year in a job, it's not too difficult to move to other locations across the country if you want; and Lockheed helps pay for the move
7) Products - We make fighter jets and missile launchers.  What we do is LITERALLY rocket science.  It's pretty cool.  I like telling people I work for real-life Stark Industries.
8) Advancement - Some might feel it comes too slow, but generally you can move up a level every 2-3 years for the first 10 years, which means a pay bump.
cons:
I've had several coworkers leave for several different reasons.  Here are some cons I see and have heard from others:
1) Pay - Although the pay starts out competitive, it doesn't grow as fast as other companies.  Many of my coworkers left for other companies in the area and got a 20-25% pay bump.  Of course, they lose some perks, like every other Friday off, etc, but they get more dough.
2) Culture - Lockheed Martin is fairly old school.  That appeals to some, but a lot of Millennials I see struggle with it.  Millennials often feel leaders micro-manages too much, that advancements don't come quick enough, that they are not being recognized for all their contributions.
3) The Customer - Working for the war fighter feels awesome.  Working for the war fighter through departments in the US Government is frustrating.  The problem is, Lockheed Martin relies on one main customer - the USG.  So what is to stop the gov from demanding what they want?  Competition is tough, so LM has to give in a lot.
4) No Bonuses
5) Earned Value Management - Defense Contractors have to follow a system of measurement that is unique to defense contractors called Earned Value Management.  EVM can be useful but it requires a lot of extra work on the part of the engineer and financial analyst.  And it really doesn't translate to the world outside of government work.
6) Pigeon-hole - This is for financiers more so than other business areas or engineers; the type of financial work defense contractors do is pretty different than most commercial companies.  If you want to move to another industry but you have been at LM a long time, you might find it hard to pitch what you have done in a way that is relatable to other companies.
7) High Level Management Doesn't Care - Honestly, this is probably true for most companies.  The Missiles & Fire Control division just went through layoffs (for the first time in a long time) and honestly, it didn't seem like upper management cared too much.  The packages given to those laid off were decent, but it didn't feel like management shared in our pain.  The CEO also seems like she has no interest in the individual employee.  When the government shut down and some contracts had to be put in stop-work, she didn't really offer a lot of support to those who had nothing to work on.  They just had to wait it out.

Management has a penchant of Promoting of people who have become insiders to position well above thiere abilities because they offer solution that will cut costs ant the expense of good engineering  only to the insult to the customer 
The  manager took away my portable and gave me a PC in the middle of an bid and proposal work carried out in another building Talk about design to fail functions of management.

pros: Challenging work environment where you can learn, grow and go far. Diversity is valued and encouraged. Main client is US Federal Government and there is always something new. Benefits for the "Old Lockheed" were outstanding, and many retirees have glowed enthusiastically about how good a place it was for them. Ethics Minutes are always good to view, and kudos for bringing HR/legal problems into the open.
cons: Large awkward Management Structure. Little to no communication between many programs makes it impossible to know where career opportunities exist. Benefits for the "New Lockheed" are ho-hum, generic, and always increase in cost to employee from year-to-year. Programs are jealous of their own people making it difficult to move from one contract to another. The "now you are part of the Lockheed Family" is a thing of the past.

review_title: Good place to work, but the salaries leave something to be desired.
pros: Lockheed Martin is a very organized and well managed company.  They really have their act together.  The are the top defense contractor and their level of competency is a big reason for it.  The benefits are good and they are active in showing community support.  Overall a good place to work, a lot of talented engineers that know how to get the job done.
cons: Too often the company line is the status quo.  Part of the downside of being the top defense contractor is that they tend to stiff their employees on their salaries.  Sharing the wealth would promote loyalty among employees and reduce attrition.  Lockheed has one of the highest attrition rates and it is not hard to see why.  The yearly performance appraisal system can also be long and cumbersome and often result in a 2-5% raise at best.  Perhaps sitting down with employees would be a better approach.

review_title: Great place to learn a lot but difficult to get things done because of bureaucracy.
job_title: Unix Systems Administrator in New Orleans, LA
pros: Lockheed Martin promotes a very diverse and pleasant work environment and stresses inclusion of all peoples as a core aspect of what makes the company what it is.  Lockheed Martin stresses honesty and accountability as well.  Most divisions of Lockheed have benefits that exceed those of competitors.
cons: The level of bureaucracy in working for a major Defense contractor is astounding.  There are two sets of hoops to jump through to get anything accomplished, Corporate and then Government and the two policies generally don't overlap often causing tons of red tape to get the mission accomplished.  In general I didn't feel that the best candidates were promoted to management.  Senior managers seemed to pick and choose people to groom and everyone knew that those individuals were the ones that were going to be promoted to management down the line regardless of their level of leadership abilities or technical competence.

review_title: Lifetime job that will halt your development as a coder
job_title: Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Lockheed offers a stable job with decent benefits.  If you do the right things there are opportunities to advance up the ladder.
cons:
Lockheed tends to be a decade behind the commercial world in terms of processes and technologies used.  I find that the good software engineers are quickly pushed up the chain -- leaving almost no seasoned developers at the lower levels.  Many people being pushed up don't want to leave the code, however advancement opportunities quickly dry up as a developer as Lockeed prefers to just throw warm bodies in those positions.  Those ranks tend to be filled with either level one/two (newer coder) developers or higher level developers that haven't coded for a long time that have the urge to do so again.

Overall this leads to anyone who actually cares about developing their skills as an engineer (TDD, core patterns, etc) with no one to really go look up to improve their skills.

review_title: It's a comfortable job, but it lacks in professional development, performance recognition, and strong leadership.
job_title: Financial Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: A comfortable job with great benefits. You start at a higher salary than many of your peers. The schedules are flexible and the time off is plentiful. You rarely work more than a 40 hour week.
cons: Career trajectory is almost flat and the promotion process is highly political. Hard work and performance is generally not rewarded. Rather, "time in service" and non-professional bonds tend to be the measure management uses to promote. I left feeling the company was great at designing new products, but was a poorly run business.

pros: If you like your work ethic / performance determined by how many hours per week you sit in a certain chair, this is the job for you! Benefits are industry standard or slightly worse. Company size means there is a place for almost everyone, but you'd be lucky to find your way there.
cons:
Their recruitment sessions should be considered fraud. They hire more people than they have space for, with no plans as to what they will be doing (but recruiters say anything to get them to accept the offer), and then shovel them in to whatever government-funded program they can put more burden hours onto.  Most of these positions will offer you no growth of skills and nothing of value to a resume, if you care about your future career. 
All new employments are at-will (easy to immediately lay off large numbers), pensions were recently taken away and raises are laughable ("we have no money") despite record profits and shareholder payouts. Employees get less as the company gets more. That combined with the illogical hiring practices and horrible allocation of appropriate skillsets smells like disaster for job security and the long term future of the company.

review_title: All federal contractors are the same...
pros: Most people don't understand that the federal government is full of contractors who work at govt buildings with govt employees, doing govt work.  Lockheed simply has the contract; I've only met my LM supervisor a few times - I answer almost exclusively to my government supervisor.  So working "almost" for the federal govt is nice; I find the work interesting and even rewarding.  I get a lot of chances for overtime which is rare for contractors.
cons: As with all federal contractors, there's a constant race to the bottom.  5 years ago my employer paid us for snow days and even gave us annual bonuses.  Now you have to take time unpaid leave to go to your own holiday party - it's ridiculous.

review_title: Lockheed Martin can be a great place to work but it definately depends on the location.
job_title: Technical Writer in Lexington Park, MD
pros: Room for growth and great schedule flexibility.
cons: It can be difficult to transfer to other Lockheed corporations.  It appears that you can sometimes get locked into a position that is difficult to leave.  Apparently, other Lockheed Martin business units must get approval from the program manager's approval prior to interviewing the employee.  I have heard of our program manager not allowing some of my co-workers to interview with other business units.  Some of the employees at our business unit are underpaid and at times overworked.  Our program manager can be very rude to the employees and the morale at our facility is rather low at times.  It all stems from our program manager so I am sure other business units are not run the same way.

review_title: Some good things and bad things about working for the largest US defense contractor.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Manassas, VA
pros: Good place to start your career.  Large company with opportunities to get involved with many aspects of engineering.  Many organizations seem to truly care about the welfare of their employees.
cons: It is difficult to advance and stay on the technical track - there is a lot of pressure to assume lead positions which are supposed to be technical but involve too many aspects of a management job.  There are a lot of processes which must be followed which are supposed to enhance the quality of the delivered product but which end up making the company much less agile and its labor cost too high when compared with competitors.

pros: Lockheed Martin carries one of the heaviest pedigrees within the engineering industry.  As an intern you will receive a generous salary along with certain benefits that include relocation expense compensation and an opportunity to attend, with all other LM interns, a symposium in Norfolk, VA where you get a chance to see some of LM's more recent and up and and coming products.  Great intern experience and a great name to have on your resume.   Overall, a great place to work for.
cons: Huge company where all employees are carrying a significant share of the workload.  Consequently, those in charge of you don't have enough time to delegate tasks to their interns and, as an intern, you tend to sit around and twittle your thumbs.

job_title: Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Very flexible work schedule. Ability for advancement. Can learn a lot of information about a lot of different technologies by moving between projects.
cons: Like any large company you are really just a number. Moving between projects has a formal interview process. In other words, Lockheed Martin is a huge umbrella corporation comprised of many small/medium sized companies. Can be very difficult to get another internal job. Health insurance plan is not good at all. Seems like every year more benefits erode away. With government budget cuts in defense spending... it's possible that we will see close to $400 billion dollars cut from defense over the next decade or so. This would cause Lockheed to shed somewhere in the ballpark of 12,000 jobs.

review_title: Great company to work for. Would go back in a minute if the right opportunity arised.
job_title: Senior Software QA Test Engineer/Analyst in Lakewood, CO
pros: Good benefits, good ethics and policies, and competitive company. Overall supportive management and good talented employees. Nice perk of discounts for employees with many different companies, health club membership, etc.
cons: Found it harder in the economic downturn to get additional training funds that I desired to help me grow professionally and advance to other positions in the company. As with many bigger companies, the HR functions, IT and your reporting management may not be local and may be more difficult or time consuming to get appropriate answers and assistance when needed.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Bethesda, MD
pros: In the time I've worked for Lockheed Martin, I've been able to do something very different every 3 - 4 years. This ability to move to different functions means that you only get board if you let yourself.  For someone like me, this has been very good.
cons: While the ability to move is really good, there are times when poor leadership decisions make it necessary to move prematurely. This can be frustrating because it's nice to see the things you put in motion come to fruition. Furthermore, while some excellent leaders will help you through these changes, many take a completely hands off approach and force you to fend for yourself.

review_title: Working towards my career and taking it elsewhere
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Flexible schedule. Ok insurance benefits, although costs continue to increase as benefits diminish.
cons: Cons – Performance review system recently "improved" is too complex, not well explained, and hence fraught with more excessive inequities than the previous system. Instructions for entering "commitments" are vague, general, bloated with corporate-speak, and effectively meaningless. End result is that any employee not in favor can always be told that (s)he did not meet expectations. Raises and advancement have very little correlation to ability and performance. Employees often are not used in their areas of expertise. The company has become totally oriented to the bottom line with little to no true concern for the well-being of the employees, although much lip-service is given to the contrary. Employees are pushed in never-ending cycles to meet schedule after overlapping schedule, forced by the "bottom line" to push out shoddy software in order to come in at or below increasingly unrealistic budget constraints.

review_title: Solid company lots of room to shine
job_title: Financial Analyst Staff in Arlington, VA
pros: LM is a Large company with many locations. This allows to move around and work in many areas. LM is often rated as a great place to start your career. I agree this is a good company for junior employees who want to get experience. Benefits vary between the business units. I would say the range is from decent to bad. Since the company is so large there is a lot of investments made in tools to help employees manage their careers. There is also a decent number of conferences to attend and network and learn. Unfortunately you must pay/attend these conference on your on dime. Great leadership Principles
cons:
Pay is below market average.
Mediocre employees create a demotivating work environment
Not a team atmosphere, people trying to throw one another under the bus to keep their job
lots of downsizing
Time off varies by contract/business unit. vacation varies between 2-3 weeks, depending on the benefits package. Sick time is basically non-existent. Employees are expected to flex time to make up any time off.

pros:
Semi-flexible work schedule.
Decent pay (for now)
cons:
Very limited career paths
Benefits have been all but eliminated over the past 4 years.
"Mandatory OT" for salary employees.

review_title: Overall a Great Place for your Career if you Love the Work
job_title: Software Engineer II in Owego, NY
pros:
-Overall a great company to work for. 
-Interesting Tech
-Amazing 401k (up to 10%, 4% (depending on when hired) match if you put in 8%, and LM puts in up to 6% into another 401k company stock fund)
-3 Weeks Vacation and 5 Days Sick/General PTO
- Flexible Work from Home
- Laid back atmosphere
- Talented and great people
- HSA account
- Currently, defense is solid
- Managers are very Professional
cons:
- Many cases, outdated tools
- Management is old school, promotions are mainly years of service over effort and accomplishments. 
- A lot of decisions are manager discrepancy
- Bonuses are now only for Sr Level Employees or above (they think this will retain employees, I beg to differ).

review_title: Lockheed is best large defense contractor...work here if defense programs are your thing
pros: At Lockheed Martin, we work on products that are of national importance.  Lockheed Martin is a very large corporation with opportunities to work at various locations in the U.S. and abroad.  Lateral moves are easy, vertical moves are much harder.  It is a very political business/company, so applicants beware.
cons: Large defense programs can be slow and it takes a lot of experience before an employee truly adds value to a team or organization.  This is extremely frustrating for entry-level employees coming straight from college where performance and recognition are virtually instantaneous.  Salary and salary progression are very well matched with other large defense contractors - you probably won't "cheat" the system and get paid outrageous money, but you also won't be left behind with zero percent every year.

pros: Quite good wages and friday off every other week
cons:
Terrible disaster of a company, which Lockheed took over, big mistake for them, should have left it for dead. Still its not too late and probably will drop them like a stone when they fail big style on the contracts. 
       The only people that are happy working there must be on pills, so i wouldnt listen to them! Most appalling place i ever worked in, dreadful politics, useless staff and megalomaniac management. Rampent culture of framing employees for senior staff failures by forcing them to write documents with content that would incriminate themselves in the event of failure. These failures would most certainly occur which is why the senior staff dont want their name on the documents.Those that spot this and refuse to play along are then bullied by management till they quit. Relevant HR arent based on site and do absolutely nothing if you complain.
      Almost 50% turnover of staff in just one year, sadly they will land in another company that is most likey the same.

pros: Excellent management at all levels.  The company really lives out its beliefs: Do What's Right, Respect Others, Perform with Excellence. There are many career paths to take within Lockheed and no one is limited to a single path.  Management will work with employees to shape and guide careers.  The company supports employees and allows flexible work schedules.  CEO Marilyn Hewson is an outstanding communicator, and keeps in touch with the worker-bees.  Overall, an excellent place to work.
cons: In big companies a lot of emphasis is put on winning bids, and high-fives are given to teams that win.  However, a lot good work is also done on a losing effort. Professionals work really hard even when they lose, and their effort should be recognized and high-fives passed around.

pros: They have a nice office and a lot of nice (but unhappy) people working for them. They have a good employee discount program.
cons: Its a call center with varying call traffic. On back to back day's sometimes your not allowed to use any sort of auxiliary phone function to complete your notes if the call drops. Everything must be letter perfect. If you forget to punctuate any part of your notes you can get in trouble. At one point I had to go to the Emergency room, I asked permission first and I brought back ALL documentation and still got in trouble for it. Part of the problem is that we don't have an HR person, the one they tell us to talk to is in another state and is completely unreachable. Their benefits are too expensive, I had to go to the exchange to buy mine because I cant afford theirs for my family. There are no real benefits to working here other than putting Lockheed Martin on your resume.

pros: Salary is high and competitive
cons: It's a behemoth of a company that is old and set in its ways. Upper management and leaders of the company only care that its image is good enough to make it onto marketing materials or for a corporate interview about how they care about veterans, the disabled, or the environment; most of the day-to-day runnings of the departments are by lower-to-middle management and they are often incompetent, small-minded, and corrupt. Most do not care about their staff; they only care about looking good in the Stay-Green Meetings (whether a project is on track), and upper management doesn't care about how the manager got those numbers, as long as they're in the green. This is a company that will not fire a manager for sexual harassment or staff complaints or other egregious actions but will reassign him or her instead. In some segments of industry they say they are cutting edge but in fact are mired in outdated thoughts and processes.

review_title: Its a good place to start off coming out of college.
pros: Lockheed Martin provides good pay, benefits, 401k.  They do a company match up to a certain % on the money you put into your 401k each week.  They also match a certain % of your pay and put it in a separate 401k that is substituted as our pension plan.  Being a big company and having jobs all over the country it provides so many opportunities in location, type of jobs.  They have leadership programs for less experience employees were they can work about 5 different program and jobs in 3 years related to there jobs skills, which is great to get different experience and to help determine what you want to focus on.
cons: The politics you have to go through to get something simple done.  No pension plan.  Poor or no documentation, which makes it a big problem once the system developer is not available.

review_title: Good company, but is slow to adapt and make good changes.
pros:
Benefits were good (not great).
Hours were good depending on the project.
Many good job opportunities within the company especially if you wanted to travel. 
To keep costs down, company encourages good health practices.
Good amount of vacation with emphasis to take the vacation for work/life balance.
Company has values most people will agree with.
cons:
Stuck in some of the old ways of doing things. LM is a big company, and it is hard to get meaningful change within the corporation - mostly due to the nature of the type of work that has to be done for their customers. 
Leadership keeps changing organization and realigning departments, but it doesn't do anything other than confuse the workers. 
Cost of healthcare benefits continue to rise. Raises did not cover the difference in health care costs.
Going through a rough spot and not afraid to let good people go.
Has very interesting work or very plain, grunt work. It is up to the individual to seek out their career path.

review_title: You can get better work, better benefits, or better pay elsewhere.
job_title: R&D Software Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- Large number of projects going on
- Relocation/rotations available throughout the united states
- One of very few places that do certain types of work (e.g., space systems, very large scale projects)
- Vacation/work-life-balance was good where I worked [however, friends on other programs did have to deal with hellish 60+ hour mandatory weeks because of management screw ups related to vastly over-promising things to the customer]
cons:
- Crippling bureaucracy
- Poor incentives.  Pay was significantly below market for the area; you were generally expected to leave for a competitor if you wanted to make more money.  This relates to the next bullet:
- Good engineers generally left after a short period of time (< 2 years), either for more money, more interesting/fulfilling work, or just to avoid the stifling atmosphere of pointy-haired bosses.  This constant attrition of actual good talent left behind a husk of barely competent mouth-breathers that one has to deal with on a day-to-day basis.

pros:
Smart engineers and scientists have no reason to choose Lockheed Martin.  Young females and female minorities are given every opportunity and second chances to excel at Lockheed Martin.  Senior employees tend to suck because they are part of the good old boy system.  

Any young female that cannot sing kudo's about Lockheed Martin are just plain, lazy, complainers.  

Sharp aero engineers go to work at NASA, SpaceX or Orbital sciences.  SpaceX is eating Lockheed Martins lunch.
cons: Lockheed Martin is missing to many "Pro's" about working there.  This company is the epitome of government graft and corruption.  This company intentionally under bids US government contracts because they know there is always the time and money to do it over again.  Case in point F-35, FBM, 'any software product', ULA, F-22, THAAD, C-5 Mod., ABL, etc. etc. etc.  Overrunning is Lockheed Martins business model and the customer doesn't care because they are looking for a job at Lockheed Martin as soon as they retire from their government job.

pros: I enjoyed some of the people I worked with.  The pay is good and paycheck is dependable.  The benefits are plentiful but expensive and deductible is extremely high.
cons:
I was laid off after 15 years of service and lost pension.  I planned to retire from the company but was walked out without even consideration of jobs that were currently open and that I qualified for. 
The environment is stale and quiet.  Sitting in a maze of cubes in complete silence without windows can be very depressing.  The only thing that keeps you from losing your mind is every other Friday off. They do nothing to build morale.

job_title: Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
The people are great, and you can really tell most are open and embracing change. The people I work with have been here 30 years or more, and are open minded to new employees perspectives, and most are very willing to teach/help/transfer knowledge.

Pay is great. Location is great in my opinion. The flexibility is worth A LOT to me. Most benefits are pretty good.

My immediate management is great.
cons:
Health insurance is bad?

They showed a graph that shows they promote based on their need for higher level engineers. Meaning if they have a lot of really good engineers, many will not received deserved promotions, because they only need average engineers at the time. Don't be surprised when experienced engineers leave when they hit a career wall simply because Lockheed just doesn't need someone that good.

pros:
Get to work with really nice people
Okay benefits package, pretty standard for industry
Yearly pay rise, performance based
cons:
Charge code culture is toxic
No training, for grads or more senior members of staff
Badly managed and structured teams
Struggles to embrace change, or listen to new ideas
Seems to prefer to hire people with skills instead of training staff (Even though staff are willing to do the training)
Grad scheme is a waste of what little money is spent on it
Seems to have a 'it's not what you know but who' culture when it comes to career progression
Flexi-time isn't really flexi-time, you have to do 75 hours in two weeks and the hours are capped so you can't do too little or too many a week.
Mixture of line manager competence, can cause confusion when information is shared through them.

review_title: Lockheed Martin is a good place to work, but it lacks passion.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Huntsville, AL
pros: Generous vacation in available.  Management is willing to work with employees when they need time off.  Job security is a plus.  Work hours are often very flexible.
cons: The performance review system is ineffective.  Salaries seem middle of the road.  There are many entrenched employees who are sometimes difficult to work with, and often ineffective.  The required processes involved are often excessive.  Project progression (and thus learning) is exceptionally slow.  Project development lacks dynamic atmosphere.

review_title: Good company for fresh college grads but not the best place older people.
pros: Its is a great place for those fresh out of college but you will reach a glass ceiling within 10 years.
cons: Career advancement is very limited. Rewards for great jobs commendation from customers is very limited. I get better reviews from the customer than from local management. Over the last decade I have received 6 commendations from the customer but not one from the company, worse the company didn't even recognize the customer commendations. Something is terribly wrong with thi picture.

review_title: One small grain of sand in the ocean
pros: Lockheed has a lot of contracts to work on in the DC area. They do a lot of different kinds of work. You can always find the technology you want to work on somewhere within the company. The people are generally great to work with. Working with government types is a great experience. There are an abundance of training options, and the best educational reimbursement I know of in this economy.
cons:
Your work location may change on a whim. You won't always work in the cleanest of facilities. The amount of restrictions you have can become burdensome at times. The pay is low compared to other companies, but there are a lot of opportunities for promotion and growth if you put extra effort into it.

There is way to much management. A lot of managers seem to not have a general competency in the technologies they oversee, which is frustrating.

Bonuses are awful.

Lunches are terrible.

review_title: A big company that works like a big company
job_title: Electrical Engineer Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
- Very important work that will provide a sense of purpose.
- At the working level, there are some truly great people.
- Fort Worth is a wonderful area to live.
cons:
- There seems to be a corporate wide effort to outsource as much engineering and technical work as possible.
- Upper management seems to be encouraged to separate themselves from line level workers.
- Incentives for upper level management are often counter to stated company goals.
- Good managers are put into a difficult position of towing the misdirected company line while still trying to motivate employees.
- The latest management tool (e.g. EVMS, SAFe/AGILE) will be forced on all workers regardless of any possible benefit beyond a specific area.
- Performance appraisals will mostly focus on justifications (read that as excuses) for a minimal compensation.  These justifications will often directly contradict quarterly performance reports.
- Trying very hard to form an inverted pyramid business structure.

pros: Amazing and intriguing programs to work on from Aerospace to Space Systems to Missiles...truly amazing the types of programs you get to work on! It is so well structured, I haven't experienced another company with better stucture, processes, procedures, policies. All well thought out and the employees actually follow it! Flex work options, awesome benefits and employee discounts! I miss getting paid weekly and 9/80 flex weeks! So easy to move around within the company! You can experience whatever you want once you are an internal employee.
cons:
It is extremely hard to get back into LM once you leave. I have been trying for 2 years and still haven't been able to get back w/them. 
I will also say that their compensation is a little lower than other companies i have worked for but the benefits are great. You can easily move around in the company but advancing from level to level can be tough.

review_title: Lockheed is not the best place to work.
pros: It is fulfilling to contribute to the defense of the United States. You may have access to technologies and projects that just don't exist in the private sector. Usually there is a good emphasis on work life balance. It is a huge company that has a lot of interesting projects. Lockheed makes missiles, satellites, ships, and the best military jets in the world. The benefits are above average. In general the people you work with are very patriotic and nice. There is a sense of pride in working for Lockheed Martin and you generally won't be ashamed you work for them.
cons: You will see firsthand how much waste, inefficiency, and fanboy jingoism exists in the defense industry In the non-defense sector Lockheed would be eaten for lunch. Too bloated, too full of itself.

review_title: A good job if you are proactive and can tolerate red tape.
job_title: Senior Electro-Optics Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good steady pay check.  If you network correctly you can find some very technically interesting cutting edge programs.  the benefits are good.  you get to work a 9/80 schedule (every other friday off).  you get three weeks of vacation, flex time and you can work on your off days to build up to two weeks of additional vacation time.  They're also ok with you working from home from time to time.  Very accommodating as employers go.
cons: Red tape and excessive process.  If you don't network properly you can can easily get pigeon holed in a boring uncreative job.  You can spend way too much time doing mind numbing documentation because your following some arcane directive that wasn't originally crafted with your project in mind but which got blindly applied to all programs across the company

pros: Some of the work will be interesting.  Being a defense contractor, Lockheed Martin is involved in the high tech industry, including the development of hardware and software, that is in constant daily use by many of the largest government agencies sporting three letter acronyms.  Contractor work on this level doesn't have quite the safety and job stability as outright government work, but it has more than you would find at a traditional civilian company.  If you are technically inclined, and very detail oriented with a preference for hierarchical structures, defense contractors can be a good place to work, and many employees work for ten or more years before retiring or moving on.
cons: The politics and the paperwork grind down many people.  Most of the people have a military background, and so accept the environment to some extent, but there is also a wide recognition that the procedure oriented nature of the company and the back room politics compromise the central mission.

review_title: Great work environment, below average compensation
job_title: Finance LDP Asc in Gaithersburg, MD
pros:
- I have had fantastic experiences with my co-workers and management team
 - Management team presents challenging opportunities to continue growth
 - Company pays all or some of graduate degree obtained while employed 
 - Very flexible work schedule - work hours that are conducive to your schedule
 - Lots of locations nationwide and worldwide to provide opportunities to move around
 - Encourages rotational opportunities to gain experiences in multiple facets of corporate finance
cons:
- Being such a large company, it is tough to initiate change and have your opinions heard
 - Salaries are somewhat lower than comparable companies in the industry (although compensation as a whole is very fair if you consider graduate degree payment)
 - There is a ton of red tape that makes a lot of processes inefficient and tough to manage

review_title: LM Aero is Not the same as Lockheed Martin
pros: Aero has large long term contracts that historically has provided reasonable job security.
cons: Manager an above leaders are too fearful of their image that they spend a great deal of their time positioning and covering their rears.  This behavior disengages employees and shuts down day to day employee innovations.  There are a lot of programs that are given lip service to employee engagement but most of the leaders do not know how to employ the skills let alone believe that they really matter to employee performance.  At Ft Worth there are lots of leaders that say "No" to ideas but there are very few that are bold enough to stand up to the system and say "Yes".

review_title: Great career starter where employees are treated fairly
job_title: Software Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Grad school tuition reimbursement
Decent Salary/Benefits
Interesting work w/ DoD Agencies
Work / Personal Life balance
Good management
Flexibly to find new opportunities in the company
cons: Like any big company, you have the politics. They base engineers on "levels" which hardly reflect the true ability and skills. Just because someone has worked in industry for 15 years, does not mean they are a better engineer than someone with 2 years experience. A level 1 could very well be doing the exact job as a level 3 or 4 engineer, but be paid considerably less because of the years of experience and the level they get put at because of this.

pros: Better than average compensation.  The people who stay tend to stay for a very long time.  Your experience depends on what business area/program you work for.  HQ tends to be a little more modern while some of the other divisions might have mgmt. techniques that date back to the Mad Men era.  Very tolerant of telecommuting- although it seems to be pulling back a bit on this recently.  Most coworkers are competent, pleasant and good to work with- but again this could depend on which program you are on.
cons: Company is not afraid to reorganize organizational structure and shuffle mgmt.  I basically get a new boss and/or department every 18 months (or sooner).  This does not allow for much workforce stability or long term strategic planning. Congressional budget issues and sequestration are a big concern and as a result, company has been downsizing across the board to cut costs.  Just read the papers and you will see facilities are being closed and layoffs enacted.

pros: Lockheed was a great company to work for my first 14 years with them.  A lot of growth opportunity and great leadership.  I enjoyed the type of work I did and was able to excel.  I felt I was treated well until my last year with them.
cons: I went out on disability and got screwed.  I paid into long term disability for 15 years but when it was time to use it Cigna turned down my long term disability claim.  The federal government approved it and yet Cigna turned it down.  I have been completely and totally disabled since March, 2010 and Lockheed should have had to pay me 65% of my pay for all these years and they got away without paying me a dime.  I should have found a lawyer to take my case because I won the right to sue them when I appealed their decision with the labor board.

review_title: A high speed employees take on this low speed behemoth.
pros: Lockheed Martin provides a work environment where the work is relatively easy, the requirements are relatively light, and the stress level is relatively low unless you are part of senior management. If you are looking to coast through employeement, Lockheed Martin is a great place to work.
cons: Lockheed Martin provides such a static work environment that does not promote or support the work of excellent employees. It has many of the standard expectations you would find within organizations of this age and size. Glacially slow and old fashioned without a lot of vision.

review_title: A good place to be- if you know what you're getting in to.
pros: There are a lot of opportunities to be involved in different aspects of engineering. You are allowed, even encouraged, to apply for different positions within the company.
cons: Getting hired is a double edged sword. It can be difficult getting an interview (applying seems fairly useless, they will find you if they're interested) so many people are likely to take less money than they want or to work in a program that doesn't particularly interest them to "get their foot in the door." It is extremely difficult to get raises or promotions without transferring around in the company. A major focus of the company is retaining younger employees, most people either leave well before they hit their 5 year anniversary or end up staying for 20-30, not a lot in between.

review_title: ATL:Interesting work, tough place to advance
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Arlington, VA
pros: The work is as cutting edge as it gets.  As a software engineer, I was exposed to a multitude of technologies that were just taking off.  The environment is relatively informal.  The hours are extremely flexible.  I could just not go to work on a random day of the week and that was ok as long as I sent an email.
cons: It is nearly impossible to be promoted above a level 3 engineer in the Advanced Technology Lab.  The level 4 and 5 employees aren't going anywhere, and there's not enough lower level employees to justify promoting any more 3's.  It's purely a function of the lack of breadth in the 230 person organization.  Also, unless you are coming in with a PhD from another high paying job, expect to get less than industry standard.  People are leaving the company now and getting at least 20-25% pay increases.

review_title: Good place to start your career, tough to stick around at the middle.
job_title: Systems Integration Analyst Staff in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
-Unique products and programs you can't find anywhere else
-Large percentage of staff will be eligible for retirement in 5-10 years so I imagine there will be a lot of opportunities in that window.
-Fast promotion and pay increases during first 5-10 years out of college.
cons:
-Slow to change/innovate because of older culture and size
-Some groups have 30+ people badged to a single manager
-Very difficult to get promoted once you reach a certain point
-Limited opportunities to
-How much you enjoy your job and how you are promoted can be very impacted by whether or not you have a good manager.  I have seen and had both good and bad managers and my career and job satisfaction have been a function of how good or bad the person in charge is.

job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Decent pay, Highly flexible work schedules for software engineers. Benefits are alright, but are getting worse as time goes on. Interesting work, if you are good at networking and can get on the right projects/teams.
cons:
Company is built as a career company in terms of structure, but is seems to be doing everything it can reverse that.  Job security is lacking - employment comes and goes with the contracts.  Pay raises barely meet inflation. Costs are always foremost - forget about being able to use that fancy tech they show off during the onsite tours.  You'll get a cube and a 17 inch monitor.
Like any large company, YMMV depending on business area, location, and manager.

job_title: Systems Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros:
- Flexible work schedule
- Most managers respect a healthy work / life balance
- Lots of classified work opportunities which Lockheed will sponsor you for a clearance for. 
- Lockheed's size allows for mobility within the company.  Build a strong network, and you can create opportunities for yourself to learn a new skill, or land a new job of interest.
cons:
- I'm sure your experience will vary from location to location, but the Valley Forge facility is an outdated and poorly maintained building. Very little is spent on the maintenance and aesthetic to the building. Just feels gross.
- If you are working unclassified, your manager will most likely be remote. Some remote managers poorly equipped to manage remote teams, and have very little visibility into their teams performance or areas that require attention. This is challenging for early career employees.
-Poor health benefits
-No employee stock purchase program

review_title: LM creates some amazing technology, but internal processes to make them come to life are disorganized and inefficient.
pros: Competitive wage to work ratios in many cases, flexible schedules, and reasonable work life balances for many, but not everyone.
cons: Within the IT realm at LM, understanding who does what and where in the company is a career in itself. Internally there is so much duplication of work that getting anything done takes what seems like eons because under each employee's roof, different processes exists and different people are doing the same thing unknowingly. The spread of team members beyond all geographic borders hinders employees from being on the same page and working efficiently. Not to mention the red tape slows processes to a snail-like pace while life outside the company is advancing at light speed.

review_title: Great place for grads and mid level engineers
pros:
Large stable company with locations all over the world
Interesting work vital to defense and civil applications
Opportunity to move to other business units/locations 
Decent benefits
Decent initial salary at all levels (junior, mid level, senior)
Management pays attention to what's going on, but doesn't get in the way of doing your job
cons:
Working for a good manager is hit or miss - there are a few good, some bad, most mediocre. You have to learn to manage your manager. I only saw one who was really horrible, Lots of status reports, yet seem to be surprised when bad news happens.
LM has an affinity for discarding senior engineers.
Poor raises every year - zero to 2%
Benefits keep eroding away - no more pension, vacation accrual cuts, insurance rates keep getting more and more expensive

review_title: Lockheed Martin was 1st class organization to work for and are they definitely the best defense contractor in the world.
pros: Pretty good benefits (health/life insurance, 401k) package.  Opportunity to advance if you work hard, especially in the DC/Maryland/Virginia area where the jobs are more plentiful.  They give you sufficient advance notice regarding layoffs, sometimes will relocate you, will always help with your resume, and HR will try and place in similar positions across different of the county.
cons: No longer offers a pension plan but does offer 3 weeks vacation to start.

review_title: Considered the "Cadillac" of big companies to work for
pros:
Been with LM for nearly a decade.  I've had the privilege of having great supervisors who genuinely were concerned about my professional growth, etc.  
The pay is similar to any of the large DoD contracting firms
Benefits are great, however, they are going through some substantial changes to better align with current economic strategies within the US.  I'm sure that will continue with the current CEO in place who knows how to pinch a penny and turn it into a profit.
cons:
Can be difficult to find training for specific career fields given the nature of contract work.  Some of a the divisions will not pay for training out of overhead and unless the contract specifically states paid training, you can get yourself into a dead-end situation.  
Promotions can be difficult as well depending on your supervisor and what contract you support; if the contract was bid on certain salary grades you could find yourself in a bad spot.

pros: They offered 9/80 flex in my old location and I never truly appreciated that until I switched companies and found myself working longer hours with less time at home. Being able to plan a 3-day weekend every other week was sweet! They also give 3 weeks of vacation, which is a week more than I've got at my new position.
cons: There is no room for growth and you need to go outside the company to expand your experience. Lockheed tends to silo their employees into a certain area and you may be there for the rest of your career. If you are not highly ambitious and looking for a quicker path to advancement LM is a stable choice. The advancement is mainly structured around time with the company and NOT around performance.

job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Littleton, CO
pros: Work on the 9/80 work schedule which is pretty cool. Get to work on incredible projects and be a part of a great team. Decent job out of college that should help me in the future. Working alongside brilliant engineers. Not micromanaged at all. Very flexible work hours. I am treated like I have been working there for 10 years.
cons: Very old school software development methodologies. Was told it would be a "fast, agile environment" but it is the complete opposite. Very process heavy. Tough for a new grad that was looking for a young atmosphere and collaboration between engineers. Pay is below average for software engineers out of school.

review_title: Good choice for interning (resume builder), but not a career.
pros: Very competitive salary and benefits package.
cons: Bureaucracy. Training is extremely unorganized and very ineffective and inefficient. Many placed in management positions are unqualified either personally or professionally to hold their position. Recognition for negative much more prevalent and frequent than positive feedback/reinforcement. Hiring processes seem to be borderline unethical (not informing potential employees of their job scope/real description, focus on utilization of full budget when unnecessary to retain recognition).

job_title: ESH Manager (JD Listed As "ESH Engineer") in Fort Bragg, NC
pros: Great work hours; team environment; employees had a personal dedication to supporting the soldiers; I was able to work closely with hourly personnel and other contractors, and thus influence safety on the shop and warehouse floor; company provided excellent benefits package with ease of access both online and CSRs via phone
cons: Corporate / Regional Safety Rep was not present for contract startup and possibly for bidding process as time was not allowed to be dedicated to required OSHA training requirements; lack of safety training materials; base facilities were not always complaint with safety codes; there was a lack of safety equipment in shops; and when I left position, a non-experienced person was “appointed” to the ESH position I had to use my personnel vehicle for business without mileage reimbursement by customer or company.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Offers the opportunity to work for large projects of vital importance to the nation.  Pay and benefits are good.
cons:
This company works with a lot of old legacy practices and technology and, aside from a small percentage of individuals and a few pockets here and there, is not very innovative.  A great many people want to avoid change altogether and actively resist it.  This company is trying to go agile, but, aside from a few individuals, just doesn't get it.

You're generally either under micromanagement or hit and run management.  The company doesn't want to promote anyone except in rare cases.  Work-life balance is supported in theory, but in practice you'll be given more work than you could ever possibly complete in a 40 hour work week.

review_title: OK, if you want a long an uneventful career with work-life balance
pros: Lockheed is overall a good company. Since it is a huge organization, the good benefits (work from home, growth opportunities, etc.) really depend on your department and your supervisor. This could really be luck of the draw. Overall, this organization is not high stress all the time, only during deadlines. The organization does a good job collecting to employee feedback as a whole.
cons:
- Benefits Package are average for the industry. For a large company you would expect industry setting standards for benefits.
- Limited Growth opportunities. It's really a matter of luck.
- Valid individual greivances are sometimes ignored.

pros: 9/80 work schedule, health benefits. Very nice office spaces with good walking paths for a lunch walk. On site medical where you can get your flu shot or just go if you're not feeling well.
cons: Training was 'catch as catch can.' Manager seems to have nothing to do but send daily emails to group: what are you doing today...tomorrow...this week. Forwards emails for non-essential nonsense. Very top heavy with managers who manage other managers and so on. Well, the 'real workers' got our layoff notices this week. Don't know how my relatively low salaried job will effect LM's bottom line. I guess the six figure managers will still be eating at the taxpayer-funded troth. Wish the US government could really 'see' what they're paying for - non-essential heavy middle/top management.

job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Denver, CO
pros:
Very happy at LM SSC so far (2.5 years).

Benefits are great: 3 weeks vaca for new hires, every other Friday off, and off between Christmas and New Years. In general, there is a healthy work-life balance attitude. Of course, there are times that we've got to put in extra time to get things done, but that is on an occasional as-needed basis only.  

In general, I have felt respected and trusted by management, and I've been given a lot of responsibility. 

Also, working on vehicles destined for deep space exploration is pretty awesome, and a daily inspiration.
cons:
Some remnants of 'good ol boy' club attitudes around here, but LM is actively trying to become a modern, attractive company to new employees. 

As with every company I've ever heard of, diving into something can be a little overwhelming with limited organized training, but coworkers are generally available for support.

review_title: I would not recommend it for experienced professionals from other industries
job_title: Lead Member of Engineering Staff in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Flexible schedule. I worked on a Flex 40 schedule which meant I needed to put in 40 hours per week with a minimum of 4 hours on any particular work day.
cons:
- Too many people who have spent all of their lives working at the same place. The culture is terrible. Some individuals who joined the company straight out of college 30 years ago still act like teenagers. Imagine having to deal with a 50 or 60 year old teenager.
- The workforce is heavily skewed in a particular direction with respect to race. Just guess how that's going to work out if you're a minority. Google "Lockheed Martin discrimination lawsuit".
- As a software engineer your skills are highly specialized and aren't easily transferable to other industries. That's probably one of the reasons why so many people stay there all of their lives. They're trapped.
- Terrible culture (at the location where I worked, Moorestown NJ). People will hide information from you if they perceive you as a threat who might push them out of their position.

pros: Great place to start, the benefits used to be great, currently switching to a high rate deductible. As a single person it doesn't affect me but many of my counter parts are scared of dropping through the wage-classes
cons: Dying; wage driven. If you like to work on white collar jobs under a blue collar mentality, you're in the right place. RETICENT to adapt to remote/terminal use, which absolutely negates all positives of the work place. Most work can be automated but the hesitation to adapt to terminal use means bodies in cubicles even though they are not needed.

review_title: Cutthroat and toxic in some areas
pros: This is my dream company. I LOVE Lockheed Martin and this is where I want to be for my whole career. Chelmsford is a good plant, but there are some glaring issues definitely to be pointed out.
cons: At Chelmsford, I've noticed that a swath of young people have recently left. I've also been hearing from people who have transferred, or left have straight up told me it is a toxic and cutthroat work environment. I've been be-littled by upper management when making a mistake. I've also been ignored when offering solutions! Doesn't make an employee feel valued and most likely will drive away people if this continues.

review_title: Beware the axe - things are not as they appear
job_title: Systems Engineer Senior Staff in Arlington, VA
pros: Good leadership development program, if you can get in.  Performance reviews are structured and timely.  Lots of opportunities to move to other positions in the company for career development.
cons: It helps to be well-connected to get ahead, and definitely a must when your contract ends, if you want to stay in the company.  At contract end, most employees are on their own to find other work with little or no help from management or HR.  Internal hiring process is broken - you rarely hear back from bids on requisitions, which are usually wired for someone else or out of date.  So it's easier to find work outside the company.  No reimbursements for parking, transportation or professional memberships.

review_title: Great to start out, not a good place to stay.
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Valley Forge, PA
pros: Good place to start your career - great opportunities are available to junior employees if you seek them out and perform well.  It also provides an excellent opportunity to network due to the ability to move from program to program.  Opportunities are fairly endless since its such a large company.
cons: Work life balance is horrid.  Getting a good performance rating is directly tied to the amount of uncompensated OT you work and on many projects, you're expected to work over and above your 40 hours.  Not that I mind doing that, but when it becomes the norm rather than the occasional exception its not good for your life outside of work.  training budgets are always slashed 3 months into the year.

pros:
The benefits are good. A lot of the people are good. Working for a big firm like LM does have pluses--they can get better health benefits than some firms, for example, because their size gives them leverage. In addition, the size of the firm makes it possible to have a long-term but varied career at LM. They are reluctant to lay people off a contract; someone who would be laid off is given first crack--and preference--at other jobs in the company. 
    The management philosophy, as expressed by the maxims of Full Spectrum Leadership, is first rate.
cons: Management is more concerned about the short-term bottom line than the longer-term needs of employees. Consequently, something like training can be given short shrift. Communication between employee and manager at the project level can be bad. This will likely vary by contract.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great benefits, that begin the day you begin.  The organization cares about their employees and when Sequestration forced layoffs, LM insisted on doing the right thing and giving the affected employees a 2 week notice.  They provided help through their Career Talent group: on resumes, cover letters and interviewing.
cons: The ratio of employees to management was high in the area I worked.  There was no recognized team leader.  With employees in several different buildings or even different areas of the same building, it was difficult to communicate with each other on projects. But this is more attributed to the placement of the employees by the FAA, to whom the LM had a contract.

pros: Lockheed is a pretty good company to work with. My co-workers are very intelligent, the benefits are great and the pay is above average.
cons: I haven't found anything too big to gripe about.

review_title: Great place to start your career and diversify your skills, but beware of the defense industry.
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Lots of opportunities to rotate into different areas of the company.  International company, lots of resources and good process guidelines.  Great place for a young person to learn the ropes from older and retiring engineers.  Lockheed puts a lot of emphasis on hiring a diverse workforce.
cons: While Lockheed tries hard and implements good anti-discrimination policies, the culture is still pretty conservative, especially at the higher levels.  Granted, things have changed a lot since the 90's and much more diverse people are climbing the ranks into top management.  It still has a way to go.  Also, if you don't like the aerospace/defense industry, then none of the defense contractors (Lockheed, Boeing, Raytheon, Northrop) are a good place for you to work.

review_title: Satellite Systems Engineer.. 18 month sting and OUT....
job_title: Satellite Systems Engineer in Springfield, VA
pros:
Security Clearance
Great pay out of undergrad (because of shift differential)
Lots of other young/recent grads
Smart people
Advancement opportunities (if you like satellite operations)
NEVER bring work home with you - you'll go to jail if you do!
8 hours per day... and that's it!! 
Great hours/benefits
cons:
Shift Schedule - The rotating shift schedule was tough. It's hard for some to stay healthy becuase of the hours, eating habits, etc. And bye bye to half your weekends!

The company is HUGE and obviously pretty silo-ed.  If you want to go somewhere else after your 18th month stint it's not like your boss can call his buddy over in a different business unit to help you out.

I thought the work was incredibly boring. Many of my peers LOVED it and wanted to stay in highly technical satellite operations for the rest of the career, never seeing the light of day, traveling, etc. I think I'm almost too much of a mover/shaker for a job like this.

pros: For me, the location is close to home.  LM offers decent benefits (healthcare including vision and dental options, 401k, onsite Wellness centers, paid vacation).
cons:
Working for a defense contractor can be very stressful, especially during periods of Government spending cuts.  I have been through a number of layoffs that have affected many close friends.  
Constant pressure to work more than 40 hours per week.  No overtime possible until after 45 hours, and you are expected to work those additional 5 hours for free every week.
Little to no training provided on company time.  Expected to keep up with current technologies on your own time, or get behind.  They offer a number of learning sessions during lunch, again on your own time.
Salary is mediocre, and raises are small (around 2%) even though LMs profit reports are always good.

pros: Good jobs doing important work with Government.  Good pay and better benefits for legacy employees, average benefits and lower pay for newer employees.  Company generally works hard to keep employees where possible when a contract ends but finding it increasingly difficult in today's environment.  Sale of IT business and aggressive cost cutting should allow the company to remain competitive in Government IT services under LEIDOS.
cons: Salaries, benefits, overheads, positions, and skill mix aggressively being driven lower to remain competitive in Government IT services contracts where lowest cost is more important than experience and higher skills.  Senior and experienced legacy employees are considered liabilities that are no longer valued in the race to the bottom.  LM is majority stakeholder in merger with LEIDOS, but it appears LEIDOS is driving the train.  .

pros: Huge company with a lot of internal opportunities to learn about the different areas of business. A very reputable defense contractor that is constantly developing new technologies. Compensation and benefits are pretty good. Overall a nice place to have a career. I have been fortunate to have a great manager, but this can vary by team.
cons:
Like any big company, the decision making process is extremely slow and change is extremely difficult to implement. People are mostly great but oftentimes complacent in their current role and comfortable sticking with the status quo. Constantly faces the bureaucratic challenges because of the industry. People are smart but too few bring energy and enthusiasm to work everyday.

Susceptible to the "lifer" mentality: the longer you work here, the more difficult it is to leave.

pros:
The Palmdale site is on a 9:80 schedule in that you get every other Friday off (can't choose which Friday), really awesome. 
The relocation package is pretty good.
The work is incredible.
For the vast majority of employees, can't access email when you aren't there, which is usually a huge plus.
Get to work with hardworking, intelligent people (my experience so far).
cons:
Not the highest in terms of salaries, especially for PhDs. I would say slightly higher than average, but close to average. 
Massive corporate machine you have to navigate to get stuff done (e.g., things ordered, various trainings, etc.). 
No cafeteria or coffee stand on site.

job_title: Software Engineer Staff in Omaha, NE
pros: Lockheed Martin is a large company and therefore there is a lot of opportunity.  There are diverse career fields with an opportunity to work on diverse programs.  There is an opportunity to work in several geographic locations, particularily on the East coast and in California.
cons: My experience is tempered in that LMC at my location is actually quite small, and therefore suffers from the problems that small companies have.  Managment at my location is poor.  Too much drama in the program.  No one communicates.  Subcontractors are in all the critical positions; LMC personnel are not in a position to make decisions.  Hence low morale and high turnover.  LMC as a corporation stresses that education and training is very important, but at my location there is no budget for training and there is very little opportunity for either unless it is done on your personal time.

review_title: Not a bad place to work, fair pay for a fair days work.
pros: Flexible shifts while not being micro-managed. I've worked at Lockheed Martin for a total of 12 years. I had to leave the company for a year to get my salary up to par with my peers. The company loves to hire young engineers at low ball salaries but then again what company doesn't
cons: Health care insurance is starting to slip. In years past an individual had several options for medical coverage but that has changed. You know have very little choice as something called the Total Health Plan has been instituted that is what the company wants all employees to go to. In the past three years I've seen my choices for plans go from five to two and the plan costs to increase by about 25%.

review_title: Giant Bureaucracy where  things move slowly and projects are not efficient
job_title: Systems Integration/Test Engineer in Houston, TX
pros:
This review is for Lockheed Space Systems Company - I worked there for 3 years out of college

A variety of benefits
*Strong benefit package
*Pay is comparable with the aerospace industry
*Great time off - 9/80 schedule
*Has some of the best contracts in the industry
cons:
The huge downside is the bureaucracy. They sent me and all of the other 40 or so new hires to Houston, TX...when the entire management team was in Denver. As a college hire, my manager, lead, and the rest of the team (except for a few other new hires) were all in Denver. Needless to say, this meant that my development and my opportunities were hindered. 

The bureaucracy that allowed such a set-up to occur showed itself in other ways. Work was done slowly and projects were consistently behind schedule. It seemed that for every person doing real work, there were about 3 people just sitting around. This made it hard to get real work that develops skills and it made promotions and development opportunities hard to come by. I definitely don't recommend Lockheed.

review_title: When 5 years is a big deal....
pros: Some of my colleagues were great to work with.  As a project, we were forgotten by corporate, so there was a lot of opportunity to do things like a small, independent, company.
cons:
Perks were non-existent.  If you wanted tap water, you could to the public fountain; if you wanted any of the needed filtration of DC water, you could join the "water club."  

Direct management was nowhere to be found unless a bus needed someone to be thrown under. There could be multiple feet of snow on the ground and taking the initiative to work from home was met with a "why didn't you get permission first."

Frankly, it was so poorly handled, I think the government would have been better off awarding the contract to our competitor.  Although, the client was just as bad as we were, so maybe they deserved each other.

review_title: This was a great place to work!
job_title: Senior Sheet Metal Mechanic In Machine Shop in Orlando, FL
pros: A great work atmosphere contributed to an overall satisfying job. Pay was in the average range most people seemed satisfied, I really liked having the cafeteria and other amenities on site too!
cons:
Many people who were tenured seemed negative about the style of management.
Some also complained about lack of promotion from within.
I really found the life work balance very hard as I lived an hour away and you were frequently expected to stay late. Sometimes I would get home @ 8 pm after leaving for work at 6 am

pros: All the benefits of a large corporation, decent pay (but I have my gripes with this), decent retirement, decent benefits. They are very accommodating when downsizing, giving you plenty of time to find another job within the company.
cons:
Benefits and perks are reduced every year. Smaller programs like gym membership reimbursement have been entirely cut in recent years. I have a rather low comp ratio, perform well, and still my raises are behind inflation. Higher education partnerships have been cut in the last few years. Most managers don't know the basics of leadership, but are really good at being nice to you in person.

I don't trust the leaders and managers. I've seen employees hired from across the country, told "we have work until 20XX", then those same employees were downsized 6 months later. I've heard of managers coaxing employees to share concerns, then using those complaints against them.

review_title: Best place to launch a career in the Silicon Valley
pros: Amazing technology is at your fingertips!  I started as a new college grad and entered the Engineering Leadership Development Program, which allows me to rotate to multiple positions around the company.  There are lots of great challenges and opportunities for the motivated.
