Higher education is encouraged and management will need replacement in the next few years, so there are multiple opportunities in the corporation for rapid advancement.  Yes, it is a big, slow defense company, but the work life balance is good and your have lots of opportunities to learn new things.
cons: None really, you can't access gmail or have a cell phone in some of the buildings.  depends on your manager really.

review_title: Great place... but you can get lost in the mix.
pros: Respected company. Secure long term financial viability. Varied cross-platform opportunities.  Much room for growth.  Competitive salary and benefits package.  Pleasant place to work.  Very, very competent and highly skilled colleagues.  If you work or have worked for Lockheed Martin, then it will always serve as a feather in your cap... opening doors down the line in your professional career.
cons: Very large company -- slow to make rapid market shifts.  Bureaucracy.  Very long hours -- dilutes salary structure and undermines productivity and workforce synergy.  Ultra-competitive environment.  Family sometimes "needs" to take a back seat.  Too large.  Senior management jobs seem to be awarded for "time served" similar to prison.  Weak mid tier management structure.  Again... tooooo large.  Not much room for "out of the box" thinking... very safe approach to design services.

pros: Lockheed is one of those companies that realizes its bottom line is directly related to its greatest asset: the people. Besides offering numerous opportunities/avenues for vertical and lateral movement, they also invest heavily in L&D (Learning & Development).  They are extremely diligent in recognizing/rewarding excellent performance. And their commitment to diversity is second to none in my book. The only possible obstacle to professional (and personal) growth at Lockheed Martin is yourself!
cons: As a government contractor, the emphasis of dotting all i's and crossing all t's three times over is a bit overbearing. I had to keep track of my time in no less than FOUR different tools. It got to be a real drag. Also, LM's performance evaluation system is extremely rigorous, time-consuming, and tedious. If strict protocol is not your thing, government contracting may not be for you.

review_title: Rollercoaster ride between excellent work and total lack of performance recognition/promotion opportunities.
pros: For engineers, great, challenging work. Good place to start a career out of college. Every other friday off.
cons: Producing good work is not rewarded with an increased salary.  Performance reviews processed by a black hole system, makes everyone into an average monkey, leaving employees wondering why they tried so hard.

review_title: Large Company,  plenty of differing job paths for a career
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Challenging work and a good working team environment with in the departments to build and deliver the best for our customer. Good work/life balance with flexible hours and first level management support. Good compensation package, health Medical, dental, life and 401K.
cons: Limited advancement within department structure or transfers to other departments are management determined . Work can be repetitive and boring at times until process issues or parts issue develop. Note there is very little room for out of the box thinking for all ideas to improve the process and decrease costs.

pros: Great pay, lots of different groups doing many diverse things. Hours were flexible, and a lot of very smart people work there. There were even separate technical and management career paths to choose from.
cons:
Since they're a government contractor, mediocrity rules. The emphasis is on spending as much time and money as possible, since what you're selling is hours, not product. That also leads to staff bloating, where it's better to have three people do the job of one wherever possible.

Management can also be clueless. They have the attitude that a manager doesn't have to know anything about the department they're managing so long as they can look good in front of a PowerPoint presentation.

They used to be very innovative, but now they sub out almost all of the innovation, and just do the project management.

pros: Pay was good, I was treated fairly most of the time.
cons: There is a constant struggle between program managers and functional managers. The project managers want to get things done as quickly and as cheaply as possible (due to "competitive" budgeting of their program) and often encourage team members to ignore the development processes set by functional managers (which were put in place to avoid defects in the product being developed) to meet deadlines. As a result, the typical engineer is left in an uncomfortable position -- do I ignore the process set by my functional manager (who conducts my performance review), or ignore the project manager (who weighs heavily on my performance review). I imagine this is true with all defense contractors, but this is my biggest complaint. I often worked hours of unpaid overtime (which you're not allowed to do) to make both sides happy.

pros: Lockheed Martin is one of a few companies remaining with real engineering bench strength.  While the company has reduced R&D investment over the last few years, there remains an exceptional staff of highly experienced technical staff.  Lockheed has also proven very loyal to its employees and makes every effort to hold onto staff during downturns.  Lockheed is a very ethical company.  Ethics come before profit; sometimes to its own detriment.
cons: Lockheed is expensive and anything but lean.  If you're looking for a Google-like environment, look elsewhere.  They are being undercut by lower cost competition which has led the company to consider several wide-ranging restructures including divestment of their entire IT portfolio and reductions in support staff.  2016 will be turbulent for employees/

job_title: Cyber Intel Analyst in King of Prussia, PA
pros:
I like my coworkers. Hard working folks that truly know their jobs. 

Functional management has always supported me pursuing (and paying for) my master's degree and additional training. They really want you to be happy where you are and if not they try their best to move you where you might be. 

Project managers are less interested in your personal growth, especially if it means edging out an extra buck off you on a contract but I suppose that's why functional management exists to complement them.
cons:
Contract work can be difficult. You typically do a lot of flying (but with work from home) if you're not onsite. If you're an onsite analyst you may be asked to relocate and the locations aren't always ideal. 

Project managers should be more willing to dish out some additional training, especially when I know for a fact they're earning the company two to four times off of me what I earn in a single year.

review_title: Career stifling; no upward promotion potential w/out spending majority of time on political positioning
pros: Employee salary payments prompt; high integrity within corporation for doing things right (per corporate policies); consistent emphasis on compliance with EEO, no bullying, etc
cons: Employee initiative is stifled and not rewarded; mgmt wants to maintain status quo; not encouraged to be creative and assist in revenue growth strategies nor methods to increase customer satisfaction

review_title: Future of Space Systems Business Unit is unclear
pros: Started out with solid benefits, competitive pay, chance to take on exciting/challenging problems (no shortage of ownership/responsibilities for those looking to excel).
cons: Highly influenced by government politics with diminishing customer diversity.  Though current Corporate/Space Systems executive leadership have 100+ collective years of experience at LM, they seem ill-prepared to navigate changing financial, political,  and technical environment (ex. Commercial Ventures effort seems like a feeble attempt to breathe new life into the business). Simply put, LM Space Systems has fallen out of favor.  What is particularly frustrating is the lack of transparency between executive leadership and workforce.

review_title: Started Great, Now... Not So Much
job_title: Project Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great benefits packages in terms of vacation time accrual (it never expires, but does cap at 400 hours). Flexibility is awesome. I work at a site with off-Fridays every other Friday. There are some sites that work 4x10, so they never work Fridays.
cons: Very large company with a lot of politics. Very slow moving. Hard to introduce change. And once change is introduced, if you move on to another project/job, expect the changes you implemented to be undone. Resistance to change is rampant throughout the company and it will take a while for them to be able to respond to customers quickly. This works for them as a defense contractor. In the commercial world, this would result in failure. People in leadership position often have no leadership skills and made it to their position based on seniority and technical experience. Being a good engineer does not equate to being a good leader of people.

pros: Generally stable, seen many people work 30 plus years here. Being govt contractor, lots of rules in place to protect employee, like limits to uncompensated OT for individual contributors. This can be a pro or con I suppose. Lots of good resources throughout company to help you network and grow, but you have to take initiative to seek and follow.
cons: If working for SSC, software technologies used may seem out dated. Change process is slow and the culture seems to reflect. Its good for those seeking more stable, not so fast paced job. Can be  boring for those energetic and passionate types trying to stay at cutting edge. This was for Space only, other parts of company are bit more in tune with latest software trends

job_title: Item Analyst, Senior in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Flexible schedules and ample amount of vacation and paid time off.  Employees are expected to work independently without a lot of oversight. Very diverse working environment.  Decent pay and benefits. Hires really good employees.
cons: Opportunity for advancement is very limited and opportunities to move into other areas of the business are almost non existent. This this type of management philosophy really inhibits innovation. However, I understand that Lockheed is trying to change this culture, but it's going to take a few years longer.

review_title: If you work for Lockheed Martin, be prepared to work until you are exhausted, and then some
job_title: Contracts Negotiator in King of Prussia, PA
pros: The name recognition the company has; many opportunities if you are willing to pack up the family and move from state-to-state (not something I am willing to do)
cons: HR system is not fair (management gives certain employees what they ask for while others are told that HR will not permit it); job growth is limited unless you move around; most of the jobs are in the DC Metro area; company expects you to work WAY more than 40 hours a week (and if you work in Business Development, be prepared to work at least 60 hours a week with no extra compensation)

job_title: Embedded Software Engineer Staff in Marietta, GA
pros: Decent Pay, Good place to learn from uniquely talented co-workers, full commitment to diversity
cons: Forced performance distributions, Rating determined by managers you rarely see, Salary compression, job category salary ranges are market based but actual salary distributions are ~ 89% of mean, Promotion opportunities go to outsiders, 4 is a career level, decreasing benefits ( no pension for newbies, lots of pressure to make up any sick time, 1 choice for health care package, etc), management and workers growing more disconnected...2 very different worlds, local managers neutered by HR and policies. Full Spectrum Leadership is preached....ever constricting management is practiced.

review_title: Glad I don't have to go back there .
pros: Off Friday and early finish on the on Fridays other than that that's it .
cons: Too many to mention attrition will always rise at ampthill and people will continue to leave . Bad management no chance of promotions or pay rise HR are just as bad face doesn't fit you don't stand a chance . Site is losing money projects are in a mess IT is a joke as I worked in the IT department even a manager said I was doing the right thing in leaving so many unhappy people there who are all looking for new jobs . Can't see the place being there in the next couple of years will get bought out again the American way does not work in the UK .

pros: Excellent stepping stone to other LM programs but this is the only upside to this program.
cons: The Lockheed Martin Aero Iraq program was a negative experience that dragged on for almost 2 years. Very poor leadership and management who truly believe they are superior over their subordinates. Many prior LM employees who have been with the company for several years all say the same thing ... Do not judge Lockheed Martin Aero by this particular program. Several people have tried to involve the LM ethics committee to try to help and Ethics will have nothing to do with the program, in other words, they just turn the other cheek. There has been a lot of talent and experience lost because of leadership's pompous ego and unprofessional ethical practices.

pros: Bob Stevens and team are a great set of company leaders with a clear vision of the direction of the overall company.  Management in Orlando appears to be "killing it and bringing it home".  Everytime I see LM news they are in it for bringing in another contract worth a couple of million of dollars.  They must have over 30-40 contracts in the millions of dollars range if not more.  So, if they happen to lose one or two due to government cuts they don't lose a large percentage of business.  Smart business model from an ousider looking in.
cons: System Integration Owego goes for all home runs.  We had 4 contracts totaling over 10 billion dollars.  Now we have 3 and 25% less employees.  Thank you management

review_title: Overall Lockheed Martin is a Great Company
job_title: Systems Engineer Staff in Marietta, GA
pros: Lockheed Martin is a great company to work for as the benefits are excellent.  The 9/80 work schedule along with flexible hours is an added bonus.  Many jobs are quite interesting and challenging, however be cautious of the many non technical routine and monotonous assignments that many engineers find themselves working.
cons: There are many large programs and projects which is good.  However, many engineers find themselves with a very small routine non-technical assignment.  If you desire technical work choose your position very carefully.  Many engineers are well paid document writers or readers, database managers, data collectors, meeting coordinators and moderators.  Most of which require little engineering knowledge.

review_title: Started fast and hit the cement ceiling faster
pros:
The pay is good. At the time I was hired, there was still a defined benefit (pension) plan. No longer available for new hires. 
Flextime - Seems mgmt is genuinely concerned w/home-work life balance
cons:
Little or no chance of advancement after you hit a certain tier (level 3). 
Too many mgmt levels between Individual contributors and those that make promotion decsions (first lines don't have much impact on those decsions).
Defense Industry  - It appears to be lean times ahead. We are doing more with less and it seems (at least in MST) our ranks are shrinking.
Too much time and $$ is spent on the PR aspects of "Inclusion, Diversity etc...). Policies are in place to make this a good work environment, but it seems that they advertise to appease the "PC" media and outside interests, when it really is not needed.

review_title: Not what I really expected, but potentially a good company for various opportunities.
job_title: Software Cofiguration Analyst Senior in Orlando, FL
pros:
At least now when I am new, the work environment is not very stressful but they have made it unnecessarily hectic. 
I think your job is pretty secure here.
cons:
Just a lot of red tape and lot of time spent on documenting your work so that if government audits you, you have all your paperwork in place to prove what you did. It just that I can't imagine, that there is not a better way to accomplish this goal.

Benefits sucks. And that is all on my. I should have read all that after I accepted the position. I took a significant pay cut from my previous job, even though my base pay increased.

review_title: Great Company, but a bit top heavy
job_title: Web Lead and Developer in Poolesville, MD
pros: Loved working for Lockheed Martin. They paid fairly well. They encourage diversity, honesty, security and a good moral ethics. It fosters a great working environment in the work place and embraces working from.
cons: Very top heavy. Lots of Presidents and VPs that really know people at the regular employee level. They have a lot of remote users *which is good) but many times the functional managers have no idea what employees under them are doing, making evaluations on promotions and raises seem uninformed.  Lockheed has been going through a lot of layoffs and getting rid of a lot of experience just to hire low paid collage grads. This leave others to work twice as hard for the same pay.

job_title: OLDP Asc in Fort Worth, TX
pros: You get a breadth of experiences in a short time while learning all facets of business operations.  The program allows you to try out many different job positions you otherwise wouldn't have an opportunity to do.  I spent the full two years working in the Fort Worth, TX Aeronautics facility and feel very fortunate.  The F-35 Program is thriving and cool to be a part of.
cons: The new program has full 1 year rotations without an elective.  When rotating different business units it is a political game to get the positions you want.  Some rotations you will not enjoy.  It is part of discovering what jobs you would actually like off program.

pros: The flexibility in getting your required hours in. The excellent tuition reimbursement package as well pension and 401K matching. The company provides multiple growth opportunities for its employees and the ability to rotate around through multiple lines of business and programs. Working for the premier defense company allows for exciting work experiences that one would not normally get through his or her job. Plus, all employees know that their work directly impacts the national security of this country. Your work certainly feeds the soul and makes the hard work all that more rewarding.
cons: The huge bureaucracy and multiple levels of management can be quite a drag on work production and program efficiency. The range in the quality of managers is rather wide. It sometimes begs the question as to how this person or that came into the position that they hold.

review_title: Good at the working level, but senior management is hindrance rather than a help
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Syracuse, NY
pros:
Strong ethical and professional atmosphere
Interesting applications of technology - not cutting edge, but focused on what works
Bright senior contributors with open door access
Reasonable salary
Appear to want to preserve defined benefit plan, even if now closed to new hires
Technical progression ladder is still reasonably intact
cons:
HR is rigid and wants cookie cutter employees - conformist is fine even if not particularly productive
Senior management are not crisp decision makers - consensus approach is very expensive, with lots of non-productive roles.
Performance management, while consistent, is formula-driven and forces one to "play the game" to get good reviews, rather than recognizing good productive performance independently.

review_title: I had a very positive experience working for Lockheed Martin for 25 years.
job_title: Senior Staff Systems Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: I was treated very fairly by most of my supervisors, and I consistently received above average performance appraisals.
cons: The turnover in middle management often leads to a lack of continuity.  For one stretch in my career, I reported to about six different managers within just a few years ... in the same job.  Also, some programs and business lines are too narrowly focused on a single government customer.

job_title: Software Dev Analyst Senior Staff in Huntsville, AL
pros: Ethical conduct among all employees in my program. Most of the people were genuinely good people. We had a good culture of cooperation, and most of the team was willing to help out each other. Good pay and relatively good benefits. A number of positions can be worked virtually (from home).
cons: No defined pension plan (not uncommon), longevity at Lockheed strictly depends upon networking and your manager. There is a tendency to downgrade the level of positions, so that you are no longer competiitve (salary-wise) when having to look for another program to move to (when your contract is winding down). Job security is so-so and should/could be better for such a large company. The downside of being virtual is that you hardly have any face-to-face contact with the rest of your team.. out of sight, out of mind.

review_title: Great work, but tough to actually stay in company
job_title: Multimedia Design Engineer Senior in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
- Great dynamic work 
- Good pay (even in smaller contracts)
- Great benefits
- A lot of room for opportunities on current assignments
- Tuition Assistance is some of the best I've seen
cons:
It's SUPER tough to get another opportunity in the company. In fact, I've been trying to get a new opportunity at Lockheed for the last 2 years. I've applied to over 20 positions that I'm more than qualified for (some over qualified for) and can't get anything. They always go to outside candidates or internal candidates who are working in the department currently (confirmed by hiring managers).

Hard to get promotions.

review_title: Lockheed Martin - "Never forget who you're working for."
pros: Lockheed Martin offers many opportunities for professional growth and development (depending on your location). They also have some very interesting and unique programs and customers and recognize the importance of staying on the cutting edge of technology. Overall, Lockheed Martin is not a bad place to develop your career. As with any company, there's good and bad, so you just have to weigh your options.
cons: Never forget who you're working for. Lockheed Martin is a defense contractor, and job stability can sometimes be uncertain if there are not enough contracts (backlog of work available).

pros: The benefits are good, but since I am already retired from the military it has no effect, I like the stocks, The work is steady and it's a good place to work, it's like a big family where I work. I don't know if I could endorse this particular job but the overall company is great.
cons: This position has no upside to it for advancement or pay increase. It seems you're working harder than the rest because you cater to them. More for less.....Where there is help for each department there is only one for this particular area so it's just you doing the work of at least two and maybe even three. As a Military Veteran I do feel over looked and under paid and as a former leader I see some who get paid a lot and do not work as hard Performance/Performance/Performance is what I was taught.

job_title: Senior Subcontracts Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros: You get 3 weeks of vacation coming in the door, 40 hours of sick time, and 9/80 work week.
cons: Lockheed is a good company to work, but don't work for F-35 Subcontract Management in Fort Worth. There's not training you are just left to figured out on your own. It's definitely a matrix environment and you spend majority of your day updating matrix. The managers in the F35 program are unprofessional, that gossip about their employees. When you need to address an issue with your manager or talk privately there is no privacy, any or everybody can hear what's being said. Some Managers in the F35 program delegate their work to you and can't explain how to do it. The environment is very unprofessional, especially managers, it feel like you are in high school. Low pay it's just not worth it for what you deal with everyday. Don't work in F-35 Subcontract Management, it's terrible over there, just about everyone is new and miserable.

review_title: Lockheed Martin: A Giant In Industry and In Agility
pros: Lockheed Martin offers a great amount of security and professional growth for a wide variety of career paths due to its size and reach - there are Lockheed Martin facilities in nearly every state and many other countries.  Awesome benefits compared to other companies, especially when it comes to relocation to another LM unit.  Ease of transfer as well - just find a place you want to live and odds are LM is there already.
cons: The company is extremely large and tends to move slower than a startup, so if someone is seeking a fast-paced environment, they may not be pleased with this company.  The company is also very "politically correct", due to lawsuits and fines, so creativity and the x-factor of workplace synergy can sometimes be stifled.

review_title: Good until corporate decided to close site.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Eagan, MN
pros: Good benefits, work schedule (9/80), flex time.  Interesting defense work.  Most fellow workers good to work with, communicate well.  Managers do a decent job of sharing specific expertise across projects.  Willing to offer overtime if needed.  Willing to fund education for those that want to improve.
cons: Low raises last 5 years, despite good reviews.  No training funds for self-improvement during rare periods of idle time between projects.  Management bids tended to be overly optimistic on new technology bids.  Formal performance reviews are painful, employees asked for more informal feedback, got more frequent formal reviews instead.  If you really want to be recognized, work on a project in trouble.

pros:
- Good pay and benefits.  Many useful discounts with partner companies.  401K match up to 4% of salary, with Roth 401K option.  Three weeks of vacation per year that rolls over from year to year, not including paid holidays.  Salaried employees can be paid for overtime if approved by management, which helps bump up the salary.
- Being a large company, there are many opportunities to transition to different positions within the company when they come available.  Upper management will usually help employees make these transitions as long as the skill sets are a fit, which probably helps with employee retention.
cons:
- Depending on the area you are working, there can be lots of office politics.
- Being a large company, there is a lot of standard procedure which sometimes acts as red tape.
- Employee performance review system continues to evolve but the latest version was poorly executed and is difficult to use.

pros: Good benefits,  flex time, typically good pay (though this varies by location and business area)
cons: If you really listen to the hr presentations for the past few years it's been a resounding message.... we're top heavy and early/mid career employees shouldn't expect to move up. But the question is asked each year from management and hr... how can we keep our young employees?  ANSWER: you have to make room for them, invest a little into them and nurture their career for a bit.... then you can reap the rewards of a well trained employee.

pros: Work with a lot of great people. Have flexible schedules and some ability to work remote although they are currently ending all that. Ability to learn a lot if you take advantage of the classes offered online and many of the other training tools.
cons: Reorgs are constantly going on- just about every year for the 6 years I have been there so far- must be very adaptable to change and new bosses. Every year they are taking away more and more of the benefits and employee activities- not really much left. Very very difficult to get promoted there even if you get excellent reviews every year you still won't get promoted for years - it's a slow process and the managers try to avoid promoting at all costs.

review_title: Working for one of the top employers in the DOD and Aerospace industries has resulted in a very rewarding career
job_title: Senior Field Engineer in Harrogate, England
pros: LM rewards employees that are willing to uphold and personify their corporate ethics and vision.  They employ a very dynamic and talented workforce and encourage a good work/ life balance.  They provide excellent career paths and mentoring from more experienced colleagues.  Management has respect for their employees and truly care about their careers and job satisfaction.
cons: As with any big enterprise, it is sometimes difficult to understand exactly how the company's vision and direction affect you as an individual employee.

review_title: Team Leader for a Java Software Development Team
job_title: Business Applications Programmer Staff in Fairfax, VA
pros: Our project experienced an extended period of stability.  Worked with an excellent group of co-workers, other employees I worked with outside my immediate project were highly skilled and professional.  Generally worked a standard 40-hour week, no unreasonable demands for overtime hours.  Decent health plan if you took advantage of all the healty-choice incentives.  It seemed like some of the recent management changes might result in greater responsiveness to the employees.
cons: Typical problems with large contractors - most of us felt disconnected from the company, weak communications on many levels, compensation tied more to the profitability of the assigned contract rather than responsibilities and performance, easier to lay off employess at the end of a contract than place them elsewhere in the company.  Some of the policies (how overtime compensation works, layoff notices accompanied with assurances that no one will be laid off) left us mostly confused.

review_title: Really nice experience at Lockheed, (especially for interns)
job_title: Software Engineer Co-Op in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Smart colleagues
Very morally correct culture
Very flexible hours
You get every other friday off work
Good rent stipend
nice cafeteria
smart, reasonable, and hard working bosses
intern events very regularly, we had movie get togethers, volunteer opportunities, a chance to get in the F35 simulations, and so on. Not to mention, some intern events had free lunches, dinners, pizza, cake, you name it.
cons:
You are forced to work no more than 40 hours a week unless given express permission from your manager (not easy)
9 hours a day instead of 8 (so that you have every other friday off)
The process to get access to things is long (due to the security concerns)
You cannot download programs from the internet, only from their selected safe programs (again due to security concerns)

review_title: Monotonous Work, Slow, Old Sofware, Awful Culture
job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Starting pay out of college was good, at first
Can have cool opportunities if in the right place at right time
cons: Extremely difficult to differentiate yourself from being "just another number".  Strict minimums for promotions, even if doing great work. Changed managers so many times I lost count. IFG is a mess. When you hire in they stick you on some "meaningful" work until you get fully cleared, 16 months is typical.  Culture is atrocious, many creepy old men, absolutely no fun can be had. No swag given out to employees EVER. If you have a good idea and bring it to your manager, you simply are told "Great! Stick to your work" and it dies.

pros:
The workload can be interesting and there is plenty of overtime to be had. There are occasional travel opportunities.

There are some movements that might fix many of the cons but the people making the changes are at the senior management level and don't seem to have the backing of their superiors.
cons:
Pay is roughly 20% below market value across the board, benefits are standard for the industry. There is very little opportunity for advancement past the senior level and promotions are not based on performance .

This location is somewhat cutoff from larger Lockheed Martin as it is a government owned contractor operated location. This also means there is no R&D and very little training or overhead budget.

job_title: Systems Engineer Senior Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Stability, flexibilty, ability to telecommute in some jobs.  The ability to move around to other jobs, locations, and roles is good.  I have had the opportunity to work in several different states for Lockheed - including WA, DC, VA, FL, & TX.  I have moved around in vocations as well - from software to systems, to management.  There is good training here...but it depends a lot on the corporation you work for within Lockheed...they all are run very differently.
cons: slow career path.  maybe a bit to much virtual teaming...would be nice to have more $ set aside for teaming and getting people together

review_title: Don't expect to be rewarded with promotions even if you are an outstanding employee.
pros: Relatively stable job. It's a good place to get experience before you find a better paying job elsewhere. The programs are exciting.
cons: The promotion system is broken and they are top heavy. They say they pay for performance. What they actual mean is that they pay you for your years of service and performance. It is very frustrating when you do twice the work of the person sitting next to you yet they make twice as much as you do just because they have been there longer. They will not consider you for promotions unless you have been working your current job for a certain number of years even if you are a rockstar employee.

review_title: Good as it gets for Big
job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
The pay is reasonable at the lowest levels and crazy at the top levels
Generally speaking, you get paid for the time you put in, there is no endless hours for no additional pay like you get in small companies. Big Business offers you some job definitions and work limits which can be helpful.
cons:
For the most part what ever you get hired in for (paywise)...thats what you get.
There are no merit raises that I have ever heard of.
A good review lets you keep your job and maybe get a 2-3% increase annually.
Union Folks are not judged in ANY way for their performance this hurts the good performers...and allows the hideous performers to stay as long as they don't mischarge or endager someone.

job_title: Software Engineer Senior Staff in Littleton, CO
pros: Great experience and opportunities to learn and grow. You get to solve tough problems that help protect our great nation. You have the opportunity to learn and excel in disciplines including engineering, leadership and project management. If you are driven then you will have an opportunity to excel.
cons: Since our primary customers are in defense our opportunities are tied to defense budgets. As defense related budgets contract so will opportunities. Every industry has ups and downs so the question is how long will this downturn last.

pros: It has great name recognition and builds products vital to the country.  The pay is not terrible and it does occasionally support telecommuting for certain positions.
cons: Inept upper management has completely swamped the company at the Sr. Manager level on up to the top.  Social justice initiatives have become much higher priority than actually delivering working products.  IT decisions are made by people that have no idea what they are doing.  Benefits have been almost completely slashed "because that's what other companies are doing".

pros: Currently on my second program and what I will say is that you will learn a lot. Lockheed Martin is growing exponentially with all the new business and we need folks across multiple functions. The opportunity to move into different areas and locations is one of the main reasons why I wanted to work at Lockheed. You will learn a lot but you have to want to learn and put the time into it.
cons: Proposals keep coming and Lockheed keeps giving into the customer demands with ridiculous deadlines. Therefore, work life balance is challenged. If the company wants to retain talent they need to work with the customer instead of saying yes all the time. Accountability is also a problem when it comes to financial deadlines.

review_title: Good first job, but maybe not the best long-term career decision
pros: Good first job with fair compensation right out of school. The nine by eighty (9 work days x 80 hours) work week is a definate plus that gives you time to have a life outside of your job. And finally, it is a company that I am proud to work for.
cons: Many of the promotions are handled on a tenure basis and not necessarily on the quality and quantity of your work. This is especially true for employees that have been around for a few years and want to take the next step, but don't have 5+ years under their belts yet.

review_title: Used to be great a couple of years ago, but now it's just not.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Huntsville, AL
pros: 9x80 work schedule is awesome. Usually very flexible on time and scheduling. Most managers are very accommodating when you need to leave work for personal reasons. The unlimited sick and personal leave time is awesome. However, new policies are that you can't have overtime unless you've "paid back" any sick or personal leave that you've taken.
cons: Three words: Model driven development. They just don't put an emphasis or give importance to real software work. They're putting all of their baskets into system engineers with software titles. Don't go here if you expect to pound code. There just isn't any opportunity to do it now.

review_title: Proud to be part of a company that engineers, integrates and builds complex products.
pros:
Flexible in several aspects- approved to work part time when fit with both the project and a move cross country- ramped back up when the project took on more responsibility.  Worked remotely when not at subcontractor or traveling. Very smart, capable, colleagues- many experts available companywide to tap from. Accessible training to stay updated, highly ethical.
Always proud that there were many women in high level technical management at one of the largest defense companies.
cons:
Too large at times and unable to get common processing across the board. Felt like reinventing the wheel when you know it has been done elsewhere. Constantly working to improve the common processing. 
Spent a lot of time and money changing employee evaluation system - added much confusion without many benefits.

pros: Good benefits if you can accept the low salary
cons:
Low salary: I started the process of exploring employment with Lockheed Martin, by speaking with a recruiter. Among other things, I discussed the salary I was looking for. The recruiter said the salary was within range, and set me up for multiple interviews. I spent several hours on the interviews over the course of several weeks. After multiple interviews, they made me an offer that was $50,000 less than what the initial recruiter told me. The salary offered was way below market for a Senior Software Engineer with a clearance. I guess they have to pay for all the shiny buildings with below market pay.

The recruiter was also very unprofessional and unresponsive. She could not be reached on the phone, would not return calls and took several days to respond to emails.

job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Marietta, GA
pros:
Extremely large organization - lots of  technology, smart people, good projects.
Proud to work at Lockheed Martin.
Generally, technical people are well managed; not micro-managed.
Top-notch vendor relationships - constant stream of product orientations, presentations, etc.
Training!
cons:
Hard to get noticed.  Maybe a cliche - a lot easier to get noticed for messing up, than doing something extremely well.
Not a lot of visible, young rising stars.  Management is mostly 15/20-years + with company crowd.
A lot of military veterans.  Not overt, but definitely a clique-like feel.
Perception is that it is hard to fire a Lockheed Martin employee.
Personal work spaces are dull - many without natural light (Marietta, GA plant)

review_title: Lockheed Martin - Going Downhill due to Current Leadership
pros:
Commitment to Ethics
Salary
Opportunities for Exciting / Challenging Assignments
Ability to Move between Divisions/Departments
Wide Range of Georgraphic Locations 
Wide Range of Products
cons:
Leadership in Electronic Systems Area is totally Lacking
Old Boys Club and Culture
Lack of Communication with Employees on Key Issues
Treats Employees like #s instead of People
Poor Talent Management
Lack of Strategic Direction
Too Much Bureacracy and too Difficult to Suggest New and Different Ways of Doing Things
Management out of Touch with Reality of Employees

pros: My manager gives me a lot of autonomy to do my work. The pay and benefits are not bad, but are not anything to brag about either. Job security may be better at this company than others -- I'm not sure nor am I convinced (we've been having lay-offs, and there's rumor of more lay-offs coming).
cons: Financially oriented instead of engineering oriented -- always feel like budget and schedule take precedence over good engineering practice. Work-life balance is non-existant; in my department, they expect employees to work a lot of hours. The five-hour gate is terrible -- every month, the management in my department expect people to work 20 hours and not get paid for that work, but they still bill the customer!

review_title: Don't walk-  RUN away from this job
pros:
The work itself is extremely easy if you've worked as a Gunner's Mate or even a Master at Arms.  If you're looking for a civilian job where you don't have to learn any new skills, this is it.

Lockheed Martin is a big name that looks good on your resume when you're looking for better paying jobs.

Some of the active duty sailors are very nice to work with.  The government's GS employees, not so much.
cons:
-Pay raises are non-existent no matter how long you've been with the program.  Unless your site unionizes, you're probably getting a 0.1% increase.  This program is stuck on the wage determination scales.

-Site leads and management do their own performance assessments and quality assurance ratings, which has got to be some kind of ethics violation.

-There is absolutely no kind of Human Resources support beyond a 1-800 number, and payroll mistakes are frequent and hard to correct.

review_title: It's all in who you know at Lockheed
pros: There are many opportunities for advancement. Pay and benefits are adequate by today’s standards.  Having spent double digit years employed there I have seen the good the bad and the ugly.
cons: Nepotism and the good ol’boy system are firmly entrenched at least at the Fort Worth Division. I’m speaking about the salaried employees only. I was salaried while I was there but I could never get it thru my thick skull that to get ahead at Lockheed you can’t waste your time building aircraft. To get ahead you have to work for yourself and network with all the right people. Lockheed will still pay you just like you were contributing to building the product. Fortunately there are enough honest hard working employees that still have good work ethics to build some very fine aircraft.

job_title: Program Management Senior Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Very interesting and capable products.  Promotion of patriotic values. Paid tuition benefit (although, it comes and goes).
cons: Executive Management's ability to run the company is heavily diluted with incapable, unintelligent, and under-qualified personnel who've been placed into positions based solely upon their gender (i.e., female).

review_title: Finally Feel Like I Am A Part Of A Company
pros:
I've absolutely enjoyed working for Lockheed Martin.  Since winning the contract that I am on, instead of keeping me at my underpaid level I was at with my previous employer (which was my fault for accepting such a low pay), they have made an effort to increase my salary to be more in-line with the industry.  

This is also the first company that I have worked for where I have felt like that I'm truly part of the company.  (i.e. - They care about my professional growth.)  And now, having lost the contract that I am on, they are doing everything they can to find me a new position within Lockheed Martin.  This is exactly the opposite from how my previous company was when they lost the contract.
cons: I wish there were more opportunities in my area.

job_title: Software Engineer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: I like it here because the management does not micro manage its employees. There is a lot of flexibility on work schedules as long as you are putting 8 hrs a day. They also allow teleworking on selected days.
cons: No Bonus sharing program for employees, No Stock Options. Too much unnecessary training per year. Multiple user accounts for different sites.

review_title: Worst place for a Software Engineer with an expectation to grow.
job_title: Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Every other Friday off because of a 9/80 schedule.

Flexible hours depending on your manager.

Security is taken very seriously.
cons:
Parking is awful, if you get to work after 8:00 you’ll have to walk a mile to get to your work area.

Pay is high for the area and according to Lockheed “adequate,” but you can make significantly more elsewhere.

Facility is really depressing without any type of natural light or windows. 

Younger software engineers will have a tough time, most of the decisions made on teams come from 20+ years of experience employees with functional programming and poor software design.

Lack of younger engineers makes it hard to enjoy being at work.

Everything is tied to charging a contract, if there is an event for learning that would be beneficial to you as an employee, you will be forced to do it on your own time and not on company time.

Work is not technical enough to keep most young engineers, as my work has become a simple “copy and paste” job without any need of computer science fundamentals.

pros: None that apply to this experience.
cons:
Applied online and received an acknowledgement email.
Received follow-up email a few days later, requesting additional information.
Phone call received the following week, voicemail left asking me to call them back - first name only given by Lockheed Martin employee, along with contact number.
I returned the call the same day, to be told that they weren't sure who had contacted me, so they took my number and said they'd find out who I needed to speak to.
No response received, so I emailed the in house recruitment team as I was concerned the person who had left the voicemail would think I hadn't returned their call.
After much debate over email, the company denied receiving my application at all.
Two weeks later, I received an email advising that my application had been unsuccessful.
What a shambles!!!!!

review_title: A cool first job. All the plusses and minuses that come from working for a giant defense contractor.
pros: I have been very pleased with the work life balance. Management has been very accommodating with flexible schedules, work atire, and access to training.
cons: Dealing with all the layers of red tape to get things done. The fact that my work computer is so locked down that it is painfully slow to check my email, let alone write software.

review_title: High value company with updward mobility....if you are in the right profession
job_title: Configuration Analyst, Senior in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: Lockheed Martin has great values and provides products that protect the war fighters and America. I think the compensation and benefits are very good compared to the rest of corporate America. You work on very advanced technology which is rare.
cons: There is a lot of opportunity for advancement especially with the baby boomer generation getting close to retirement which Lockheed has a lot of. Unfortuntely you need to be in Engineering or Finance to really have any possibility of real career advancement. There aren't a lot of opportunities for the rest of us despite our strong leadership abilities.

review_title: Very Good Company to work for...
job_title: Computer Systems Analyst in Mount Laurel, NJ
pros:
Professional, exciting, always using the latest technology.  The company has a vision of One Company One Team, and in the corporate world this is hard to make happen... but most people that I worked with try to apply that principle.  This makes for a successful system for getting things done.
This is one of the reasons why LMCO has a great reputation... the people that work there and the attitude of who we work for.
cons: Corporate America is the toughest to make a success these days.  This economy makes careers in this company very difficult... no guarantees you will work here 3 years or 15.  DOD contractors are governed by government jobs and contracts.  So lay-off's are more so now than they have been in the past.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Charlotte, NC
pros: This company offers flex time to their employees  on most contracts ( when possible), and  promotes balance between their  employee's lives and the workplace . Don't get me  wrong - employees are expected to step up and work VERY HARD when it comes to deadlines and deliverables.  LM also promotes from within when possible.  They also have an advanced leadership program for ambitious employees. This is a highly ethical company that embraces diversity.
cons: All of Lockheed's work is contract based -so  layoffs can be common and frequent.  But they try  to place employees in other jobs, if they are willing to travel or take a lesser positions.   After being laid off once, I was re-hired. Current crunch with Fed real funding could impact  company's future profit and  opportunity.

job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Flexible hours, some interesting problems. Very nice, very smart employees.
cons: I wasn't developing. Many workers were trying to split their time across multiple teams which meant they couldn't focus on one project. Classified nature of work meant everything moved more slowly. Hard to get your hands on an unclassified computer, even if you need one for development. Company seemed to be cutting costs wherever they could. No bonuses. All the bureaucracy of working for the government combined with the wacky fun of working in an incredibly dull office.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: Specifically for the Lockheed Martin Aeronautics site at Palmdale, CA, the Skunk Works, this review is to say that this is a place where you can achieve a high level of autonomy and recognition for your work, especially as an early career engineer.  There is a high percentage of employees who are hard core airplane people and love their work and that makes the Skunk Works a pleasant place to be even during hard times. Lots of opportunity for a good work/life balance, as well.
cons: There is not much work to be had at this site right now which means that resources are low and makes other work more difficult to get done. Otherwise, no cons.

job_title: Research Scientist in King of Prussia, PA
pros:
Internal job postings policy is fair and open
Separate vacation and sick-leave (not combined "paid time off")
401(k) plan has reasonable options, including self-managed (up to 75% of balance)
Company raises remain competitive
cons:
Former defined-benefit retirement plan now frozen.
Health care plan has high deductibles and high portion for employee paid premiums, but does have reasonably broad network
While some divisions still have respect and appreciation of engineering workforce, other divisions (IS&GS in particular) treat engineers as commodities, with the resultant "race to the mean" skill level

review_title: Great Company but time to leave
pros: LM offered stability while still providing flexibility to move to many different contracts. Lockheed can also provide career/salary growth but you have to be willing to spend the 'Good Will' you've accumulated. As long as you spend your good will every few years, you'll do decent compared to your peers in smaller companies.
cons: Lockheed is a huge company and often its HR policies are one size fits all. If you want an exception to the rules, you need an executive advocate and lots of patience. With all the changes Lockheed is going through, if you can find a comparable job elsewhere, take it.

review_title: Great Company Depending On Who You Work With
job_title: Systems Administrator Asc in Herndon, VA
pros: Some of the best people to work with were at Lockheed martin, the facility was very nice, work / life balance and ample career opportunities to move around. It all depends on who you're working with.
cons: I had some of the worst supervisors and managers I've ever had in my career here. One supervisor was very unprofessional and treated the younger employees like garbage. She went past the line of employee harassment. Some even reported her to our manager. HR and management did not handle the situation very well. The supervisor later was joking about having a one on one with management about the incident in our morning team meeting.

review_title: Prepare to be taken advantage of
pros: They pay a lot for the area. You mostly get paid for the work you do.
cons: They have been gutting benefits for years. They nickel and dime PTO. You get few of the benefits of being salary, but many of the drawbacks of being hourly. You WILL have credit stolen from you by management, but be blamed if a project fails. They value butts in chairs over skill. You WILL stagnate. Bureaucracy is the rule.

pros:
Diverse workforce.
Strong military pride and customer interaction.
Excellent education reimbursements.
Global presence.
Open door policy with any leader at any level.
Health rewards program is generous, but expensive.
cons:
Quantity of years on the job vs quality of years is looked at first and foremost. Preference almost always given to candidates with more years on the job and strong military background.
HR is very slow to move on internal postings. It takes anywhere from 2-9+ months to hear anything when you post online.
Poor merit raises despite strong financial performance with successful and above ratings at year-end review. Ruthless bell curve distribution.
Uneven distribution of workloads across departments and lack of communication across organizations.

review_title: Great way to start my career - company really believes in its engineers and supports them.
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Rockville, MD
pros: Tons of leadership training, ability to transfer within the company, solid and clear path to promotion, especially at junior levels. Met some great managers and engineers.  Strongly motivate leaders to mentor others and it is a team atmosphere, not competitive within.  Definitely recommend, especially to young career folks or those who like the structure and stability of a large company.  Plus the stock has been killing it lately in the market.
cons: Federal budgets are declining and therefore LM budgets too - they have been tightening belt and doing layoffs.  Not a fast pace of change.  Depends on what work you do and what you're interested in, but I never really liked the whole "blowing stuff up" part of the company.

job_title: Subcontract Administrator in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
I have been here about a month, and will share my experiences so far:

Great Work Life Balance- I started in mid-November right before Thanksgiving. First week had Friday off, next week 2 days off (thanksgiving and day after, Paid), The next week had Friday off again. This is my first full working week and it has been great. Fridays are generally easier because people are out. I have met some people that never work Fridays too.

Vacation Time- 3 weeks paid vacation starting, 25 off Fridays, 11 paid federal holidays. 5 sick days and 3 personal days. 

Great Co-Workers- I was blessed to be with a pretty young crowd, mid to late 20's early 30's. Of course there are some a bit older, but it's a good mix. 

Team Environment- Happy hour every Thursday before our off Friday. The last Friday of every month we celebrate that months birthdays with a small party (food and drinks).

Monthly Cooking Competitions.( last month we had 50+ different salsas and dips) January is desserts 

Nice Equipment- I was given a nice laptop and case my first day. Lots of office supplies, 2 computer monitors, Ice/Water machine..

No Micro-Management. Have yet to feel like my manager is constantly watching over me. 

Work Environment- Probably the best part about Lockheed Fort Worth, this  is where we assemble the JSF F-35 Lightning II and the F-16 Fighting Falcon. I can take a 5 minute walk and be staring at complete fighter jets (that will actually be flown, possibly in combat, and are not sitting in a museum). It is incredible 

Products: We build the worlds leading technology. There are many more, but to name a few:

1) Orion Spacecraft that flown 12/5/2015 around the earth, may take people to mars, and was the farthest flown Man-able capsule in 40 years
2) SR-71 Blackbird, the fastest air breathing manned aircraft ever 
3) The worlds first and only Nuclear Fusion reactor 
4) F-35 Lightning II 
All built by Lockheed Martin

The Worlds Largest Defense Contractor and a Fortune 500 Company- Number 59 in 2014 

Compensation- I received offers from BAE Systems, OHA Private Equity, and Warren Douglass. Lockheed had the highest salary, and a sign on bonus. Started at 55k with 1k sign on. ( BBA in Accounting 3.4 GPA from A&M in 2.5 years) 

Generally Upbeat- Any person you meet is willing to help you. My 3rd day here I was lost looking at a fire evacuation map on the wall (having no sense of direction) a woman stopped and asked me if I was lost, I told her I was, and  where I was trying to go and she walked me directly to the office. She didn't just point and say some directions that I likely couldn't have followed; we walked together, and showed me  some landmarks incase I got lost again. We had a great conversation too. 

9/80 Schedule- 9/80 means you work the following schedule: 
         M-9hrs, T-9,  W-9,  R-9,  F-8;       M-9,  T-9,  W-9,  R-9,  F-OFF. 
Most corporate jobs require 9 hours a day anyway, and never get Fridays off. 

Flex Time- If you need to leave early one day, or know you will be leaving early in the future you can work extra an extra hour or two one day and take off early the next. Mostly use it only when you need to. 

Hours- If you come in at 6 you can leave at 3 (with no lunch). I get in at 7 a.m. and usually leave at 4:30-5. 

Retirement Plan- We have a pretty great retirement package, a top competitor of any Fortune 500 Company. The total company contribution is roughly 7%. Capital Contribution 3%, SSP Company match up to 4% (at 8% employee contribution), so maxing out your marginal contribution totals up to 15% toward retirement. Considering that the average American saves <5% per year, Lockheed is pretty good.

Telecommuting/ Work From Home- I have yet to work from home but there are some in my office that do, and I was told in my first day lunch meeting with my manager that I will be able to after about 6 months. Some departments let you work one day from home every week, just depends on your department. My HR rep was one of those that did. 

Last Thing- Don't believe all you hear about not being noticed and the company being too big to succeed. If you work hard, and get stuff done you will move up fast. I was concerned about this when I started but after asking around I found that you will typically jump a level every year to 15 months which means a minimum of 10k raise, plus a yearly performance bonus of about 4%. A girl in my office jumped 2 levels in 18 months. Transferring to a different business unit can make that process go faster, and usually will get a bigger than a 10k raise (unlikely to be more than 15k) until you have had 7-12 years of service and are getting a manager, senior manager, or director role. Pay raises are based on how much effort you put in. I have met some people that have not attempted gain access to the computer systems after over a month of being here, (which is critical to get actual work done) yet I got all my security clearance and system access in 4 days. I also ask for work to do, and am happy to do the repetitive tasks that slow down my teammates.
cons:
The Walk- Depending on where you work the walk could be 10+minutes from your car. Luckily, my area of the building is close to a main entrance and non-numbered parking, allowing me to get inside and sat down in less than 5 minutes. A motorcycle guarantees close parking and a short walk. 

The Food- The food found in Aero Café and 50 Foot Isle is overly expensive. Easy to spend 8-12$ on a meal on food that is decent quality. Aero Café has a bigger selection and some less expensive choices but is easily a 800 meter walk from my office.

No Covered Parking- I have seen a handful car with paint peeling and fading from baking in the sun for hours on end. I am debating purchasing an older used car as a commuter to work simply for that reason.

review_title: Where your 30+ years makes you as valuable as an intern
pros: Everyone has heard of them
cons:
Let me preface this by stating I work for the IS&GS division. Earlier this year we lost a lot of our top management - transferring out to other divisions. Shortly after that Lockheed announced that they're getting rid of our division (they still don't know how) and that NO ONE WORKING IN IS&GS can transfer out. Oh, expect for upper management who just happened to transfer out a few weeks earlier....

Then, to make us "more competitive" they switched our health insurance to the same plan they offer interns. Yup. people who have worked their entire life for Lockheed, helping them achieve success after success are now being rewarded by the same health care as a summer intern.

If I want to be treated with no respect I could have remained married.

review_title: As with all jobs it's what you make it
pros: Lockheed has excellent benefits. 9/80 schedule and great 401k contributions. Nobody holds you down from excelling and in my experience if you perform you will be rewarded. I have heard complaints that promotions are slow and raises are low. This is not true. Raises are slow if you are average. Their are many smart people at Lockheed so standing out is tough. I will say that there are many older employees so in the near future there is going to be a massive opportunity to advance.
cons: My only real gripe is that for a major company the IT budget is awful. It's obvious the first place to cut money from a gov contract is IT.

review_title: Insurance Deductible is too high. Can't afford to get sick.
job_title: Crib Control Attendant in Palmdale, CA
pros: The people are amazing. Work is rewarding. Very happy to be working at Lockheed Martin.
cons:
Medical Insurance deductible is outrageous. 
By the time deductible is reached the year is over & you have to start over.
I literally can't afford to get sick. I refuse to even make a doctor appointment for anything. So much for their Health & Wellness Programs. Doesn't make sense to even get involved in that.

pros: Lockheed provides a great learning environment and ability to take on an increasing level of responsibility.  Promotions came slowly at the site I worked at since it was unionized but management was very cognizant of your performance level and did the best they could to promote you.
cons: I worked at one of the very few sites where the engineering staff was unionized.  This really shackled management's hands in a number of ways.  Promotions and bonuses are all driven by letters of understand and approved by the union.  The union has the interests of the poor to mediocre employees at heart.  Don't work at a unionized site if you are looking to be rewarded for all-star efforts.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: I've been working nearly 30yrs at multiple companies, with 12yrs at LM Aero.  Pros: I've never seen a company that requires so very little for such good pay.  Corporate welfare abounds here.  If you have a family (that you like spending time with), then this place is awesome.  You can strap on your golden skates, and be home at the same time ever evening, and have every weekend off.  It's really great for spending the most about of time with your family.
cons: It is the most absurd place I've ever worked.  Burning budget so as not to "give back" anything is common practice.  Be prepared for an amazing level unproductive time.  The old military adage, "Hurry up and wait.", is alive and strong here.  The first day I was here, a senior worker told me young hire sometimes had a hard time due to the slow pace of work.  I should have run right there. :)

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Huntsville, AL
pros: Good pay. Decent benefits. Opportunities for growth and differentiation as long as you are willing to put in the work and time.
cons: Change is slow, which is expected for a multinational company. Management is sometimes out of touch.Company wide policies may not be applicable or relevant in certain divisions.

review_title: Only difference between 1950 and now is a computer... Not for problem solvers or proactive people.
pros: Easy to shine if your smart and ambitious, somewhat stable employment.
cons:
Average employee age must be near 60
Low pay and horrible raises for top performers
No stock plan or bonus
Filled with very moderately to unintelligent people
Process driven for everything with processes being 50 years old
Very outdated in every regard: corporate culture, IT, management philosophy (body in seats X hours per day is viewed as productivity)
Poor performers are not let go just constantly shuffled around
Operates as a true extension of the government
Bureaucratic and filled with superfluous layers of management 
Everything is slow as can be

pros: In my short experience at Lockheed, I've been able to jump between a variety of projects that are vastly different from one another. It's easy to move around and try out research projects or work on mainline business. Many opportunities to work on cutting edge projects.
cons: The work is difficult and you learn nearly completely through experience. There are not a lot of training opportunities so it really does take some time to feel comfortable with what you're working on. It also means that you have to put in a LOT of hours as an entry level employee, especially toward the end of the year.

pros: Excellent challenges.  If it served the illusions that Management thinks it pursues, then it is fine, but for overall scope, not good.
cons: Draconian at this location LRAFB.  Self-Serving Level 5 Managers.  HR very self-serving.  I think it is just the MST Division.  For me, a 'working Manager' there was no work - life balance.  All work to save the place with 8 year old equipment that no one had the insight to replace before I arrived.  My predecessor was terribly under-educated in an experience sense and was allowed to do whatever he wanted, though he didn't know much.  Fixing it fell on my shoulders as an incumbent.  With terribly low wages and a very counter-productive HR.  No support for non-union Managers.

review_title: Not a bad place to work but it depends who you work for
pros: Generally a great place to work - great pay and benefits (although the benefits have been reduced year after year) and flexibility of hours.  I worked with a lot of very smart, talented people.  A lot of opportunities to work in different organizations throughout your career.
cons: For the most part the management is good, however some managers are condescending and down right rude to employees often creating a bad working environment.  HR and upper management turns a blind eye to these managers as long as they continue to produce results.  Full Spectrum Leadership is part of management's goals and they should be held accountable for their actions.

review_title: Good place to work, Great people, recongnition not the best
pros: Work your own hours, working with your own customers.  Friendly people, and good benefits.  The management is excellent when it comes to letting you work independently.  I would say that the teams that I personally work with are some of the greatest people.  There is freedom of religion here, making it a great place to work without being uncomfortable.  All in all, I would rank Lockheed Martin as being a wonderful work place.  There is also opportunity around the country if you were to ever want to transfer or move.  This is also one of the great benefits of working for such a company.
cons: Lower pay scale, not much recognition for accomplishments.

review_title: Great place to start, plenty of room to move around since it's a big company.
pros: Great place to gain experience if you're just starting off.  There are lots of locations around the US and even around the world to move around in if you want.  Get to work on interesting projects from time to time.
cons: Lockheed wins some really cool contracts but then manages to handle the execution of them very poorly.  There are frequently the "wrong people" making all the important decisions which result in budget problems, wrong equipment being purchased, focus on status reports over actually performing work.

review_title: LM-SSC leadership response to the current economic downturn has been less than stellar.
pros: Lockheed Martin has very competitive direct and indirect compensation package. Company stresses and strongly supports the work-life balance, evidenced by the very popular 9/80 work schedule, flex-time and some telecommuting options. Collaborative, virtual and mobile/wireless work environments on the campus are some newer initiatives that are currently in their infancies (subject to government/program security requirements).
cons: Current economic environment has LM-SSC downsizing. LM-SSC targets senior staff  and senior level positions with the expectation that staff and associate level positions can/will step up to fill the more senior vacated positions at a lower cost to the company. While the corporate and company executive management appears to adhere to the corporate ethical values, that does not appear to be the case at the entry through director levels of management, especially during this volatile economic period.

review_title: LM is solid as a whole, but IS&GS doesn't offer career growth or any training
job_title: I T and Process Architect in Denver, CO
pros: Work/life balance, decent pay, good people.
cons:
IS&GS doesn't provide much career development.  In the past 6 years I have requested, but not been granted any training... "because the customer will not pay for training".  With the exception of compliance training, the company doesn't have an organized training plan for the employees.  I know a senior level person who had to pay for their own way to an I.T. conference which benefited our client.  

During the past government layoff, we were forced to take vacation and were told we couldn't look for work else where in LM.  Working for a big company like LM, I would have expected a little more support, but we got a 4 day notice to "take vacation".

review_title: I enjoyed my 10+ years at Lockheed Martin
job_title: Systems Integration & Test Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: During the first 5 years of my career at LM, the possibilities for career growth were endless. LM was winning government contracts at an outstanding rate and the work was plentiful. I had the opportunity to travel, meet new people and learn a lot about the company.
cons: The remainder of my career was nothing like the beginning of my career. As government contracts slowed down, so did the work available to the employees. LM has an extremely high turn over rate and often I felt as if I were just another employee. Definitely a insider "good old boys" organization.

review_title: It was a challenging and rewarding work experience assisting the military accomplish their mission in the battlefield
job_title: Network Manager III in Bargay, Kandahar Province
pros: We worked long hard hours under adverse conditions but at the end of the day I felt like a did my best in our efforts to defeat the enemy and keep our men as safe a possible under the circumstances.  We worked side by  side the airmen and soldiers and I will remember the experience all my life.
cons: As I stated we worked under adverse and often dangerous conditions.  Being away from my family was the most difficult part of the job and the long hours did take a toll on you after a while.  The living conditions were tough but we knew that going in.

job_title: Subcontract Management, Stf in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Pay and benefits are very good, people are professional, intelligent, educated and try to do a great job.  Ethics are important to the company and therefore, to the employees.  Upward mobility is possible if you learn the Lockheed way, work hard, perform above expectations and work on high profile projects--where management pays attention.
cons: The company is so large that they need lots of policies and procedures and metrics to manage the place.  Sometimes metrics are one-size fits all, even when the metrics don't apply to the work you're doing.  It is a very large company and is difficult to get recognized if you're doing routine, mundane work.

pros: Strong solid company that is stable for the most part. As long as the government is somewhat stable. There are a lot of intelligent people that work there and the work life balance is very manageable at the Individual Contributor level. If you want a good stable job with good experience this is a great environment.
cons: Typical Cons of a Government Contractor. Culture is very slow moving and you sometimes have to work with unmotivated employees. The annual increases are relatively low and you have to fight for any increases outside the normal cycle. Promotions are typically based on years of experience instead of performance unless you make a good relationship with a manager that has power. Management is very political and this gets in the way of the teams trying to do work.

pros: Great company with good benefits. I worked on a military installation as a instructor and course coordinator. Corporate Leadership was engaged in our program and supported its employees.  My program manager was one of the best leaders / bosses I've ever worked for.
cons: LM is a very large corporation engaged in serving the defense industry.  At time the human resources personnel seemed out of touch with those on the ground and pushed out redundant HR corporate training materials by the boat load. These programs often took employees away from the important work LM payed us to perform.

review_title: CEO concerned more about Wall Street than Employees
job_title: Principal Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The ability to work around eye watering technology, with a large and diverse portfolio of products and services.
cons: Latest CEO, Marilyn Hewson, is nothing like her predecessors. Yes, she is bright.  Yes, she can work the media (as she always has) to get herself recognized. However, she has never cared about her employees. She has fully selected the path of cutting costs FASTER than the loss of revenue.  So at the end of the year the company beats estimates and we all cheer about the stock price.  The problem is we are in constant RIFs, with the best talent leaving the company. Investments in R&D are down tremendously. This is a company in deep trouble and on an unsustainable path.

review_title: Great place to be if you crave job security
job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Moorestown, NJ
pros: It's extremely hard to get fired. There are plenty of departments to transfer to if you want to learn a lot about defense.
cons: I worked in 2 departments and received very little to no training in each. The simulation and analysis work I was doing in MATLAB wasn't hard, but understanding the results of the simulations required a lot of expertise. There is no documentation, you can't Google it, it's not intuitive at all. Therefore you NEED someone who has the experience to train you. My department was struggling to maintain employees because we didn't have that experience. I ended up leaving because everything became a guessing game.

job_title: Contracts Negotiator Staff in Washington, DC
pros: Was in the finance group, first in the Finance Leadership Development Program and then on to other roles within the F&BO org. Generally worked with great people, supportive managers and ethical leadership. Had one issue with a team leader who created an ethical issue, but it was addressed quickly, thoroughly and adequately. LM is an industry leader and a solid company.
cons: Getting recognition for your accomplishments can be a challenge. You have to know when to be the squeaky wheel. The performance recognition system is very formulaic and it can take some practice to make the system work for you. Also, even if you are at the top of your game performance wise, pay raises are very modest.

pros:
401k match is 4%. 
Job security. I don't think anyone gets fired.
Most people are great.
Cafeteria on site.
cons:
Sub-Contractors can make more than regular employees and get a better schedule 9/80 vs flex 40.
The health benefits are high deductible. 
A lot of lifers. This makes upward mobility more difficult.
Most projects are working with dated technology (ex: Java 1.6).
Enormous amounts of bureaucracy. Everything takes three times as long as it should. 
Tons of useless compliance trainings (ex: human trafficking). 
Company pretends to have high ethical and moral standards while simultaneously selling billions of dollars of weapons to Saudi Arabia. 
You’re working for the military industrial complex. 
No potential to work from home on a lot of projects.
CEO made 20 million dollars last year, but you have to pay for coffee in the office.

job_title: Multi-functional Financial Analyst Senior in Littleton, CO
pros: Flexible environment, well above average benefits, 90/80 work schedule, interesting products, diverse workforce, it's very large so there are lots of geographic locations and programs to choose from.
cons: Not all business units are created equal.  LM Space needs some corporate intervention to clean up their rotten culture of extreme cronyism.  No career growth. Availability of promotions and development programs are entirely based on knowing the right people, which means many high performers get stuck and unable to progress. All the opportunities go to the same people.  The age discrimination has gotten very blatant, again.

job_title: College Student Non Tech Intern in Alexandria, VA
