pros: Lockheed Martin opened many doors for me. LM had a comprehesive intern program that encouraged students to be eager about all facets of their internship.  I loved every minute.
cons: Returning to LM was hard my third year.  Althought I had two years experience under my belt and great reviews from my two previous years, many othe managers were stressed on GPA's.  I got a 3.0, drove 200 miles to interview and did not get in, where as my 1st and 2nd year got in w/o an interview and w/o a review of my transcript -- and my grades were lower back then!

review_title: Lockheed Martin, great job for an entry-level or senior level technologist
pros:
The work schedule is flexible, when you put in your 40 hours you are allowed to leave (as long as it is okay with your manager) or you can bank the hours for use later.
You gain a lot of experience from LM and if you stay with them and do a good job and you are a US citizen, then you can easily get hired on at the Social Security Administration which is who we are contracted to work for in the Woodlawn, MD area.
cons:
The pay is less than at other area government contractors.
They hire many H1B visas which take away from jobs for citizens, I don't think it is fair that they hire people just because they can pay them less.
Only merit raises from 1-2.5% once per year.

review_title: Lockheed - Great place to work and develope your career
job_title: Lead Member Engineering Staff in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Lockheed Martin provides me with a flexible work schedule so that I can take care of my work and family and feel good about doing both.  They also pay for the majority of the Health Benefits that we receive.  And since most of the work is for the government, I feel like I am contributing to the security of the United States while having the opportunity to work on very interesting things.  There are also a lot of outside activities sponsored by the company, including golf leagues, tennis leagues, tutoring in schools, bike-a-thons, blood drives,  etc.
cons: Due to the deadlines that we work to, this can be a stressful job if you can't separate your work life from your home life.

job_title: Manufacturing Engineer Senior in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: When I started with Lockheed it was a much better run Engineering related company.  It is a great place to work if you are well liked by management and have the necessary education levels they prefer.  The benefits are among the industry's best for the old timers (PENSION) but not as appealing for the newer employees.
cons: In some instances it can be an Good Ole Boys club where the ones the kiss butt make out at raise time and job assignments.  I am sure it is about the same in most Government supported (welfare) defense contractors.

review_title: Love the people and the company!
pros:
Everyone is very nice and pleasant. I worked out in nowhere land on a contract that Lockheed wasn't even the prime on. Although this was the case, they always tried to make you feel at home and connected to Lockheed.

- Very good people
- Everyone really liked their job
- Competitive pay and great benefits!
cons:
- It seemed that some of the major advancement opportunities were given only to people with "grey hair" (that is what people told me on the inside)
- Also, it seemed that you had to be on a major program to get recognized

pros:
+ Incredibly interesting technical work.
+ Very technically talented coworkers.
+ Access to absolutely top end, world class equipment and facilities.
+ With the right attitude, you can learn an impressively diverse skill set here.
+ If you want to drink the Kool-Aid, it's not very hard to jump into some worthless leadership/rotational/development program and ride someone's coattails into a low value/high pay corporate gig.
cons:
- Clings to 1960's style "Company as family" propaganda, when the relationship is clearly one sided.  LM will show you no loyalty, but seems to expect it.
- Clock-punch mentality.  To some, value of work = how early they arrived at the office
- Beyond inept at talent retention.
- Awful at giving promotions; clings to service time model (see 1960's critique above)
- Kafkaesque bureaucratic environment.
- While talented, many of your coworkers are bitter.
- Layers upon layers of upper management and executives.

pros: Very good work community. Company getting better at understanding work/life balance. Challenging work.
cons:
Performance management system needs improvement. It doesn't contain enough checks and balances for contested reviews.

Matrix organization with a low overhead budget means that many functional managers do not have enough time to know what their employees do on a day-to-day basis, but they are the ones writing the annual reviews.

Very little oversight of performance at the functional management level and above.

pros: Honeymoon phase lasted for about a year, then when it was discovered that I can do more work, additional responsibilities were piled on my day.
cons: Over the course of 3+ years, my job description began as a receptionist to pay roll, reset passwords, order office supplies and used SAP to reconcile purchases. Little did I know, b/c I was non-exempt, I was denied an annual performance appraisal, which meant no raises either. My responsibilities increased a three fold, yet I was being paid the same, year after year. In the LM policy somewhere, it states that you can cross train into another career field. Don't buy that-it's BS.

review_title: Great if you have zero experience elsewhere
pros: Decent pay, great 401(K) matching and no vesting period, 9/80 work schedule, low expectations for work load and speed of completion, a good number of smart people, good vacation policy
cons:
If you are a young motivated engineer do not come here.  

The company is full of politics that go back 40+ years, yes there a plenty of old timers still here.  This coupled with the endless bureaucracy and red tape means projects move slower than a snail's pace.  This will quickly kill a young engineer's work ethic and drive.  Executives have said they know this is a problem, but that they cannot fix it.

pros: Defense & Aerospace industry is the the top pay scale in the country.  The mission is critical for the USA's security.
cons: Because of the the mission criticality and high payscale, emploees will drive themlves into the ground to accomplish the task.  Travel can be extensive, but overtime pay can compensate.  Health issues are common place, due to extended hours and completion deadlines.  Additional program resources are typically unavailable to deal with cost overruns, leaving employees to manage with what they have.

review_title: Excellent place to work, wonderful support from management
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Ability to work nearly anywhere in the world, in nearly every profession, only limited by your own skillset.  The evaluation process is fair and even, ensuring all employees are rated similarly. Recognition and salary adjustments are based on performance, rather than favoritism. Work/life balance seems to be engrained in management's mind with multiple flexible working plans available to all employees.
cons: Large company that sometimes has trouble adjusting to new circumstances in the workplace or to customer needs.  So many processes and regulations to ensure conformity allow little flexibility for rapidly changing situations in the work environment.

pros: Good benefits, decent hours if not forced to work unpaid overtime.  Good people at the working level.
cons: Senior Management that is trying to hold on to past glories in a defense industry turned upside down by falling defense spending.  Management will not do whatever it takes to win business.  Always afraid of shareholder reaction if profits fall below expectations.  Would rather give up business than work on contracts that keep people employed but with lower profits.  Highly bureaucratic and top heavy, with commensurate high overhead costs compared to competitors.

pros: Good company to work for, to a point. Challenging work and training has been good.
cons: This is a tough one, but what I have noticed when it comes to lay offs is that favoritism plays a big role in who gets laid off and who doesn't. I noticed in one instance that someone completed all work assigned to them and never complained when asked to stand in for managers or attend meetings. But, there is that one guy that does absolutely nothing 95% of the time and works on their home on company hours, but he is the one that doesn't get laid off, while the guy that tries  hard and never turns down nothing gets the ax. I guess this is  what happens when he is good friends with the lead.

pros:
Large company: fair opportunity for horizontal and vertical transfers.
Mature processes.
Ethics is one of key values.
There can be higher than average job security.
cons:
Onerous hierarchical structure that is heavy with management.
Employee performance review process is highly obscure: an employee placed in the bottom 10% may not be told what his/her peers have done that he/she has not, or what to specifically do to improve performance; an employee can be rated bottom 10% and only be given the explanation that "other peers are more competitive", making it easier for management to put someone at the bottom, than when the rating was done on a 1 to 5 scale with specific negative factors needed to place someone below average.
Being a government contractor, employees need to account for work time by specific task on timecards.
Overtime is valued over work quality.

job_title: Senior Technical Professional-structural in Marietta, GA
pros: union wage , 9/80 work schedual , bonus programs ,  Excellent work enviornment, well maintained facility, the pride you can have in the product you put out ,and the ability to provide well for your loved ones
cons: because of the environment and the product beeing made there are many injuries that happen and the union would rather you get your own lawyer than to spend your dues to defend you and keep your position and the FMLA there is set up to work against the employee

pros:
Large scale high-profile projects (within country of residence)
Good benefits.
Competitive salaries.
cons: Working for Lockheed Martin International, I figured I could apply for jobs in countries all over the world where Lockheed has a footprint.  Turns out that unless you are a U.S. citizen these job openings are not made available to you. The internal job opportunity search engine automatically defaults to only display jobs available in your country of residence/employment. Any international jobs require you to be a U.S. citizen to apply. Your work e-mail is also labelled "EXPAT" in the Global Address Book, if you are not an American citizen.

job_title: Aerospace Engineer Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Lockheed Martin has interesting and challenging programs for engineers of all levels. The 401 k plan has a good match. The company currently has a good backlog of work for more employment stability.
There is good potential for advancement for some engineers in both technical and managerial roles.
cons: In some cases, rather inexperienced engineers are being given leadership roles that they are not prepared for at the moment. More experienced and better educated engineers are looked past in the process.

pros:
-Good work/life balance
-Benefits
-Location to public transportation
cons:
-Upper management hoarding budget spending until the end of the year
-Excessive overrun budget not returned to gov.t nor is it used to keep talent
-Those employed for over 30+ years still employed while those with 3-10 years are forced out the door 
-Good ole boys network still in place, regardless of keeping ethics in mind

pros:
- Company gives opportunity to work on a multitude types of government contracts
- Well known in the area
- Opportunity to gain experience in many areas
cons:
- Company will prevent you from moving into other opportunities, for 90-120 days, if they feel that their client is better served by you remaining in the same position.  

- If the company has too much overhead, they will not win the yearly "Government Re-Compete" which could me you are out of a job within less than 30 days notice.  

- High turnover especially among highly talented individuals looking to go beyond the day-to-day or basic status quo

review_title: Great Company, but the pay could be better.
job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Halifax, NS
pros: The work is fun and fairly interesting.  The managers at the office I am at are friendly and care about the employees.  The product that I am working on is interesting and definitely enjoyable.
cons: The pay could be better and there is little documentation of the code base.  They also take a lot of ideas from smaller companies such as "flex time" and manage to turn them into very corporate policies that don't work all that well.  The amount of paperwork required can hinder an employees productivity, but also is a necessary evil in the defense industry.

review_title: Sr. Software Engineer- Old boys club in Valley Forge, PA
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros: 9/80 schedule and flexibility, cool work, smart people to work with (sometimes),  good pto accruing. Learn new concepts and techniques (sometimes), great place to build a career if you know the right people.
cons: Only path to upward mobility is if you're friends with the managers or they really like you. Qualifications and experience don't matter when promoting from within. Low pay for experienced professionals (about 10%  below market), poor medical benefits, struggling to recruit the right talent for some of the work they're trying to do. They have a long way to go for diversity & inclusion.

review_title: 9/80 work week rocks but stock options would go a long way towards retaining young talent.
job_title: Electronics Engineer Senior in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Lockheed Space Systems has a terrific work-life balance.  Three weeks of vacation is standard for all employees plus holidays. The 9/80 work week is wonderful; you get every other Friday off!
cons: There is a lot bureaucracy that can make getting anything done very difficult.  The publishing of research is discouraged by the legal department.  Promotions hard to earn and based entirely on the employee's age, not skills nor knowlege nor talent. There are many near-retirees in trumped-up roles that contribute little. A lot of great, young engineers start their careers at Lockeed then quickly jump ship when they see miniscule raises and no opportunites.

pros: LM has a good benefits program and also competitive salaries.  There is a broad range of technologies and programs to choose to work on (assuming you can get on that program).  Tthe work they do tends to help in defense of our nation -- so you can be proud of the work you do to help our nation.
cons: Work and home life balance can be a challenge, especially if you are a manager and/or your program is in trouble.  Corporate management can be "relentless" in providing non-value added help when programs are in trouble.

pros: Ok education benefits. High emphasis placed on innovation strategy.
cons: Benefits on the decline from education to healthcare. While there is still alright tuition re-reimbursement program you could be in school forever with the cap per year. When you finish, you owe 12 months. Medical coverage, as with most place is gone up in cost, raises were minimal for 2012 merit. New rating system is horrible and was poorly implemented. No one knew it was coming and no substantial training to prepare. Put in your 20 years and maybe you will be promoted to a lead. Management never seems to have any real working experience for what they are in charge of. More opportunity for lateral transition than up the ranks. Most opportunities for other positions have already been written for a specific individual.

review_title: Great place to start,  but don't stay too long
pros: Average Pay and compensation, not bad for the industry but also not great.  Relatively secure job, you can work here the rest of your career doing the bare minimum.  Work life balance can be good, gets bad once you get more senior.
cons: Pay/compensation isn't related to performance really, only matters a small degree.  The future isn't looking so good for parts of the company.  Company performance is tied to the US Gov't, so it goes up and down on a pretty predictable schedule.  If your a hard worker who really wants to advance your career, you reach your limit pretty much after 5 yrs.  The road to a Director or VP is at least a 20 year commitment.

review_title: Great experience to date at Lockheed Martin
job_title: Software Engineer Asc in Littleton, CO
pros: I love the 9x80 work week, I also have the ability to come in whenever Id like which is really nice. I have a lot of opportunities to travel, which is possible because of Lockheed's large budget and extensive list of business partners. The company really tries to take care of its customers with good health benefits/incentives, discount programs, credit unions, the list goes on. LM is very active in the surrounding communities with volunteering and reaching out to youth.
cons: The yearly LM commit performance reviews are somewhat annoying but it seems like most large companies are doing something similar. With my job, I sometimes have to be on call for emergencies or at times am scheduled to work critical events in the middle of the night.

review_title: Exciting products in the US but UK business in steep decline.
pros: Loyal, hard working colleagues with some of the best minds in the industry. Professional collegiate atmosphere depending on area of the business and programme you are working on. Work / life balance is good with flex-time policies and a culture which acknowledges family commitments and the need to balance.
cons: Company is struggling to remain competitive in a changing market. Transformation programmes are as slow to be implemented as one would expect from a huge Corporation; unfortunately this is translating into short term actions such as cost cutting in training, research & development and benefits. Salaries lag behind competitors and continue to fall in competitiveness.

pros: Senior leadership's vision for the company is one that includes strong leadership and unbiased interactions. Engineering projects are challenging and provide interaction across functions, locations, and customer entities.  Opportunities to move between positions abound, and constant change keeps things new and fresh. Work/Life balance is provided through flex schedules and 9/80 work weeks.
cons: Corporate leadership may be focused on culture changes, but implementation details at the lower levels is lacking. Efforts to please the shareholder often leave the employees disenfranchised.  Generally, pay is average and skill expectations are, too.

pros: Flexible schedule (9/80), some opportunities for growth - especially if you are open to relocation, generally highly ethical environment. Good amenities if you are at HQ locations...concierge, gym, car detailing. Great name recognition.
cons: Bureaucratic, outdated technology-philosophies-methodologies. Not diversity friendly...but think they are - which makes it even more problematic. Mediocre benefits and not so competitive pay...not worth the mental aggravation. So political.

pros: The work is interesting and challenging, and is in a field that I have significant experience in.  Boredom will never be an issue.  Significant opportunities to develop skills in areas that may be unfamiliar.
cons: The pace of the program is intense, and over the time I've been there it's been difficult to maintain a work-life balance.  Much of this is due to ever-shifting requirements from the customer, but is exacerbated by the fact that the technical leadership often doesn't have the domain knowledge to understand what is and is not feasible.  This often results in scrambling to meet deadlines.  Attrition rates for new-hires isn't great, because amidst the chaos there just isn't much opportunity for training and guidance.

review_title: Mixed feelings, review and ratings are only for the Kings Bay, GA location.
job_title: Mult Fnc Info Sys Analyst in Kings Bay, GA
pros: Good pay, if you have good management you can get good raises. If you can get at a good location you can have a great career.
cons: Management is horrible for the most part, this is for the Kings Bay, Ga location. Most have the dog eat dog mentality and are just trying to get to the top, it doesn't matter that they run things into the ground. Lockheed Martin is to big and one hand has no idea what the other hand is doing. I have worked with a number of people that were miserable at this location that took jobs elsewhere within the company and are now very happy.

review_title: Don't work for Space Systems Company
job_title: Senior Staff Systems Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Really good pay and benefits. Flexible work life balance. The senior / director levels really set the tone for a program. As a result, some programs are more fun, easier to handle the challenges then others.
cons: Constant layoffs for last three years. System of layoff includes "bumping" which is laying off people who's jobs still exist because there is another "more qualified" person who can do the job .  Management at Sunnyvale Space Systems is poor. Team work is poor. Laziness is rampant. Team dynamics are poor. Very insular culture.

job_title: Field Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: First, Lockheed Martin is huge. So depending on which business sector or department you end up in will define or shape your opinion. The compensation packages are truly outstanding. My business unit allows us to flex time and/or accumulate time for additional time off. From medical/dental benefits to professional discounts there are plenty of perks available. Tuition assistance is great across the board and if you are furthering your degree or trying to get one this is a great place to do so.
cons: Some of the managers should not be where they are. There seems to be little availability for advancement.

pros:
I worked here for a little over five years. I started with them right out of college. While I learned a lot in these years, lately they are slowing down in business and employee morale is low. 

- Lots of training classes available
- Paid for my education (although I do not believe they do this anymore)
- Lots of work locations
- Some telecommuting options
cons:
By the time I recently left, it was:
- A horrible dog-eat-dog type of environment
- Several layers of managers and people who "think" they're managers that actual managers are afraid to put back in their place
- Budget pressures felt companywide which caused:
 - extremely low morale
 - months of reorganization/ layoff warnings, again
 - managers to tell employees there are no more resources for training or additional opportunities
 - no more than 2% a year raises

pros: Competitive starting salaries, good benefits, interesting and rewarding work. Locations all over the US and world so many opportunities to travel and relocate.
cons:
Dingy cube culture, some leaders are good and others not so much depending on what programs you work on.   Company is in cost cutting mode with due to government budget cuts so you're expected to work on more contracts than you should. The starting salaries are competitive but its hard to advance rapidly.  I've seen employees apply for jobs at a higher level, however they will sometimes keep you at your current level when getting the job, doesn't make sense. 

I will say with such a big company there are different work environments depending on your location and programs you work on.

job_title: Senior Staff Software Engineer in Manassas, VA
pros:
I've been in the industry for a long time and lost my cutting edge skills.  When I went to Lockheed, they gave me a chance to grow new ones.  System Engineering is now a skill this old coder feels confident in.  
The company does really cool stuff.
The developers they hire are top notch.
cons: Too much of a Bid to Win mentality, which puts some employees in the mode of mandatory 60 to 70 hour weeks.  Also, puts mid level people in uncomfortable situations explaining why they are behind on unrealistic schedules.  Note that this is not everywhere.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros: There are plenty of opportunities to move around and grow here. They really invest in their employees career paths if you're wanting to move up. I like the fact that they do reward hard workers. You have to prove your reason for being promoted. Dead weight employees can't stick around very long.
cons: The environment can be very competitive because everyone is trying to make sure they're not in that bottom 10% and in that Exceptional Contributor ranking. You have to prove your reason for being promoted.

review_title: Long hours, interesting work, and fair wages/benefits
pros: Great benefits, flexible hours(as long as you work your full 9 hour shift) Interesting projects, and getting to work with brilliant minds. If you want to work towards a different/better position, they are helpful in that.
cons: If a project hits, with a short deadline, you will be working long hours and weekends. Most projects seem to be this way.... so you end up working over 40 hours weekly. There is a lack of young people, and a lot of policies that make things difficult. Middle management is looking to move up, so often they are looking out for themselves more than those below them.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Manassas, VA
pros: It's great when you're first starting. I've gained a ton of experience and I've enjoyed the people I've worked with.
cons: Lockheed's salary isn't competitive once you've become more experienced. Management values leadership contributions more than technical contributions. I found myself in a situation where in order to grow within Lockheed I needed to do less technical work and more managerial work. The technical path at Lockheed is very narrow because at the end of the day, they rather have a lower level engineer perform a task than a high level engineer. It makes sense from a business and cost management perspective, but it's not good if you want to stay technical.

review_title: Gov't contracting is not the best envirenment for productive SW development.
pros:
Flex hours
Easy work
Never run out of things to do
cons:
Can get boring quick
Once you stop learning their way of doing things you stop learning and become stagnant
Not a great place to work for more that 3 years.
Use 20+ year old out dated technologies simply for the fact of being lazy/not having contract money.
Non rewarding work.
Poorly managed and contract work can just get pulled out from under you, it happens quite often. Working on something for months then you have to full stop on it because there is no money. Then months later you need to ramp back up on it finish it out in an unreasonable time frame.

review_title: The commercials and college recruitment ads are a HOAX!
pros:
Looks good on your resume
Gets your feet wet if you are early in your career
cons:
Promotion from level 1 to level 2 takes like 2 years.  From level 2 to 3 takes like 5 more years.  Then expect no more promotion.
You don't use anything you learned in school.
Same boring mundane tasks.
PAR reviews are a joke.
There is a competition to see who can work the most overtime.
A good-ol-boy military conservative baby-boomers culture that doesn't fit with younger generations.
No excitement in your work.  A monkey can probably do your job.
People don't talk to you.  No social life.

review_title: Good normal job--short hours, decent challenges, work is sometimes interesting
pros:
Working at Lockheed Martin is like having a part-time job, with full-time pay.  I've been there for over 4 years, and have never, ever worked more than 40 hours a week.  As a software engineer, you have enormous discretion over when/where to work.  Since I can get the job done quickly, I probably make it to the office for only 5-6 hours a day.  Combined with the 9/80 schedule, it's like having 3-day weekends all the time.  

The work can be interesting at times, especially since you are working with complex electronic systems.
cons: The technology is older than at most Silicon Valley companies, so don't expect cutting-edge research/development.  Some of the buildings don't have windows, so that sucks too.  Also, most employees are pretty old.

review_title: Not a place to work if you are looking to grow
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Decent benefits
Support for communities of practice to engage in creativity and sharing of ideas
Good HR personnel
Good upper upper management
cons:
Incompetent middle and senior management
Company seeks technicians over engineers
Little room for creativity in software
Failing 20 year old practices
Long term, little chance for growth or advancement (in both career and personally)
Locked into aerospace after too long a time, with great difficulty in transitioning to more "normal" software business companies
Big on talk but little on action.

pros: The smaller LM divisions have a great atmosphere and great leadership. There has been a transition to being compensated for the performance you do and is improving. Most areas offer a flexible work week. Has a great relocation program if it is offered as part of the new position. There are leadership development programs for new employees and tuition assistance programs.
cons: At the bigger LM divisions there is a lot of stovepipes and unwillingness to share information. Some managers are not as willing to offer flex and telecommuting options. Not all managers are supportive of the employee's career decisions.

review_title: Started well, but I would not suggest this place for people who enjoy working in teams without having to watch your back
pros:
When you have a good team & good leadership, it is a great place to work. When the supervisors and team leaders are taking care of their people while getting the job done, goals are accomplished and customers are happy.
Looks good on a resume!
cons: There are a number of people who are very political. Certain people will work to get rid of you if they see you as competition. Long work hours and long rambling meetings reduce the effectiveness of teams

review_title: The working environment at LM is upbeat, where challenges are abound and innovation is encouraged.
job_title: Engineering Planner in Des Plaines, IL
pros: One of the best reasons to work at LM is due to the ethics policies the employees uphold.  The corporate environment of all-inclusiveness and diversity is apparent in the productivity and self-motivation of the employees I've had the privilege to know during my tenure there.
cons: There is a lack of presence in north-western states like Illinois (particularly in Chicago).  As an internationally-known government contractor, LM does not seem to offer locality a broad portfolio of states or large cities having a wealth of talented, skilled, highly educated workforce.

pros: Awesome place to get your hands dirty with cool work. Plenty of neat projects to work on since there are so many different funded projects. Great partnership with colleges/universities.
cons: Personally, as a software developer, I prefer a more laid back environment and this just isn't where you'll find it. You hit the ground running on projects, have to maintain a dress code, and have plenty of protocol to follow. It's a con, but that's for you to decide how big of a con that is. Also, they unfortunately use a HORRIBLE review system. You're performance isn't ranked objectively, it's only in relation to the others around you - there will always be a top performer and a low performer, no matter how great everyone is doing. See too many people get hurt by this system.

job_title: Lead Integral Tank Sealer in Marietta, GA
pros: Good pay. Decent Benefits. Pension and 401(k). Free Gym open 24/7 on work-site. Friendly and helpful workforce. Good management. Union membership optional but has a strong presence if you need it. Company typically looks out for its own, good place to network. Attendance policy is very lenient. Overtime pays double on Sundays and triple on Holidays.
cons: Work is physically and mentally challenging. Very long and random work hours. Difficult process when dealing with DCMA and Quality. No cafeteria just a vendor (Aramark) and it sucks. Benefits depend on favorable union negotiation outcomes and the union typically badgers the company. Overall not a real challenging job but the long hours make even menial work exhausting. Can't transfer to different location for similar work.

review_title: great working environment, salary could use some work
pros: Almost everyone i work with is very helpful and always have time for question. Meeting are kept at a minimum. It make working a very pleasant experience. No backstabber or glory hog that i have came accross yet. Everyone on the team pull their weight.
cons: manager you get assign under is on another program so peer feedback is the only thing they go on at the end of the year. Rating is on a bell curve so only 30% will get good rating, and the other 70% get told you done a terrible job.

pros:
Potential to work on interesting projects.

Managers seem flexible for systems engineering in letting you do something different if you are unhappy with what you are doing and are interested in something else if there is availability. 

Helpful managers and coworkers
cons:
The company is very cheap towards their employees

The only health benefits are high deductible plans

The pay and benefits are not competitive compared to other large engineering companies

You only get 40 hours of sick days a year. If you go over you owe them 40 hours of unpaid overtime plus the number of hours you go over 40.  ex. 42 hours of sick days = 42 hours of overtime.

They took away their fitness program that assists in paying for your gym membership

They will not pay you more money for getting a Masters Degree once you are there

review_title: Great place to work if you love Space, Aviation, or Military hardware.
job_title: Staff Quality Engineer in Eagan, MN
pros: Great benefits package (especially the 9/80 workweek at many locations, gives you every other Friday off).  Company has a stable backlog of business in many different sectors (mostly defense), which hold up well even in a sagging economy.  They have a very strong focus on ethics and doing the right thing.  There is a great program for new college graduates, or if you've been working a long time, its also a great place if you just want to specialize in a certain discipline.  Lots of emphasis on leadership development also, and lots of great training is encouraged in many different areas.
cons: Since most work is on Government contracts, the work can be highly structured, and there are many procedures to follow.

review_title: What its like to work at LMSSC
pros: The company does have a pretty good benefits package. In addition they allow you to flex your time pretty easily. I think there's a lot more control over the amount of hours you work than most other places.
cons:
Management/HR seems to have a complete inability to recognize employees for exceptional work performance. You must do your time regardless of how well you perform. 
Additionally, LM likes to tout how much training/education they offer but much of it is not really relevant to core engineering skills. If you want be a hardcore design engineer, LM is not the place for you.

review_title: Lockheed Martin - not a Great IT ServicesCompany
pros:
Work environment is good.  
LM recognized as a leader - at least in Aerospace.
LM is very process-oriented.  
LM values a diverse work population.
cons:
My comments only apply to LM IS&GS - not the other three sectors (Aerospace, etc.).  
LM is top-heavy with senior management - from the Director through the Sr. VP levels.
Real bonuses are only paid-out at the Director level and above.  
Sr. Management fails to seriously consider those employees that really know the client.  
They are totally driven by the stock market - to the extent their decisions are not sound based on the given circumstances.

review_title: Excellent company with a lot of stability in a time of uncertainty!
pros: Smaller sites have a lot of advancement opportunities. A lot of training offered for leadership developement. If you perform and give 100% then you will have strong stability and recognition. Been there for 10+ years and overall, outstanding place to work.
cons: Company tends to have a lot of "retired in place" (RIP) employees that the company is afraid to get rid of.  80/20 rule: 20% making things happen and 80% RIP or doing just enough to get by.  Performance system needs some changes, and new healthcare benefits needs improvement.

review_title: Great place right out of college
pros: I was given opportunities right from the start. I had the opportunity to move around to different jobs as well as different work sites. I was even able to travel for training classes and seminars. The benefits are very good when looked at as a whole. I worked with some very talented managers.
cons: The pay was lacking and hours were very long. I worked at the Aeronautics division in Ft. Worth which is a union shop. To say the hourly workers were unmotivated to do anything would be an understatement. Ultimately, that is what drove me away. Being excited to try new ideas and techniques that went to the shop floor and died because no one had any motivation to change because 'ive done this for 20 year, i know what im doing'

pros: Excellent corporate benefits and internal opportunities.  A lot of work put in to give employees tools to succeed.  Corporate volunteerism program.  Valuable training.
cons: If you're on a small contract, potential for conflicts to be very difficult to resolve due to lack of oversight.  Also, such a large company, if you don't look out for your career options and opportunities, you can miss a lot of chances.  Be proactive.  Waiting for contract extensions to know if you'll be employed can be unnerving.

job_title: Applications Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It is a well known, large corporation, with offices all over the country.  Their benefits are average but their stocks are outstanding.  They do have many programs for their employees to better themselves and receive either discounts or reimbursements.  Management is very open and willing to help although they are usually tied down by corporate.
cons: You are a number within the company.  The company is very large and is not in touch with their employees.  When you think of corporate America, this is the best example.  The managers and their managers are tied down by corporate policies and financial restraints.  Over the years I have witnessed first hand, several benefits go to the wayside.  Holiday parties, gym reimbursement, parking/travel reimbursement, and any kind of pension have all been taken away from the division I work for

pros:
Culture of respect for each other
Good work life balance
Most people work hard
cons:
Too many layers of management means that people who know what to fix don't have the power to do so, and people with power to make changes don't understand how work is done day to day.  This creates a disconnect between policy and reality that workers and supervisors try to make the best of.
Recent cost cutting has focused on low-level employee layoffs, which means remaining employees are overworked, but little money was saved.

review_title: Best company I had worked for until the Sikorsky acquisition
pros: I was able to advance and receive merit-based pay increases. I was given wide latitude in decision-making and learned a lot on the job.
cons: It is not the same corporation. They have restructured their portfolio and sold-off their IT company (IS&GS) and all the IT work except for what support their core business: manufacturing of things that fly, float, or explode. The year prior to this they enacted a matrix management organization which was a disaster and hugely expensive to the programs. LM is not the only corporation doing this. The services sector is too competitive and low-margin for these large corporations to survive. Defense materiel is more lucrative to the shareholders.

pros: Lots of opportunities for career, relocation, etc.  The smaller Business Units are much leaner and provide more opportunities because it is an "all hands on deck" type of organization.
cons: Depending on the Business Unit, there are "legacy" leadership who don't necessarily follow the Full Spectrum Leadership Imperatives that are required for everyone.  That is frustrating but the best thing to do is to find your passion in LM and a program you love then dig in and keep the company great.

review_title: Right out of college - great first job
job_title: Software Engineer in King of Prussia, PA
pros:
The team was super supportive when I first came on board. Senior software engineers took their time explaining concepts  (the basics and the mission). Everyone on the team is willing to drop everything and help another team member out. The collaboration is fantastic and everyone is super supportive which is exactly what someone right out of college wants/needs. 
Management is easy to talk to and caters to the employees needs with proper training and guidance.
Benefits are pretty good. Health care plans just recently went up though.
cons:
PTO is limited and may feel pressured to get full 40 hours in when you had a snow storm in the middle of the week still.
Security clearance process is a pain and slow.
Work is sometimes dull - lots of maintenance fixes and not a lot of coding/design implementation at times.

review_title: Lots of opportunity but don't forget about the little guys...
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Springfield, VA
pros: It is relatively easy to transfer within the company and there always seems to be a good number of job opportunities available across the country.  You also get a good sense of strong corporate ethics.
cons: The healthcare plans and benefits in general seem to be on a relative decline over the past couple of years.  The number of choices for healthcare options have been decreased and bonuses seem to be a rarity.  Senior Business Unit Management is prone to making knee-jerk decisions regarding factors that have significant influence over workplace morale (elimination of overtime and casual Fridays).  It can also be difficult to find a sense of identity in such an overwhelmingly large company.

job_title: Software Engineer II in San Diego, CA
pros: There are good people to work with and lots of opportunities for different types of work.  They support furthering your education with tuition reimbursement and even fitness reimbursements for gym memberships up to $250
cons: Contracting with the government all depends on if the government has funding to support your contract so sometimes a project that you worked hard on is just gone all of a sudden because there is not financial support anymore.  It's easy to get lost in the crowd and even though you work hard you may not always get recognized for it.

review_title: Almost like working for the government...lots of minutia!!
pros: It is an okay place to work when times are good. However, the site I worked at tended to over staff to make "sales". Though when the did this they would overrun the contract and would have to make mass cuts...usually around Christmas, nice huh???
cons: When cuts in personnel come they usually are followed by the hiring of additional managers. "Hey we can't afford you anymore, but we are going to bring someone in at double your salary to sit at there desk and send out vague emails".

review_title: Large corporation doing cool things...budgets always a concern
pros: As a whole, the corporation is on the cutting edge of technology and it feels good to know you are contributing to innovation and the protection of our country.  There are opportunities for those who are developing a career to do so, and internal networking as well.  Many of the first line leaders are wonderful managers and leaders who care about the mission and the people.
cons: In a company so large there is a lot of redundancy and jockeying for attention and budget, which sometimes can take away from the mission that is being conducted for the customer.  With so many layers of management, different styles and strategies throughout the corporation, not everyone is marching to the same beat all the time.  Constant concern and flux in the defense industry makes the environment unstable.

review_title: Great salary and benefits, good ethics, but oh, that defense part ...
job_title: Systems Integration Business Analyst, Senior Staff in Mims, FL
pros: Can't complain about pay and benefits - company did me right here.  Also came along pretty well when it comes to diversity - proud that my company achieved a perfect score on the Corporate Equality Index, and changed its executive leadership from what used to be known as "The Five White Guys" to women, minorities, and even a member of the LGBT community!
cons: Only downside is the mixed emotions I had working for the world's largest defense contractor.  Granted, the company is trying to diversify and become more of a systems integration company, but there is no avoiding the still large defense contingent.

job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Eagan, MN
pros: They paid me more than any other software internship in the twin cities would. I learned I never want to work in the defense industry.
cons: I worked most of the time in KShell(80s technology) on software that had been written in the 90s and abandoned. They never implemented anything I made, so the internship was basically a joke.  The environment is very gray and when you look at the corporate hierarchy you realize it's 9+ levels of management that don't do anything but come by once a month to recite platitudes and corporate propaganda. Most of the people here sit on six figures while the air traffic control software hasn't changed much in decades. Don't go here if you want a modern software environment to build useful relevant skills for the 21st century.

review_title: Lockheed Martin is a good company because of its people and its mission
pros: The people are the best thing about this organization, some of the nicest you will ever meet. You'll especially like it if you have conservative values and if you like to have a career that is essential to national security and defense. More young people are being attracted to the company as many of the older employees are retiring.
cons: There is more separation between management and employees than other companies I have worked at and the workload can be heavy in certain areas with employees taking work home to get it done. Some of this is due to budget cuts and lost contracts.

review_title: Great company but carries some baggage with it.
job_title: Systems Engineer Senior Staff in Uniondale, NY
pros: It's a company with a great reputation in the defense/aerospace industry, and a long history of innovation and invention.  The pay and benefits are centerline, but management does have ability to reward performers with incentive payments, raises (past 3 years raises total 30% of salary 3 years ago) and other awards.
cons: Long hours, the "get it done mentality" and the "we will deliver" mantra, no matter what the costs or problems.

review_title: Educated young aspiring professionals should look elsewhere.
pros: Salary and benifits package are on par with other large companies. Job duties are relatively easy although very small in scope and repetative.
cons:
EBS Management has no desire to see employees grow in their careers.
Job duties do not provide good work experience and are very repetative clerical accounting work.
Promotions are insignificant to non-existent depending on who your manager is. 
Flexible work schedule is based on what your manager agees with. 
Good performers seem to be punished with more work and poor performers are looked at as hard workers because of the excess time it takes to complete tasks.
The key to success isn't hard work but rather long hours.

review_title: Great experience wit high profile projects
pros:
Great experience for fresh out college students  gain alot of variety of experience first leve management rotates employee to new projects aproximately once a year.

Projects are given  recognizition
cons:
Employees are evaluated "ranked" for salary increases against others with more experience employee. Employees do not share vital information voluntary. Employees keep critical information to themselves apparently to shore up their job security - to be seen as Subject Matter Experts (SME)
by Management. Management gives the subtile message that if you are not viewed as a SME, you 
will not be be given favorable reviews/raises. Employees are given little or no training.

review_title: Aircraft assembly is challenging yet rewarding, also gainful knowledge for future experiences.
pros: Decent pay, awesome benefits, interesting work environment.
cons: Starting pay for A&P's is low although, a new hire with very minimal aircraft experience and no A&P, can exceed your starting pay while you achieve Lockheed experience. New employees with minimal experience from other companies, should never pass the pay rate of an employee who has years of  Lockheed experience. Especially when the previous experience was only two years, and you have achieved three years Lockheed experience and make less!

review_title: Tired of the good old boys way of doing things... Manassas Site (MS2)
pros:
If you are "one of the boys" you should do well.
You get to work on pretty neat things.
Salaries are OK, not super competitive--you are compared to your peers within your rank, most times this works out OK.
cons:
You will be passed over for promotion if you are not one of the "good old boys".
There are lots of actively operating quid pro quo relationships.
People are rewarded for kissing up and personal relationships.
They do not have a reliable HR that cares about what is reported to them--they often turn the other cheek.
Mid-level management runs that place, regardless of what the upper level management thinks or what their mission statements are.
Mid-level management routinely encourages unethical practices, esp wrt charging time to government contracts.

job_title: Test Engineer Senior in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
-big company with better job security than startups
-benefits are competitive
-extremely hard to get fired (or recognized!)
cons:
-extremely hard to get fired (or recognized)
-large gap in pay between many employees performing the exact same jobs. I saw employees in basically the same position make 1/3 the amount of a direct peer. They may have a different title, but the job responsibilities day-to day are the same. 
-difficulty securing promotions if employees in a location other than Denver. Promotions beyond 3 to 5 years of employment are near impossible right now. 
-very negative work attitude among a majority of employees (even the good ones).

review_title: work everybody mandatory unpaid overtime for over 6 months then lay them all off!
pros: you get to say you work on some cool projects
cons:
In the past 4 years the senior management has removed countless benefits from employees. 

It started with removal of the coffee, tea and water "because its not in our budget" even though other remote sites still have this benefit. 

Immediately after this obscene move they stopped paying any employees for overtime "without VP approval" i.e. nobody gets paid overtime. 

Tthen they stopped allowing employees to book comp time.

Tthen they removed hundreds of hours worth of personal business/sick time. 

here we are today with mandatory unpaid overtime (working minimum 10 hours for FREE) and our treat at the end will be another massive lay off just like they did to the Structures team last year. 

Sadly this remote site is being ran into the ground by decisions made from managers that aren't even located in Houston.

review_title: Great place to start a career
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Reston, VA
pros: The best reasons would be the career mobility, being able to work in many industries within the same company and being able to work all over the country/world. The pay and benefits are reasonably good. I am happy with my level of responsibility and rate of promotion.
cons: The upper management is very very removed from the "worker bees". There are many layers of management and it is possible to get lost in the crowd. Your direct manager makes a big difference in the quality of job you end up with. If they are stickler for all of the corporate policies the job might become unbearable. I am in the fortunate position to have a manager that understands how important the people are.

review_title: Good place to work, Great place to stay.
job_title: Systems Engineering Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great products that support our country.  Overall it is a fairly secure place to work, although one where it is easy to get complacent.  It seems that in the past 5-6 years, there has been a noticeable change in atmosphere and past "silo" type mentalities are slowly being broken down.  The technologies are impressive, and fun to work with.  The people are good, with a lot of former military, and there is a great sense of duty and responsibility that permeates all levels of the company.
cons: Promotion process is rather "by the book" and there is not much working with that.  Exceptional talent will have to perform first, and then be rewarded.

review_title: Lots of opportunities, lots of politics.
pros: Lockheed has a lot of different places they operate from, and hundreds of different jobs in any given field. They make it very easy to move around within the company, so you dont need to feel like you are trapped in just 1 job. Also, having a security clearence makes it easier to get a job within the company, as well as similar companies if you decide lockheed isnt for you.
cons: Working with a security clearence, there is the extra stress of dealing with security procedures, and you can not come home and tell the family what you did at work that day. Getting changes made to policies is a big complicated deal, typical to large companies. Lots of politics to deal with.

review_title: Could be better, could be worse
pros: I've worked from home for the past 10+ years.  We do some cool things that help protect America and her allies.
cons: Management turnover due to job rotations create a ton of re-work for the program managers who have to continuously sell their programs to the "manager de jour".  Also, if you're not a graduate of their coveted Information Systems Leadership Development Program (ISLDP), your name will never be discussed for manager positions if you're in IT and work for their corporate division.  For new hires, make sure you ask about this.  You'll be glad you did, even if you don't want to be a manager one day.

job_title: Senior Project Engineer in Moorestown, NJ
pros:
The feeling you get knowing that the work performed is making a difference in keeping our military safe while protecting our country.

The ability to work on many diverse programs and projects and the opportunity to move from group to group fairly easily.
cons:
Company is so large that the lower echelon workers feel more like a number than a face.

Very few opportunities to promote from within. I knew many people that are still only level 2s or 3s after 20 - 30 years of service.

job_title: Program Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Lockheed Martin has to be the top defense contractor to work for in the country.  They establish the baselines which all others follow from Capture Management, Program Management, Engineering practices, to the finance world.  I will say the thing that most impressed me is the opportunitee to learn and be mentored by quality people.  I would have never left had it not been for a family situation.
cons: At some of the customer sites, the working conditions are not ideal.  The company also tends to be quite conservative on the business development side.

job_title: Systems Administrator Staff in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Really enjoyed working with the non-management staff many of whom had been there for many years.  Split work week, nine hour days, so you always have every other Friday off.  Work from home is super easy and just as connected to the folks in the office.  Great relationship with key vendors.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy on documentation.  Simple IT change management approval can take up-to a month.  The five bosses rarely got along or agreed on priorities for employees (multiple direct line managers isn't the norm at every location).  When reporting on successful tasks completed for boss A it wasn't uncommon to have boss C yelling belittling remarks just to appear better than A.

review_title: Great company, great benefits, middle management is less than stellar in some places.
pros: Large company with numerous perks and benefits. Work can be interesting and challenging depending on your business area. Education reimbursement is offered and encouraged.
cons: As with any large enterprise not all places of a company are as good to work at as others. I have seen facilities with great management and cohesive environments, on the other side of the coin though those places with bad management can be very difficult to work effectively.

review_title: Didn't realize what I was missing until I left!
pros: Mostly great people, smart, sharp, talented, hard working. The business itself is exciting and you have a lot of pride being associated with a company like this. Reputation is fantastic and what this company does is cutting edge and trend setting.
cons: There's definitely a good old boy network, where friends look out for friends. Management believes the first thing they hear about an employee, right or wrong. The employee performance management system is flawed and unethical: management must rate their team in order of value and importance and it's all dependent on what the manager (or the managers manager) thinks of the employee. People are kept around because of who they know, not what they know.

pros: Some good projects. If you can learn on the job, that is all you get.
cons: Need treat employees better, benefits not better they "peers," lies when saying it cost the same. Saying no peer employer has it is another lie. News says company's giving unlimited maternity leave, we get 2. SLT keeps get more, we get less. Training is not helping you keep your skills up to date, only training provided is how to do your time, how to treat fellow employees. These are lies about training that every employee get 40 hours of training every year. Will pay for master college courses but not undergrad or electrical standard changes.

pros: Rewarding work to provide the BEST for our military men and women, involvement with State-of-the-Art technologies in the aviation, space, above and under the sea Battle space. You can't beat that experience.  Great retirement plans if you want to work toward that goal.  Upward mobility comes but initially you have to acclimate, learn the LM culture, and project a upbeat, engaging professional spirit and willingness to team with others for mission success.
cons: Physical working environment is nothing to crow about.  Sometimes, getting identified for the rewarding jobs takes a bit longer.

pros: Most teams are very involved and have good leadership.  Work is very consistent since they have both new programs and sustainment work depending on which program you work in.  They have some of the best benefits including employer matching for 401K.  Very good at the work life balance since they have flex time.
cons:
I feel like the design software used here is about 15-20 years outdated.  Drawings should be in 3D more like what I learned in college 13 years ago.
FML should be extended for new parents.

pros: Lots of learning opportunities in may but not all roles.  Incredibly high ethical culture and you get to work with some of the smartest people in the world.
cons: Significant lack of racial diversity in some of the higher level roles. Typical large company issues that you will face anywhere. Things can move slowly sometimes because of the bureaucracy and "old school" leftover leaders who haven't been forced to retire yet.  There always seem to be a reorganization so you need to be comfortable with names changing on the front of offices faster than you can keep track.

pros:
Great people to work with
Unionized
cons:
Oh boy...
Insurance deductibles that start off at 5% of your annual gross salary
Extremely low wages compared to the rest of the industry
Management has a very "shoot first, ask questions later" attitude about discipline
Shift to shift dynamics are toxic at best and completely dysfunctional at worst
We don't get Veteran's Day off despite all our work going towards "bringing the warfighter home"
They won't even give us refrigerators in the break rooms to keep our food fresh
Mold in the ceiling tiles
Non-remediated lead dust and fumes
Dangerous chemicals
Roaches in the break rooms and bathrooms
Little to no room to move up within the company, most management and engineering is hired from outside sources
The company values sound great on paper, but unfortunately most of the people working there have let those values fall by the wayside in favor of cutting one another's throats in an effort to gain favor from the higher-ups.

review_title: Cool place to work most times..
pros: Flexible Work schedule and some real good people.  A pension plan is availble for some, but as of 2007 it was dropped.  There is some job security and you work on some interesting projects.
cons: There is a buddy system with the old timers.  Promotions are rather hard to come by.  Profit sharing doesn't exist, company seems to care too much for stockholders and director/VP bonus's.  Company braggs about record or good profits, but it is never passed to the employees.  Raises are usually bad, unless your manager goes to bat for you. Too many paper pushers, you would think we were a scheduling and management company rather that at aerospace company.

review_title: A good place to start, not a good place to stay
job_title: Software Engineer Associate in Reston, VA
pros: Lockheed Martin is perhaps the best place to get your foot in the door in the Government Contracting sector. At my site, management is flexible about how I put in my hours on any given week.
cons: Lockheed Martin has some of the lowest pay in the sector, and the raises do not keep up with inflation. Regardless of your current responsibilities, they will not consider you for promotion until you meet the years of experience required for that position. It is difficult to grow technically here, as money for training and tuition reimbursement is carefully restricted.

review_title: Awesome company as long as you can follow guidelines/procedures.
job_title: Financial Analyst in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: There are a lot of opportunities for growth.  They pay for grad school, textbooks, fees & gym memberships.  I very much enjoy the flex time because I like to sleep in late.  There's a very friendly atmosphere and relaxed dress code.  Also, managers respect their employees and listen well anytime their employees have anything to say.
cons: Overtime basically expected.  As a contractor, if something goes wrong, it's always our fault.  We need to always follow guidelines to make sure we can't be blamed for anything.  Because of this, there are a lot of processes and rules.

review_title: Good opportunities, but hard to get hired
pros: Lockheed is a large company. You meet a lot of interesting people, the work always varies, and it's hard to get bored.
cons: As a subcontractor, it is hard to get hired full time, despite the fact you are told management would like to hire you. Lots of overtime sometimes, and you also get let go if there isn't enough work to do. They will bring you back if they like you, however. Also if you are a subcontractor, you don't receive any of the benefits, and sometimes people treat you differently. There are also a lot of politics in the office and different departments.

review_title: It depends on what you are looking for in a job which will determine whether you will enjoy working for Lockheed Martin.
pros:
Lockheed Martin provides opportunity to learn, but you must be EXTREMELY proactive about advancing your career.  The 9/80 work schedule (every other Friday off) is great.  Lockheed Martin has some very brilliant people working there so you have many resources and everyone is willing to share the knowledge.
Management seems pretty open to letting you direct your career.
cons: Programs are very very long term.  They move slowly since it is such a large corporation.  If you are young and looking for excitement and fast paced work activities, this is not the place to be.

review_title: I was a Technical Writer/Editor III for Lockheed Martin from March 2000 to November 15, 2013.
job_title: Technical Writer/Editor III in Manassas, VA
pros: Very good company to work for. Good location.
cons: I didn't expect to be laid off after almost 14 years with the company but there were layoffs due to decreased government funding.

review_title: Left due to frustration with management
job_title: Senior Staff Hardware Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Usually had interesting work, good salary, and good raises. Most people are pleasant to work with.
cons: Management often clueless. Division I was in was formerly part of Loral, and before that Ford Aerospace, and was bought by Lockheed in 1995. We had a long history of successfully supporting our customers. Management didn't understand our customers or our customers' needs. Ran projects by mindlessly following company processes. Many people just coasting out of frustration.

review_title: Good Company, Creative and smart people, but too many layers if management
pros: Benefits have been great but are becoming less and less. Great place for young engineers to get in on the innovative technologies being developed.
cons: Too many layers of management not to mention the lack of quality lower level managers. The annual review process is so inadequate and unfair - Annual wage increases are measured by a rating system (you against 250 people at the same level). Try to find anyone who thinks it's an honest assessment and fair process.

pros: Very large Company. Seemed like a company who valued its employees and would take care of them in the long run.
cons: Wrong people were put in charge at VP level with little to no experience in the Service's Line of Business. Laid off valued employees based their higher salary and whether or not you were charging overhead dollars vs. direct charge to Govt. Never took into consideration your benefit to the organization, loyalty, dedication to the Company, nor length of service. Finally got their act together and fired incompetent management, but too late and had to lay off more personnel. Cut major health benefits and 401k opportunities. Currently In process of selling off Line of Business.

pros: Good benefits, competitive compensation, good teamwork. Good training opportunities at the corporate level.
cons: New to the company on large contract; no training provided. Extremely difficult to meet contract performance metrics on large programs - company bid low and over-sold operationally in proposals. Employees were overworked and stressed out working in chaotic environments. Senior management expected employees to perform and metrics to be met, regardless; they didn't feel the pain of the employees on the ground. It's not surprising the division was sold.

review_title: Good company to start your career with
pros: Excellent benefits, great pay, good tuition reimbursement, and you have off every other Friday.  There is always plenty of work, therefore you will stay busy.
cons: No big complaints, other than the no brainer: make sure to take advantage of any career opportunities (training, position openings, etc), but also make sure to "play your hand close to the vest."  Some managers get upset if you look outside of your current role or have an overall goal that does not involve your current position.  Lockheed is a big company with plenty of opportunities and very successful employees, so I suggest getting a trusted mentor to help out.

review_title: Good place to start and gain experience, easy to move around
pros: Good 401k match, 10 holidays (4 of them floating holidays), job security (management works with you to move you to a new contract if needed), ability to move to different contracts voluntarily and gain experience (at least if you're a developer), nice coworkers
cons: Expensive yet sub-par health insurance, vacation is only 2 weeks a year which is below the industry standard (they cut down on benefits, it used to be 3 weeks a little before I joined), salary is kind of low for the DC metro area (but pays better than the federal government), annual raises are not good, if you "exceed" your commitments for the year as a developer, you get 2.9%...

pros:
Meaningful and interesting projects

Work/Life Balance

Active efforts to promote Vets and Diversity
cons:
Outdated processes and procedures which need to be be streamlined to be able to remain competitive with young innovative companies on the rise.  Unnecessary processes ramp up development and production costs, which was fine when defense had unlimited budgets, but management refuse to change ways since that is all they have known for past 30 years.

Terrible benefits which CEO has slowly traded off in return for keeping shareholders happy at the expense of employees, hence CEO of the year.

job_title: Software Engineer Senior in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Health benefits, average pay.  There is a fair respect for employees flexing their time, but some government contracts require overtime (non-paid).  Most Lockheed sites are very nice, but I work at an Air Force base.  Our accomodations are falling apart - but Lockheed save money on our overhead.
cons: The managers have not succeeded in normal worker communications.  Most are very transparent when it suits them.  After 35 years I'm finally getting fed up.  (35 years - I'm an idiot)  At appraisal time, the same average rating is given time and again.

review_title: Company of great stability.  Can be political at times.
pros: It's internationally recognized as a technologically advanced company.  There's a huge variety of work available within the company that make changing jobs without changing company easy.   It pays tremendous attention to work-life balance and promote an inclusive work environment.  There's vast resources within the company, both people and facilities.
cons: Organization and management not streamlined and efficient.  Often there are many layers of management.  While each layer needs to justfiy their existence, it often burdens the working level to support their request for information and hinders real work progress.  Often find people who are unwilling to accept new responsibilities and stay passive in work attitude.  No intiative.

review_title: I really wanted to love this place but policies that promote mediocre work kill it.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
There are opportunities to work on some awesome missions. 
Work/life balance is great for many positions. 
9/80 work week, get every other Friday off!
cons:
Company policies affecting performance reviews, merit increases, promotions, and compensation remove all incentive to excel and try to move up quickly. High performers aren't really differentiated from average performers. 
It takes forever to move up - every coworker, high contributors included, has been promoted years after it was deserved due to HR policies. Your title doesn't reflect your actual level of competency or responsibility. 
Engineering salaries are lower than SF Bay Area averages, and almost no one receives profit sharing. 
Lots of ancient technologies & policies everywhere. 
Multi-disciplinary technical teams often require software engineers to come in at unnecessarily early hours.

review_title: It's not What you Can Offer, it's Who You Know -
pros: Large enough to offer a variety of career paths. Competitive salaries and benefits.
cons: Growing your career depends on Who you Know, not What you Can Offer. I had the misfortune of working at an LM support office for an AFB in Illinois; there was a Triad of Power that 'ran things'. My supervisor was remote - located on the east coast - and when I reported the difficulties I encountered, he CONFIRMED them. His response was "most of Lockheed isn't like this". So, if you're considering a position with LM, check the specifics Thoroughly. BE CAREFUL OF WHAT YOU STEP IN; YOU MAY BE SCRAPING IT OFF YOUR SHOE FOR QUITE SOME TIME.

review_title: Great Place to Work with Strong Values
pros: I worked for Lockheed Martin for over 10 years.  It was a great experience - learned a lot from some of the most talented people in the business.  They had a very strong ethics program which set them apart from competitors and strong leadership.  Really good work/life balance and salaries were generous.
cons: Since it is such a large company, their overhead budgets (anything not charged directly to a contract) are fairly limited, but I think it keeps costs down so that new opportunities can be won.  The facility I where I worked had a training center that allowed the workforce to take classes on their own time, so that was a benefit.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I have previously worked for LM a total of 10 years and at 3 different locations. Each time, I liked the people, the work environment, and the company mission. LM does a nice job trying to insure their employees are comfortable and well trained. Depending on your division and position, the hours are flexible. The last division I worked for had 9/80 work weeks. It is like getting a long weekend every other week.
cons: The downside is you are working in an industry (defense) that is subject to lots of layoffs and uncertainty. During layoff times and plant closings, the mood of employees is sour. Even so, most people still tend to try to do the best they can for they dying position. Pay could be better.

pros: Just a few things unfortunately, First pay is great for the work that we do. Second, coworkers are friendly and very supportive. Hours can be flexible but you have to make your case for why you need the hours that you want. Employee discount program is a huge plus, as well as amazing Vision and Dental plans.
cons: Management lacks skill and professionalism. The office politics between all supervisors will help or hurt your career. Don't bother with complaints of any manor because they just use the circular filing bin for them.  Health benefits are a joke.

review_title: Not the company it once was
pros:
There is some level of prestige working for the largest defense contractor in the world. 
Opportunities in many locations allows geographical movement and advancement
cons:
LM has become too PC. There are support groups for every possible workgroup. It seems that some of the younger employees contribute little to the end product but much of their time planning events.
In spite of record stock price and earnings, they are nickel and diming employees on benefits, salaries and raises.

pros: Reasonable stability. Lockheed Martin has had this current contract for over 13 years. There is some flexibility in the work hours. As long as you hit your 40 hours per week you're ok. There are a lot of pretty smart people working here, so the ability to pick up additional knowledge is available.
cons: Very political. Poor communication. The thought that because they have a "plan" for communication, they're actually communicating. Too many obstacles to getting the job done. The idea that the employees are simply plug-and-play commodities. There is no thought to growing their employees. They simply hire someone to fulfull a need, rather than provide training and opportunity to their existing employees. Tuition reimbursement is a joke.

review_title: Not a company I respect or am proud to work for
pros: It's hard to get fired unless you violate security procedures or there is a reduction in workforce.
cons: Much bureacracy and red tape, innovation is stifled.  Major salary compression, lousy annual raises.  Too many processes, things that make total business sense aren't done and fighting for change is rarely successful.  Many bad middle managers.  Pervasive culture of not valuing their employees, this manifests itself in many ways.

pros:
Hardcore engineers will get their fix
Good compensation package
You work among very smart engineers
Pretty nice perks, like every other Friday off, plant shuts down for 1 1/2 weeks around holiday season (schedule may vary among facilities)
cons:
Working there is just a drab. Dull and old facilities, little motivation to succeed (other than the pride of an engineer solving a problem.)
My site is a small one (<1000 employees, including factory operators) so we felt like a family, which was nice, but from what I hear it is not like that at all- brown nose, dog eat dog to get to management level

review_title: Opportunity to learn and grow with the company.
job_title: Senior Aircraft Maint/Mod Planner in Greenville, SC
pros: An opportunity to learn and grow with this dynamic company and I worked in a team environment.
cons: The facility was very old at the Donaldson Center in Greenville, SC and was in dire need of upgrades to some of the buildings that were built over old (non-operational) underground military bunkers that were infested with roaches and rodents which came into the hangars and buildings daily at an alarming numbers and can be a health hazard for the employees as well as the on-going mold problems in the air duct systems in some of the office areas (in particular, Hangar 4) this caused respiratory issues and/or cold like symptoms for fellow employees.

review_title: You are nothing but a number to the bottom line
pros: Large company where management likes to delegate down management so it makes it easier to hide in the crowd if you don't do your work, or if you are aspiring management without skills you will likely get promoted for pretty charts and delegating your work to others.
cons: Stress, Lack of trust, poor management, pay, lack of opportunity, ability to show how you outperform people in your line of work at higher levels and you still get poor reviews because the company is still attempting to implement a review system that is fair. You are treated like a second rate person if you are not an engineer. I am still unsure why I have more managers than I can count on all my fingers.

pros: Big company. Decent benefits.  Local management will look out for you as best they can.  Most people are friendly.  Networking opportunities if you're in to that.
