cons: Its government contracting.  Basically contracts come and go. Lockheed bids on government contracts and either wins over or loses out to competition. Contracts usually last a few years.  Budgets fluctuate, political situations and relationships crop up, etc.  In ~4 years, I jumped between 8 different EPA programs in order to keep busy.  The local office was in decline.  Lay offs will happen.  You must also keep track of all your time across all contracts which can get annoying and is subject to being audited internally as we as by government reps.

job_title: Technical Trainer Senior in Fort Eustis, VA
pros: Company has great benefits. My supervisor was very supportive with assisting me with my customer. I worked for Lock heed Martin as a contractor so I went through alot of corporate training which was very imformative and beneficial. They have a great corporate culture and promote from within. Most of the top executives have been long term employees.
cons: Being in a contract position my position was always in jeopardy of being eliminated which happened in my case. They have an inhouse referral program, however most project managers do not crosstalk well and are not willing to hire employees from other projects.

review_title: Good work life balance but poor management that don't properly reward technical expertise.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Good work-life balance and good benefits! A lot of smart individuals and good people.
cons: Poor management. It is too easy to become a manager but very hard to grow in the technical path. Stay away if you don't like brown-nosing but if you like easy brainless work just come to work on time and pretend you work hard as long as you answer all your emails and go to all the meetings.

review_title: Great job security, limited job growth
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Littleton, CO
pros: Great job security, especially if you have a clearance.  I started my career with Lockheed and I'm glad that I did.  The engineering  is rigid and process driven, but that can be beneficial in some ways when you're a young engineer
cons: Engineering environment is incredibly stale.  If you work classified programs then expect to work with old technology or build everything in-house.  Any software libraries you want to use have to vetted by the security team (takes months or years).  The longer you're in defense contracting, the more valuable you are to defense, but you become useless anywhere else because your skills and tech familiarity will slowly degrade.  They rarely fire people, so find plenty of underachievers that are just productive enough to keep their job.

pros: Lockheed is full of smart people who have pride in the corporation and work hard. Some locations are better than others (Palmdale, CA is horrible), but the engineers, management, and support staff on the east coast and northern California were wonderful to work with and for.
cons: Some of the more industrial locations (Palmdale, CA) had a lot of unhappy workers that were resistant to change. Also, because it is such a large corporation, advancement and standing out can be challenging.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Indianapolis, IN
pros: No work to take home. After 8.5 hrs you can leave it all there.
cons:
The position is a secretary and has little to do with the actual mortgage. Mostly taking complaints and getting complained on because you don't help. However, you are there to take complaints (not help) and phone messages for HUD. You will also handle calls for most parts of HUD that having nothing to do with the position you are hired for and when you cannot find the person or have any knowledge of what to do with caller, management (Lockheed) will give you a poor performance review.
Dead-end position if you want to move up. Don't waste time unless you really need a job. The stress is bad. Compensation starts at $17/hr.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Competitive pay and benefits,  Good work life balance, depending on your manager.  Lots of paid exercise because the work areas are so far apart and far away from the parking areas.
cons: Poor leadership.  The facilities are dirty and in poor repair outside of the production areas.  Evidence of rats and cockroaches can be seen throughout the campus.  It feels more like a military base, (sterile), but without the cleanliness you would find around the military.

review_title: You can do better in the Silicon Valley
pros: Interesting programs and projects, great management, coworkers, and customers. Plenty of opportunities for career growth. Great place for a young engineer to gain experience. Good work/life balance with the 9/80 schedule.
cons: LM's engineer salaries in Sunnyvale are low compared to other Silicon Valley employers. Health and other benefits getting weaker and weaker every year. The company's longterm strategy appears to be to close Sunnyvale facilities in favor of moving business to Colorado.

review_title: Decent place and interesting tech but you find growth in out of state
pros: It's a decent place to learn about engineering for space. Working at a large company, you can find and network in order for you to grow and maintain job stability. A really great work life balance with a 9/80 work schedule.
cons: There are many problems with adopting new technology as they are stuck in the past. Certain process and procedures maybe overkill as it hinders your ability to get the job done. If you want to learn or be on more interesting projects, you will have to look at the Denver facility. Pay is much lower than average for silicon valley.

review_title: College Student Technical Specialist Internship - MFC
job_title: College Student Tech Spec in Orlando, FL
pros: The MFC site in Orlando was close to the perfect experience (minus the crazy rain!)!! I was afforded the opportunity to push myself as hard as I wanted. I was given guidance throughout my entire internship but enough freedom to test my creativity and knowledge. My project had me work mostly with cad models designing things.
cons: None, potentially extending the hours of the cafeterias by a little bit

pros: Great work life balance: flex 9x80 schedule provides every other Friday off and company provides 12 paid holidays; benefits have decreased in the last year but overall I think its still a decent package
cons: Expectation that you will move to achieve higher leadership positions (or wait several years to (maybe) get them without moving); very good focus on 0-5 year employees, providing opportunities to advance but not very good at higher levels (you must find your own opportunities and leadership is not shaping opportunities for you based on your skills and strengths); integration of several businesses over the last few years has been challenging on the teams

job_title: Electro-Optical Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Wide variety of projects to work on ranging from space based platforms to UAV to ground-based.  If you're technically creative there's research money available to get new ideas off the ground.  There is no sense of intellectual protectionism, and full credit is given to employees whose ideas are successful.  It's easy to move up in the organization if one is willing to take on additional responsibility.
cons: Because we work on hardware that is launched into space and cannot be easily serviced, the corporation is extremely conservative in systems design, meaning it's difficult to inject new and interesting technology, and we're frequently weighted down by over-bearing paperwork and process to ensure 1000% mission success.

pros:
It's a good place to start your career.
Good reputation company to work for.

It's sad but I don't have any good words to say about this company..
cons:
Company focus too much on leadership and less on technical excellence.  
Company needs to invest on employees by providing professional/industry training to prepare us toward the future.
Moving around the company can be very difficult.
Technical training in the company is very limited or doesn't even exist (varies with program)*
Receiving a promotion in the company can be very difficult and political.  
I learned most of skills by myself and very little from technical leaders.

pros:
Compensation was great
Upper Management was extremely professional and friendly.
Hours : My hours were extremely flexible and my subordinates were able to change their schedules to fit their needs
cons:
Benefits came out of your pay while still being called benefits
Promoting from within is not their strong suit. I was lucky enough to receive a promotion but they usually hire outside for positions. 
Contracts are unstable mine was canceled after 2 years though it was for 5.

review_title: Great company but bad local decisions at times
job_title: Program Management Senior Manager in Washington, DC
pros:
- Large company with vast resources
- Good benefits
- Lots of job opportunities
cons: - On two occasions they brought in a "rainmaker" who proceeded to run the (very large) program into the ground and we lost the re-compete(s). Also, people who were formerly highly rated suddenly became rated low. I left the program I was on the first time it happened, and the company itself the second time. The first time I got out ahead of any negative impacts. The second time I tried gutting it out and went from having the highest or second highest rating for 11 straight years to the lowest possible rating before I finally left.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Lockheed Martin is involved in some of the most interesting projects in the world.  There are countless opportunities to explore new career goals and grow as a professional.  Many of the jobs are very rewarding, and play a crucial role in the stability of the U.S. and its allies.
cons: With the predominant customer being the government, the business tempo is erratic on many programs.  Many projects operate on long term visions, but short term planning.  The volatility both internal, and with the customer, lead to aggressive response times, and teams being ill-prepared to tackle challenges.

job_title: Subcontract Administrator Senior in Fort Worth, TX
pros: As long as programs are funded it is a very secure job.  Large company, decent benefits from day 1. Vested from day 1.
cons:
METRICS, METRICS, METRICS....  Refusal to carry inventory leads to shortages 
OMG the parking situation is dire....  1/2 mile walk from the car to my cubicle...  The cubicle that I share w/2 other people...  in an open room with hundreds of cubicles... hundreds of people...

job_title: Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: higher than average pay, more stable than most commercial engineering outfits, wide variety of products/projects to work on if you're flexible. Depending on job/area/management relaxed dress code.
cons: Too many directors and VP's, there seems to be a VP for just about everything. HR has way too much power and no technical background making their judgement of promotions/hiring/growth relegated to excel spreadsheets. Benefits are pathetic but company says they are "industry standard". Coorporate says they are "going to change culture" for the last 5 years but have never actually taken steps to implement a change, corporate culture is from late 80's.

pros:
-Great support structure, typically people would drop what they were doing if you needed help
-Progressive employer, LGBT friendly and equal opportunity, culture of acceptance
-Very kind, understanding management
-Flexible hours
cons:
-Knowledge concentration is a problem. Often there would only be one person who knew how to solve certain problem, if they were unavailable there would be trouble. As far as I could tell there was not much being done to change this.
-Software being worked on is old and obscure. Very little documentation is available, and the enormous and out of control codebase can be a nightmare to debug. The supporting software is also older than dirt and agony to use.

review_title: Good company for a certain type of person
pros:
Generally very good work-life balance for finance employees (trade-off is low pay, of course)
Pretty good benefits
In hindsight, very low-stress environment
401(k) match is/was pretty generous
Not asked to do a whole lot, except during proposals or other special projects
cons:
Not asked to do a whole lot, except during proposals or other special projects
To all those young people: most of your co-workers will be noticeably..... more experienced in the workplace, so don't expect an exciting work environment with lunches, happy hours, social activities, etc.
Some of your co-workers will be the type considered low-to-mid performers at other companies, just putting in the time to get a paycheck
Not a whole lot of career opportunities, I consider myself very fortunate to get the chances I had

pros:
9/80 Flex schedule 
Weekly pay
 Work life balance is okay but could be better. Sometimes you will have to work weekends.
Okay benefits
cons:
Favoritism and lots of covert racism

Promotion based on who your close to and who you know. Not based on actual metrics.
No bonuses for high performers
Company's priority is managers everyone else just passes through the farm.
Sucks the creativity and passion out of you
Poor decisions by management wastes millions per year
Too much politics even for a politician

pros: 9/80 Flex schedule - Every other Friday off.
cons:
HR and Recruiters' communication skills and professionalism are abysmal. 
There's very little to no opportunity for upward advancement.
Management is unable to do the one thing they are supposed to - manage.
Health benefits and benefits in general are horrific for a company this size. 
Resumes are thrown to the side by recruiters who don't even understand the job they are hiring for and are not even a part of the interviewing process.
The first 5 hours of overtime is considered "free" because "you are a professional and are expected to act as such" which is extremely unethical and most likely illegal. In this state, overtime MUST be paid unless the employer and employee both agree that any hours worked over 40 hours for the week will not receive compensation. No where do employees ever agree to this, Lockheed just doesn't pay for the first 5 hours of overtime.

review_title: Good job with lots of future potential
pros:
Flexibility of job assignments and opportunities to expand skill sets.  Since Lockheed is involved in so many projects you rarely become stagnant in your job.  they encourage employees to gain flexibility and experience in multiple areas both within their discipline and across disciplines.  
Senior management has taken a very proactive approach to leadership and strongly advocates leadership vs. management.
cons: Still very male dominated in the engineering workforce which is slowly changing but needs more hands on encouragement from senior management.  Although senior management appears to be aware that leadership skills are important and how they treat their team is important this is not being effectively practiced by lower level managers.

review_title: I love the company...pay could be better!
job_title: Database Administrator Associate in Orlando, FL
pros: Great Company. Very stable, many advancement opportunites. The people are respectful. You can create your own work schedule and there's a great balance between work and family life. I worked there as an intern and the intern program was building, but headed in the right direction. The access to people and information at the company is great. Doesn't take much to get the answer you need.
cons: The pay is lower than some other companies in it's bracket.. I think there could be a formal entry-level training program for those who are coming straight out college into the work force. Access to certain websites on the internet are limited such as personal e-mail cannot be accessed from the company''s network.

review_title: Lockheed - a good place to vacation from.
pros:
It is a steady job...while you have a contract.  In my experience it is a very flexible place to work - each vacation request I submitted has been approved, sometimes with only a week's notice.  Four weeks of vacation a year when you walk in the door is nice as well.

Once in, it is hard to get booted from all I have seen.
cons: The work is uninteresting, and the company is so big that your work rarely matters.  Pay is low, industry-wise.  The company is very top-heavy, and as they try to remedy this promotions are becoming harder to get.

review_title: Lockheed Martin, TSI - old style, heavy handed, uncaring, demoralizing management
job_title: Senior Software Developer Analyst in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The coworkers with whom you must suffer through become your comrades in the struggle to get through the next day.
cons: Managers are out of touch with their staff and they refuse to hire people with the skills to actually manage people correctly.  It's an "old boy network" and if you don't fit, don't expect to get anywhere.  And if you make any sort of wave, get ready to be punished until you are so demoralized and crushed you leave.

review_title: A good company to work for, but wouldn't want to be a lifer.
job_title: Human Resources in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great people, challenging work, a lot of flexibility in hours/vacation time, etc. Lots of internal positions to apply to in order to expand your knowledge base.
cons: Strong 'who you know' network that can hinder promotions. Higher ratings are determined by how much exposure you have had to senior leadership throughout the year. The more visible you are the higher you are rated. Strong cultural discrepancy between Baby Boomers and younger workforce. Healthcare plan has gone down the toilet. Pension plan not available for younger employees = no incentive to stay.

review_title: Some wonderful people to work with and a couple rotten eggs here and there.
job_title: Software Engineer Staff in Hanover, MD
pros: Lockheed pays a very comparable salary. If you are starting your career, there are many avenues you can pursuit. If you enter Lockheed as an experienced professional, the process, jargon and culture may be a problem at first. However, eventually you will become familiar with the Lockheed process which is exceptional.
cons: There are some wonderful people and there are a few rotten ones. One manager was hated by everyone, but everyone was afraid of her, so she held on for years terrorizing her group.  But I guess that sort of thing happens in other places too.

review_title: Make sure you don't end up on an off-site program'
job_title: Associate Software Developer in Halifax, NS
pros: Great people, managers are approachable and friendly.  Good benefits, good pension.
cons: Once you are on an off-site program you do not hear anything about other opportunities on other programs.   You get isolated and program managers do not want to lose you so you are not told about other programs.  As well since you are not in a main location managers from outside your program have no clue who you are.

pros: There are some smart people working on innovative projects (engineering,
cons: There is a lot of the blame game going on.  Any time anything doesn't flow at a normal pace, people are put into the fire.  This happens most on a contract work, no so much if you're charging overhead.  Also, there is a very standard career progression.  HR/management give promotions 90% based on years worked rather than actual skill.  There are plenty of times when more qualified individuals are overlooked because they haven't put their time in.

pros: Good pay and good benefits.  If you support the military it can be a satisfying place to work.
cons: Without a doubt the worst HR department bar none (Space Systems, Sunnyvale, CA).  In the Operations side of the house leadership is non-existent.  Company espouses “Full Spectrum Leadership”.  Unfortunately that’s about all they do regarding leadership.  Employee’s had to take flex time or personal time (after the 30 min regular lunch time) to attend Holiday lunch (which usually lasted 60 to 90 min) offered by the organization.

review_title: A company bleeding for the stock price
pros: Great company if you want to get a Master's to further your career, This is further exemplified in their corporate culture by increasing education benefits while cutting everything else.
cons: Poor pay, poor benefits (cut TWICE in 1.5 years), bad PTO, terrible work environment, and dense top leadership

pros: Great work environment, is it high pressure? Yes, its litterally rocket science somits going tombe a challenging job. I like being challenged and even though its challenging i never feel like expectations are too high for what i do. If you cantbtake the heat dont gominto the kitchen. This company sets the standard for beingninclusive. I aman older white male and i love that my employee is changing the old stereotypes, promoting women, minorities and rewarding the “best athlete” regardless of their gender or background.
cons: None, i love working for a highly professional organization where you are rewarded for hard work and the environment is inclusive and open.

review_title: Give it a go and move on when you're stuck
pros: Market rate pay and above average benefits. Organized company, professional and smart workforce. Roles can offer good schedule flexibility.
cons: The cronyism and age discrimination rampant  within certain functions prove to be career stoppers for many very talented people.  Best advice is once you see yourself getting stuck, move on. Despite the massive ego of that place, they aren't the only show in town.

review_title: Great for professional growth, not for personal growth or work-life balance.
job_title: Systems Integration Test Engineer Senior in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Challenging work environment with many opportunities to stretch into new areas.  Good pay, benefits and people.  This is a great technically fulfilling and professionally satisfying employer.
cons: Being such a large company many times the communication lines are very thin.  One can easily get lost in the mix.  The job posting internal and external is cumbersome and lacks feedback or responsiveness.  It seems sometimes that the benefits get cut continuously including tuition reimbursement, pension, and next to come health insurance.  Record profits don't mean record pay increases, just a higher standard for the next year.

pros: Brand recognition for the next employer; Great benefits; Good salary; Good tools; Women and Diverse employees given equal respect, recognition, and opportunities; Safe Environment; Exciting projects
cons: Laid me off at age 54, a few months prior to ability to retire with help towards the health insurance premiums upon retirement; largest age discrimination suit in history; very difficult to make changes..they look for the reasons NOT to rather than the reasons to make a change; follow rather than lead technology; reward following, keeping your head down, NOTsuggesting alternatives; cost driven rather than technology driven; treat the masses the same rather than truly distinguishing based upon performance; Very high turnover of new college grads, typically within 2 years of graduation when they can take their learned skills elsewhere

review_title: Entry level employee speaks on first impressions.
pros: Lots of opportunities across all the Lockheed locations in the US and abroad.  First and second level management is excellent where I work (I expect it's similar in other jobs).  The overall atmosphere is very welcoming.  Coworkers have been very helpful and are always willing to share information.  Moving into a new position within the company is very easy and management is always willing to help you advance your career.
cons: Weird health insurance plan, sort of lame corporate slogans and programs for motivating employees.  Upper level management sometimes doesn't seem as knowledgeable about what they're managing as they should be.  CIO was a business major and doesn't really have any technical knowledge about IT which is often quite frustrating.

review_title: Building closure in Eagan is a mess.
pros: Lots of upward mobility within the company.  The work is interesting.  If you want to relocate there are many branches across the country.
cons: Make no mistake, to the company you are a person that does work that they can charge the government for and replacing you is not a big deal to them.  I was in a skip-level lunch with an executive who said "Everyone is replaceable."

review_title: Sinking Ship and Management is to blame
pros:
We build technology that saves the lives of people.
There are some truly gifted engineers we get to work with at Lockheed Martin.
cons:
Managers have no practical skills related to the teams they manage (e.g. many managers leading software teams don't even have background in software).
Management regularly shows a high level of incompetence.
It's the good old boys club, promotions and raises are handed out to those who know how to "play nice" with the current leadership team.
Daily operations are plagued with red tape, usually red tape that isn't even necessary, it's just "the way we've always done things".

job_title: Applications Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Good company, 9/80 is good, over 45+ chargable hours and you can get paid overtime if you are salary.
cons:
High stress, micromanagement of time (i may put in 45 hours one week but the next week if I don't put in at least 40 I have to take vacation), that is not salary, that is hourly without 1.5 overtime over 40.  Growth is very, very, very, very slow.  I've been an HC (high contributor, aka better than average) for 4 years in a row and still no promotion (oh and I'm on the low end of the job levels).

Recent changes to Health Benefits also has caused more money out of pocket than raises i've seen over the past 5 years.  I'm making less than 5 years ago.

review_title: They hire and fire quickly and without concern for employee well-being
pros: A large organization, if you keep your head down, and have a solid education, you can have some job security.
cons:
Complete lack of concern for employees. They will hire someone away from another job, just to have them burn through some money for one week and then fire them. 
Pretentious, arrogant management.
During a serious snowstorm, the mayor of Baltimore declared it to be against the law for anyone to be on the streets driving in Baltimore due to overwhlemed city emergency response. Lockheed made sure that they declared themselves open, so that they could bill Social Security and not have to pay out to employees.
It's a good place to start out of school, but there are no raises, and you're simply filling a chair.

review_title: Great products, competitive salary/benefits, Good people. Middle level leadership issues
pros:
Highly technical, innovative products that serve the defense and space needs of our and many NATO countries.
Competitive salary and benefits.
Meaningful work assignments
cons:
Frequent restructuring and leadership changes leads to frequent direction changes in business operations and methods.  Gets disruptive to workforce.  At time middle management directs tasks without asking listening to or  asking for ideas and concerns of those tasked with carrying them out.  Often times work-life balance is work focused, unless you are in leadership positions.
Becoming increasing politically correct

review_title: Work Your Career and Company  Politics
job_title: Systems Engineer Senior Staff in San Jose, CA
pros: Get yourself selected for a leadership development program and you are on your way. Also, tools are provided for in-house skill development, as well as tuition  reimbursement for university degrees and occasionally, there are exciting projects on which to work.
cons: Because this is a business model that doesn't lend itself to producing a new product or service that can be widely sold, advancement can be uneven as there is not a product line to with which to grow.

review_title: Awesome company except the IS&GS division does not act like the rest of LockMart.
job_title: Software (Systems) Engineer, Senior Stf in Littleton, CO
pros: Best global security and defense company on the planet, they take pride of workmanship, develop the best and most complex technologies, and they are straightforward with Customers when there are problems without sugarcoating or waiting to hide the problem.
cons: The IS&GS division acts more like a blue collar IT and software house where people are treated as expendable, replaceable, and the technology is really not so amazing that the next IT company couldn't come along and take that business away easily, so costs have to be rock bottom, not the most motivating environment.

review_title: Overall good company, poor environment to work
job_title: Subcontract Administrator Asc in Atlanta, GA
pros:
People are amazing to work with.  Ultimate professionals, team works well together, good culture.  Managers are overall very competent. 
3 weeks of vacation to start, 1 week of sick time.  Every other Friday off.  Flextime-telecommuting privileges. 
Promotions come from within almost always.
cons: LM micro-manages their employees to no end.  It goes as far as asking its employees to sign out on a white board when they leave.  Pay is horrible, if you start as a level 1 employee, they wont negotiate with you.  Promotions are nonexistent until you hit year 3-4.  Switching jobs internally is also nearly impossible with poor performance review.  Human resources reps are dishonest and misleading.  LM has become a stepping stone for me.  It looks decent on a resume but cant see anyone working here long term unless you have your MBA.

pros: Good benefits, climate controlled hangars (heat), company supplied tools, lots of company events where food and souvenirs are given out
cons: extreme lack of aviation experience within management, no aircraft familiarization courses or training provided to employees (with minor exceptions), company supplied tools, management expects and forces certain people to act as leads without officially giving them the title and paying them accordingly, the ACE program has wasted more time and money than it has saved, the left hand doesn't know what the right is doing

job_title: Systems Engineer in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: Easy to get learning and going. People are very friendly and easy to work with. Many opportunities to move around within the company or even across business units. Work/life balance is pretty good - get a lot of holidays and they operate on a 9/80 schedule which gives you every other Friday off.
cons: Too traditional in how the company operates. Majority of the employees are much older so processes don't change very much and it can be hard to really implement change in any way. Working for a defense contractor requires a certain personality and don't expect to be impresses by the office space or buildings. Lockheed hardly upgrades anything except their products.

review_title: Lockheed Martin - Great Place to Work Even If You Are a Useless Tool
pros: Good pay, good benefits, great opportunities to do exciting and fun work. Ethics really IS important and not just noise from above. Leaders, for the most part, are high quality.
cons: Management forced to hold on to dead weight underperformers to keep HR happy and do so at the detriment of the competant, valued workers. More overhead money is spent on a select few than on the training people need to do their jobs.

review_title: More downs than ups, but the ups are very nice.
pros: Great pay and benefits.  GIves me a sense of accomplishment to work for such an admired company.  For the most part great people, and pretty cool to think of the end product to which you work towards.
cons: Looooong hours most of the time (50+/wk) when it gets busy.  Complexity of information is insane; you must be VERY technologically inclined to have any kind of idea what's going on.  No accountability of upper management and no sense of ugrency.  You get piled with work right before it's due for projects that take weeks, yet those that need it want it in days.

review_title: Interesting work, good leadership opportunities, low pay, sluggish environment
pros: There are a lot of interesting projects.  They pay for overtime... anything over 45 hours a week.  Flexible schedule.  Good leadership training opportunities.  There are a lot of opportunities because the company is so large.  There are opportunities in every state, and in every field.  The benefits are very good.  There is a leadership program for young engineers where they invest quite regularly in training and social event.
cons: Pay is less than other places.  Extreme risk aversion leads to a sluggish environment where technology is not adopted too quickly.  There is a huge amount of process overhead and not all of it is worth while.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to be an engineer
job_title: Research Engineer Staff (4) in Greenbelt, MD
pros: Lockheed Martin is one of the premier aerospace and defense contractors for a reason.  They work on the leading technology in the world.  They respect engineers and the work we do - I love the flex time, independence of work, and casual dress.   It's a great work-life balance with opportunity for flex time and part time work.
cons: LM is a huge corporation with lots of beauracracy.  You can sit in the same cubicle for decades doing the same job, if you're not careful.  Low performing employees are kept regardless of the effect on the team.  (Which I suppose is a pro if you're a slacker...)

pros: The work was reliable, even during the economic downturn.  Lockheed employees get some excellent employee discounts from companies.  They paid for security clearance for me, which is often difficult to get an employer to spring for.
cons: The group I was with had no connections to the rest of the company, and appeared to have been forgotten.  The portions of the company responsible for making promises to the government didn't seem to have any communication with the portions responsible for fulfilling those promises.  The company provides every kind of service and product to the government, so they don't specialize or excel in anything.

job_title: Information Security Engineer in Orlando, FL
pros: The company has a really good benefits package.  There is much room for growth and they are big on encouraging employees to improve themselves for both their benefit and the company's benefit.  Happy people produce more.  There is always a new challenge to face and great people to face it with.
cons: Only real complaint is that the health insurance could be better.  $3k deductible for a family is a bit much.  I would like it if they allowed OT to be paid more freely.  (straight time for us exempt folks)  If you are willing to work 60 hours a week, then why not get paid for it when the need is definitely there?

job_title: Systems Engineer Staff in Boulder, CO
pros: Great benefits. Large company provides room to move up within the company. All kinds or support resources are available. Has mature processes structure.
cons: Work is tied to programs, so when a program nears its end then you need to find other work. This fine if there are other programs at the same site, otherwise you'd have to move. I've had to move twice and now again it is time to find work elsewhere. Managers tend to favor some and so they give them what work there is, not necessarily qualification based.

job_title: ESH Engineer, Senior in Newtown, PA
pros: Great company, good leadership, excellent leadership development and career development programs.  Excellent mission overall at all levels.  I work in compliance and thoroughly enjoy working with the professionals in my department and across all functional areas every day.
cons: Not really a 'con', but something to be aware of:  because of the critical nature of our mission, Lockheed is heavily process oriented.  There are many procedures, quality checks, reporting processes, and other administrative requirements.

job_title: Aviation Structural Sheetmetal Mechanic in Lexington, KY
pros: Had a great work group. Mostly all Vets, made some real good friends there. Loved the customer we worked for. Had a lot of pride working on the aircraft that I did. Flex schedule was awesome. Basically, as long as you get your 40 hours in, they really didn't mind how you got there.
cons: Management never let us know how the company was doing, what the future was holding for us. Then one day, layoffs because of ending of a contract.

pros: Very pleasant atmosphere, most of the people are polite and friendly.  The pay is good and the job offers plenty of opportunity for advancement
cons: Some people may not like the early morning hours and the very busy days. Also when the treat level is raised it requires a lot more detailed responsibilities.

pros: Found another job.  Stable employment due to strong role in government contracts and defacto "tenure".  Many can work here their whole career. Found a way to get paid a $1B retainer by the US gov. to "be there" in case the gov needs a rocket.  Cost of rocket not included.
cons: Exemplifies the inefficiency of government work and wasted tax dollars.  Massive overhead and a constant stream of "VPs".  Aggressive Corporate Policy crosses the line on privacy.  Operations based on an endless system of paperwork rather than wise and logical decision making by the people qualified to make those decisions.  A great example - the recent "success" of the F35 program - 7 years late and $200B over budget.

review_title: Not at all what I expected
pros: Worked as a Mechanical Engineer overseas. The money was good, the benefits ok, and the working conditions were manageable.
cons: I just hope this is not what LMC is all about, our superiors were unable to place a round peg into a round hole if you held their hand.  NO LEADERSHIP whatsoever and the people on top only hire their buddies for the lead jobs.  No advancement unless you are related to someone.

pros: I've met some of the most brilliant but down-to-earth people while working at the Lake Underhill location. Great range of ages, with lots of young, new talent from the nearby university (UCF). The environment is laidback for the most part, and you will be hard-pressed to find comparable jobs in the area that offer the same level of pay and benefits.
cons: Easy to get stuck working on the same product for years in the same role if not aggressively pursuing other opportunities. I don't know how this can be remedied because most of the work is supporting products that have been around for years and will continue to be around in the future. It's just the nature of the business.

review_title: Great company but they dont promote often and annual raises have gotten laughably low
pros: Great company to have on resume, lots of different jobs to do if you want to, good benefits and vacation time, flexibility of work hours, 9/80
cons: Advancement can be throttled if you have a bad manager, in seat promotions are nearly impossible to get, performance rating system is terrible you can work hard all year and get a lousy raise bc your manager didnt fight for you. Here, you need to be in the bosses inner circle to get ahead so network hard!

review_title: Upper management is only focused on schedule and dates at expense of quality
job_title: Staff Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Could be a fun place to work but requires a major culture shift
cons: The culture and mentality of upper management is always looking for scapegoats for their failed planning. CEO allows the culture to interfere with success. Program almost  a decade late yet being ran by the same management team. Where is accountability at the management level?

pros: There is a certain prestige to working for Lockheed Martin that I enjoyed while working there. Ability to apply anywhere in the company internally and you are given preference over outsiders. They paid for my master's degree.
cons: The benefits went downhill, health insurance had huge deductible, lots of managers and not enough workers and on my contract they were laying off more workers to keep budget for managers that couldn't even tell you what they did daily.

review_title: LMC is a solid, smart company to work for
job_title: Software Engineer Senior in Washington, DC
pros: A lot of flexibility in work schedules; for the most part, employees tend to be good, all-around, solid, decent people; compensation is at least competitive; I believe in the work they do
cons: There are some companies that may pay better; dealing with some of the bureaucracy of a huge company (it could be must worse and you are bound to get some of this in any large company -but it is a downer); company tends to be a little more formal - it's understandable why, but it takes a little of the fun out of it; monetary bonuses seem few and far between

job_title: Signals Analyst in Newport News, VA
pros: Generally low stress environment compared to other positions in LM.  Flexible shift schedule allows employee to adjust accordingly for circumstances (sickness, holidays, etc...).  Excellent benefits that compete with most others in the industry.
cons: Very poor vetting of co-workers (new hires do not have the correct skills, and are unwillingly/difficult to train).  Working at a customer site which causes interference with regularly scheduled work hours.  16.5% of pay is not given when working other than contract hours (taking holidays, sick leave, etc... causes a reduction in pay).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
Decent salary for getting back into the work force, but below what I should be making in the position. 
Great people to work for, at least immediate supervision and coworkers.
cons:
The job was a complete baite and switch, with no real way to progress. I was expecting a technician job to grow my skills, but I am only doing inventories and coordinating other contractors to do the "real work". 
Don't get me wrong, it's a great job if you like little to no supervision and sitting on a computer all day looking at spreadsheets.

pros: Great company overall. Many on-site options.. nurse, bank, food. Benefits are good. The facility is not very difficult to get to since it is right off the highway.
cons:
Your happiness here may be project based. For ALIS F35 -
Absolutely zero consideration for employee work life balance on ALIS F35 project. General consensus is if you don't like it leave. Yes they pay OT without a time gate. However its only hourly not time and a half.  Company claims to run a 9x80 flex. You will most likely work 10-12x120.
